Rarely do we get to enjoy such complex, adult characters, realistic dialogue and stunning imagery in the fantastic genres.
The absence of true grit and dirt-under-fingernails feeling weaken the believability of the drama.

Patrick Lussier's sharp editing and Rob McLachian's crisp camerawork add punch from beginning to end, drawing in viewers to a thriller where there are no extras, scene changes or variance of any kind.
What rescues this telepic are the accidents, searches for stranded skiers and the like.
Gets awfully slow awfully fast.
The real star here is the ensemble cast.
Fact-based stories are now the norm rather than the exception in TV land, and as is the case here, not all headlines can sustain a two-hour treatment.
Director Georg Stanford Brown keeps the energy hot and heavy, even with the limitations of made-for-TV production. Vidpic efficiently illuminates another Vietnam tragedy.
movie_title: The Last P.O.W.? The Bobby Garwood Story (1992)

movie_review_blurb: The range and impact of hate rock and its message isn't gauged here, but it's encouraging to see this type of programming on MTV and it's also encouraging to see that the much-maligned MTV does have a conscience.
Medical movies are nothing new but the way the action here is kept out of the hospital and the injection of realism into the script and acting makes For the Love of My Child a healthy TV experience.
movie_title: For the Love of My Child: The Anissa Ayala Story (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Art School likely will entertain a sophomoric audience and etch some winning college-kid figures, but art house audiences will be disappointed by its paint-by-numbers storytelling.
Tthose who reveled in such cinematic synapses as the eyeball being slit in Un Chien Andalou will gravitate toward this outrageous, and frequently hilarious, piece de film.
An affectionate, comprehensive overview of Hollywood's blockbusters and bombs.
Dragging along in a tedious rhythm of long-take, big-talk, Hamaca Paraguaya is a cinematic bust.
A delightful diversion.
A deliriously funny romantic roundelay.
Brick is a dazzling slab of hard noir storytelling.
Hong Sangsoo's character development and, similarly, relationship progression never develop beyond the slam-bang aspects of romance.
movie_title: Woman is the Future of Man (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It is smartly and convincingly fleshed out, at least enough to fit inside and burst the seams of generic dimension.
This smart, aesthetically understated concert film from Jonathan Demme will transport Young's legions of baby boomer fans back to the future, as 1969 re-invents itself in 2005 for Young.
It's a textural mindblower and a lot of fun.
A moving drama of one young mother's drug addiction.
Develops slowly, almost painfully so, but those mature viewers who stay with it will embrace a mature and stirring glimpse of 'true love' in one of its three vignettes.
After a while, the crudeness and venality of the central characters proves as stifling as the incessant Queens summer heat does to our dubious protagonists.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A brainy blend of farce and heart, this is one of those movies that veteran moviegoers complain they don't make anymore.
At its most stimulating, Moustache is a keen glimpse into a marriage that appears perfect on the surface but when examined shows its deficiencies.
Distilled to a more endurable length, this insightful odyssey might best serve as a required text for graduating medical students and hospital administrators.
The narrative is so scant that watching the film's weather is the chief pleasure.
It's unlikely that even the most sophisticated or jaded of festival audiences will kindly endure the onslaught of viciousness on display.
Visually, Free Zone resembles a home movie in which an overly enthusiastic vacationer records every moment of a mundane trip.
Kilometre Zero offers a searing look into the horrors the people of Iraq, specifically the Kurds, suffered under the brutish tyranny of Saddam Hussein.
Only when the multicultural conceit of vastly different musical traditions blending to produce a transcendent sound is muted does the film finally jell.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pithy and highly amusing.
Plodding and predictable.
[The] overriding deceptions and flaws give ample cause for an early annulment with discerning viewers.
5 Days should enthrall viewers interested in the Israel-Palestinian conflicts, as well as those generally interested in prescriptive conflict resolution.
A missed-love story with people you don't care about.
Mired by director Cherie Nowlan's indelicate direction. Nowlan pumps the drama, as well as the comedy, to blaring pitch. Similarly, several attempts at cutesiness slog down into rank contrivance.
A warm family drama pops through the seams of a film within-a-film about Silvio Berlusconi.
More a home movie than a documentary film.
Amazingly dunderheaded.
Chock full of elements that never spark beyond one-sheet dimension.
The imagery of the classic movie, where a spirited red balloon wafts unpredictably over Paris, never even attempts to reach a metaphorical height, nor does it even engage us compositionally.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This girl-talk comedy is a cut below its predecessors.
Evinces an appealing sentimentality without being maudlin or only puppy-dog cute.
A frothy delight, robust with strong and conflicted characters.
A stirring and heart-wrenching statement of the horrible powers that mankind holds in its fist.
movie_title: White Light/Black Rain: The Destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's horrific and important subject matter is distilled into a lackluster lump of generic buddy-movie/road-picture components.

Chapter 27 is a smart attempt to distill the twisted psychology and motivation of Mark David Chapman, which we've all superficially gleaned through mass-media reports and intermittent updates on Chapman's incarceration.
A brilliant house-of-horror tale with Hitchcockean flair.

Son of Rambow is pumped up with all the right kids' ingredients: slapstick, fantasy, alienation and severe adult authority figures. But screenwriter and director Garth Jennings has slammed them all together with little cohesion.
A rousing documentary on the street children of Cairo, These Girls is an agonizing and uplifting depiction of street survival at its most daunting.
A masterful distillation of explosive elements: science, art, psychology and humanity.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An uplifting yarn as a young American Indian ventures from the reservation.
Samuel L. Jackson knocks out a championship performance in this gritty, uplifting tale about an ex-boxer.
Year of the Dog ambles with both light humor and dark insights. Filmmaker Mike White's easy comic touch graces the storyline, unleashing some amusing comic characters, as well.
While often hard to watch because of its unflinching portrayal of the ugliness that love can take, Snow Angels succeeds because of the depth of its well-drawn characters.
A touching and unlikely romance that is no gloss but all heart and brains.

We can hear the French barking "auteur" already... Beneath the profanely preposterous premise, Stay is a rather sweet and conventional love story that perambulates around the notions of trust and acceptance.
This well-made film illuminates the power of a charismatic personality in rousing the multitudes.
In this affectionate glimpse into those countercultural times, filmmaker Stuart Samuels has compiled an engaging distillation of those nocturnal filmic emissions.
movie_title: Midnight Movies: From the Margin to the Mainstream (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Much brainier than a John Waters opus, Avida eructs with deadpan hilarity through a series of nonsequential comic set pieces.

Scene after scene of verbose fiddle-faddle: Characters orate at each other, while sitting in cars, sitting at dining tables, sitting in living rooms, sitting at office desks. The film might be better titled The Big Sit.
A misguided blasphemy of "Bicycle Thief," downloaded through film-noir affectations, this Competition Entrant is morally specious and narratively nonsensical.
Predictable and narratively uninspired, this Un Certain Regard entrant is unlikely to generate interest beyond its homeland.
Launches into the audience-pleasing stratosphere with a brainy, unpredictable story orbit.

Screenwriter-director Brewer transcends his generic story, laying out his beat from each character's heart. We come to know their inner fears and demons, including those of some particularly well-drawn supporting characters.
A chokehold of a movie, grabbing us but not ultimately engaging us.
The Jacket is not likely to be everyone's cup of tea, but filmmaker John Maybury has forged a mesmerizing mindblower.

Tarantino's lined up a fine cast to play his assorted snotwads, grimeballs, sleazoids, small-timers, druggies and bulletheads in this 1990s version of a down-and-dirty 1940s pulp fictioner, the kind Dash Hammett and the boys used to crank out.
Those who survive it emerge in a shell-shocked euphoria -- so good and so blunt is the writing.
Despite the evocative aesthetics evincing the hollow state of modern love life, the film never percolates beyond a monotonous whine.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Intelligently crafted and often insightful.
An insightfully cheeky entertainment.
In every respect, director Gary Winick has served up a delectable, entertaining film.
In this involving film of three decidedly different women, filmmaker Rebecca Miller has distilled some gripping character portraits.
It's a vibrant, embracing film of people on the fringe of mainstream America.
An engrossing portrait of a man whose engaging manner and flamboyant style made him a truly larger-than-life character.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: In general, the film is a series of Broomfield popping up Michael Moore-style, unannounced, and drilling the unsuspecting subjects with invasive and blunt questions.
An absorbing, slice-of-depression life that touches nerves and rings true.
It smartly delineates the hard choices that people without many options must make, and its treatment of their conflicted situations is respectful but highly comic.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: LaBute hammers this Shape to smithereens with argument after argument.
'Butterfingered' is the word for the big-fisted direction of Jez Butterworth, who manages to blast even the smallest sensitivities from the romance with his clamorous approach.
At its best, Bark! has some good bits, but it also has some numbingly irritating sequences.
An uneven mix of dark satire and childhood awakening.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some harsh patterns, it's a stunningly warm tapestry of human beings struggling to endure despite all things.
An absorbing and unsettling psychological drama.
Provides both a searing satire of modern suburbia and provocative insight into the malignant maturation of generally well-meaning and privileged kids.
We're left with a voyeuristic view of some strangers' lives whom we're never interested in other than, of course, an initial prurient curiosity.
There are fine performances and smart comic flourishes throughout.
A wild ride with eight boarders from Venice Beach that was a deserved co-winner of the Audience Award for documentaries at the Sundance Film Festival.
A thoughtful and compassionate story of a young girl.
A sobering, highly entertaining insight into the innards of that up-and-down business world.
It's sophisticated, both intellectually and morally!
In pacing and vitality, this is almost as listless as its drab lead character.
A sobering and powerful documentary about the most severe kind of personal loss: rejection by one's mother.
In this day of dummying-down and coddling students, it's refreshing to see a teacher push his students to levels of accomplishment they didn't think was possible.
It's juiced with recognizable family trauma and garnished with a quirky sensibility -- it's the portrait of a group of people we come to care about.
A generally tasty entertainment that is both engaging and uplifting.
Playing at 158 minutes, Mondovino's essence would be more flavorful, as well as powerful, if distilled to half that time.
The film is not sheer wizardry; it also has heart.
A superb coming-of-age film with international appeal.
Estes has crafted a realistic and rich portrait of the moral dilemmas that adolescents experience.
A smartly scoped story of great personal growth and transformation.
Told with a tender vigor, the film explores relationships on a number of levels.
A grand story of redemption, laced with barbecued wit and slopped with intrigue.
Delirious sendup of girl-power films.
A stunning, difficult film.

Saved! serves up the treachery of modern-day high school crowded with stereotypical characters and generic conventions. Unfortunately, the film pontificates with a smug brashness, glorifying in its own slight subversions.
Throughout, we're constantly rooting for Maria, aware of her underlying decency and protective of her missteps.
[A] smart insight into modern-day relationships.
Hats off to Michael Polish for his otherworldly slants on the barren expanse of this far-out Americana essay.
A sleek psychological thriller outwitted by its own hyper craftsmanship.
In its very calibrations, from Scott Alan Kosar's edgy, spooky script to Anderson's provocative visualizations of Trevor's disintegrating mind-set, The Machinist is a gem.
It's more muscle than high-formula, and it clanks, sputters and spins out in its pedal-to-the-story medal style.
Nicely enough, it's packed with droll humor and smart compassion.
It is both piercingly insightful and kindhearted.
An extremely well-modulated and mature work, especially for a first-time filmmaker.
Both an appealing coming-of-age yarn and, as Monsieur Ibrahim embraces his own mortality, a heartfelt coming-of- aging saga.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Screenwriter Joe Wein has smartly wired these three bizarre personal stories into a raucously satisfying triumph of good over evil.
It's got the kick, style and flavor of a straight-up story, before movies were watered down with the opinions of marketers, lawyers and committee heads.
An engaging, sympathetic portrait of junior high girls who have grown up too fast and way too little.
A masterful film and a bracing movie experience.
Both a satiric and level-headed slant on collegiate life and big-time sports, Bookies is an eye-opening amusement.
Consistently touching, The Event brims with compassionate insight.
While the plot whirls around with a number of deft twists and deepens into darker layers, the story is emotionally uninvolving.
A talking-heads, philosophic tedium posing as a film.
A searing story of addictive behavior.
An intelligent, if non-illuminating, look at an organization.
This rebirth is almost a casebook study of how not to transpose "literature" to film.
Neither scary nor shocking.
If you believe in magic, Life, Animated is the potion for you.
Filmmaker Penny Lane (real name) spoon-feeds the audience the myth that we so steadfastly cling to. Then, she pulls the rug out.

Nearly the entire film is shot with hand-held cameras... Throughout, Wang makes a virtue out of necessity: Her on-the-run scoping and jarring cuts infuse the film with a sense of desperate danger befitting its subject matter.

Mixing interviews with the staffs of the surviving clinics with heartbreaking accounts of botched, private abortions, Trapped is a succinct and heart-rending revelation of this complex and controversial subject.
The film is a captivating, sobering look at the world's endangered aquatic species, but it's also a frightening revelation of what methane and carbon are doing to the ocean.
[A] full-bodied and thoughtful HBO documentary.
Both a comprehensive personality profile, as well as a smart depiction of Americana.

Interspersing clips of his daredevil comedy days in Boston to more recent sojourns at his reclusive upstate New York dwelling, [the] film is both a personality profile and a sociological-political satire of the places and times that Crimmins skewered.
This well-constructed, thoughtful documentary could be used as an instructional aide in criminal justice courses, ethics courses, as well as law-enforcement agencies.
Cartel Land [is a] spellbinding, verite documentary -- a frontline look at the murderous Mexican drug cartels.
In the lead roles, both Robbins and Freeman are outstanding, layering their performances with snippets of individuality: Their small, daily sustenances and minor triumphs are wonderfully inspiring.

Despite the juicy, on-the-edge craziness, Murray is able to layer his outrageous histrionics with an inner sensibility, making his ultimate transformation not only believable but Christmas-cheer uplifting.

While meticulously drawn, the film's characters are so stereotypically representative that only the lamest of moviegoers will not determine their respective backgrounds and problems long before the plodding movie does.
While Murray's deadpan putdowns and dry dismissals of provincial peccadilloes are the comic highlights, Groundhog Day is no supercilious rip of small-town U.S.A.

Extraordinary portrayals of everyday people characterize the contribution of director Mike Nichols' talented diverse cast. Once again, Nichols justifies his past plaudits for bringing the best out of his players.
Radice's filmic delivery breaks sharply from just a sports-story to an intensely personal story as well as a glimpse into the social/political cataclysms of the 1960 and '70s.
A hard-eyed but empathetic glimpse into the hardscrabble lives of struggling Missouri folk.
While one might agree or disagree with their theme, aesthetically Citizen Koch is feisty.
A stirring documentary about an exploited pair of Siamese twins who attained notoriety and suffered tragically.
Throughout, its exhibitionist proclivities are evened-out under director Geoffrey Sax's astute guidance and the intelligent, nuanced performances of Berry and Skarsgard.

veteran filmmaker Stanley Nelson has crafted a searing portrait of those violent, racist times. Intelligently composed and powerfully driven, Freedom Summer is a stirring historical document. It would seem an essential addition for any university library.
The Battered Bastards of Baseball is not just about baseball. It transcends the game and is a charming anti-establishment yarn that should delight audiences who don't even know an r.b.i. from a balk.
It's a comprehensive portrayal of these people's personal and professional lives. We see what makes them tick. Are they adrenaline junkies? Thrill-seekers? Not at all.
A moving document of what it means to be a minority in an exclusive, high-performing school.

Colossally ambitious, this logistically boggling and technically brilliant film from writer-director James Cameron is a visual tour de force, featuring overall, the greatest underwater sequences ever seen on film.
Compelling insight into the staggering pressures faced by court-appointed public defenders.
The chief wonder of this rock 'n' roll cast is Tom Everett Scott, whose easy charisma, dreamy smile and undersurface intelligence should shoot him up the acting charts like a bullet.

The best thing about Good Will Hunting is not in its well-crafted, psychological symmetries but in the just-plain messiness of its humanity. It's rowdy, it's funny, it's heartbreaking - it rings of life.
Not so much an entertainment or even an illumination, but rather a personal cinematic scrapbook, which should be stamped 'return to sender.'
Hopkins' performance is spectacularly unnerving and should win him future award nominations. Holding her own against Hopkins' hare is Jodie Foster as the tenacious, tortoise-like trainee.

While nicely layered with tough, conflicting personal questions, Ducks ultimately flaps off into easy outcomes and pat contrivances. Still it's an overall charmer, and director Stephen Herek keeps it flying with a nifty mix of slapstick and action.
While not a pretty picture - no ride-into-the-sunset cliches - Unforgiven is a magnificently realized work. In addition to Eastwood's fine, rough performance, Hackman and Freeman stand out.
While much is in the Animal House vein and quite funny, several tasteless episodes mar the film.
Admittedly, the film is bolted to an intriguing psychological/paranormal premise, but the narrative trudges along in a fitful monotony of somber tones and stodgy pacing.
Bernie's is good old, knock-down slapstick with just the right dose of cruelty thrown in.

There is an abundance of astute and knowledgeably drawn scenes with this contextually structured story. There are some biting observations of college life, with law school in particular taking some verbal jabs on the chin.
Light and likable, with hearts unabashedly all over its sleeves, Roxanne is a winning romantic comedy whose appeal should cross age barriers and backgrounds -- giving it an across-the-board promise.
A bittersweet, modern-love morsel, this scrumptious drama should touch moviegoers' hearts in this action gorged summer.
Packed high with explosive action and loaded with high-stakes jeopardy, Con Air charts a generally sound narrative course, although it hits some story turbulence before it hits its climactic jackpot.
One of the most amusing entertainments to come around in a while is Fletch, an amiable comedy/thriller starring Chevy Chase.

Jordan's superstar persona and serious demeanor are well-suited for his role, essentially that of a straight man. His unruffled confidence and restless energy make him the perfect star and the perfect foil for his new 2-D teammates.

In Costner, writer-director Robinson has found the perfect player for a personal-stakes game, a guy with a leg-it-out intensity and kidlike enthusiasm. It's Costner's eye-on-the-ball exuberance that carries Dreams past its often mechanical aesthetic ...
Vinny is a winning character and Pesci's performance as the beleaguered litigant is terrific - cranked yet cuddly.

It's a rambunctious comedy, coming from director Ron Howard who, with his previous, wacky Night Shift, unarguably shows that beneath that Opie Taylor/Richie Cunningham persona, there's a wild and crazy spirit.
Unfortunately, while Black's assembled all the parts, he's not locked in the conflict early enough, and the good scenes simply aren't enough good to make up for the plot's too-late lock.
Former Israeli Navy Seal and filmmaker Shimon Dotan has delivered a ticking encapsulation of the never-ending conflicts revolving around the Israeli settlements in the West Bank.
Whoever catered this set must have served extra good donuts and stuff because the acting is real good and we're not just talking about Lowe's deep-smoothie performance.
Narratively, this crazy-grid comedy is slighter than a plate of California cuisine, but what it lacks in solid bulk it more than makes up for in its neon array of oddball cultural colors.
As the big brute, Bautista is endearing in an against-type performance, while Snow wins our sympathies as the ditzy college student.
A rousing documentary on a youth movement against, essentially, educational brainwashing.

A heartfelt and stirring documentary about the extraordinary love for life of Simon Fitzmaurice, an Irish writer and filmmaker stricken with a devastating ALS diagnosis but determined to never give in.
Bratt fleshes her out in fullest political and social dimension, but also captures her personal life and driven personality.
A stunning documentary about a team of young people - Paul Farmer, Jim Yong Kim, Ophelia Dahl - whose charitable medical work 30 years ago in remote Haiti came to ignite a healthcare movement.
While Stone has certainly stirred up the waters, with good conscience and, in JFK's own parlance, "with vigah," most people are likely to regard JFK as BS.
Carrey has never been better - that is to say funnier, or more controlled. He's reached a higher performance plateau here, playing a real human being we care about rather than a goon figure.
Enthralling and revealing portrait of Anita Hill, whose Senate Judiciary testimony led the country to recognize workplace sexual harassment.
What makes this movie work is Jennifer Lopez's electric performance as Selena, capturing the charismatic aspects of Selena's stage persona and the essence of her maturity as a growing woman.
Delisle blends stark visual images with character voice-overs to convey the hurt and isolation that one family faces because one of its members is imprisoned.
A charming old-fashioned romantic comedy transposed to today's global dating world.
movie_title: The Other End of the Line (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A remembrance of things past, it's also a sobering realization for the filmmaker that past places only dimly still exist.
A sobering and resonant tale.
An edgy entertainment, the movie also remarkably has the feel-good warmth of an old-time Irish film.
Succinct in its visualizations and crisp in its pacing, its deferential storytelling is in sync with its Odd subject.
A funny, scary send-up of filmmakers.
Can you inflate a gimmick-driven comedy skit into a full-fledged feature film? Up to a point.
Members of the gutter-al elite will be the sole survivors.
A booming, heart slam of a film.
With this reverential biopic, director Richard Attenborough has cranked out a many-reel, talky talkie.
A raunchy between-the-sheets peak at modern-day black sexuality...should woo urban audiences to the theater.
movie_title: A Good Day to Be Black & Sexy (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A comprehensive, even-keeled depiction of today's recruiting process, An American Soldier brims with insight and drops us on the domestic front-lines of our military.
With a keen affection for his own formative years, filmmaker Greg Mottola has crafted a funny and spunky amusement.
A well-made, neo-Western from Norwegian directors.
Pierces the senses.
Stirringly told, American Son dramatizes a harsh social reality and tributes this nation's fighting force.
An erratic, freewheeling satire of Middle American mores.
It's the players that invigorate The Mysteries of Pittsburgh and keenly flesh-out its emotional dimensions.
Inspired a packed Sundance house to forget their Saturday-night pains and stand up and cheer.
Filmmaker-actor Ray McKinnon voices his Southern droll in this amusing, feel-good comedy.
A visually arresting but emotionally uninvolving dark comedy.
[A] searing documentary on the genocide in Darfur.
The well-selected cast is winningly sympathetic and entertainingly idiosyncratic.
With their detached, sardonic and decidedly sick slant, Jeunet and Caro have served up a burnt-to-a-crisp feast.
Touching and brilliantly envisioned story of a young, nearly blind teen's first love.
movie_title: What They Don't Talk About When They Are Talking About Love (Yang tidak dibicarakan ketika membicarakan cinta) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Radiant and wise comedy of miscommunication.
This slight-framed bird never soars and ultimately crashes under the weight of its excessive thematic ballast.
An overwhelming, masterful dramatic competition entrant, this Lee Daniels film may have no bounds in the awards categories.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The mesmerizing performance of [Elle] Fanning as the gifted and troubled young Phoebe sparks the picture.
Story and style are all over the place, rendering it somewhat inaccessible. Admittedly, the whole film is in a bit of an aesthetic dither, which will confound many viewers.
A visit to the depressed, rural mire of a nondescript country.
movie_title: The Machine Which Makes Everything Disappear (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "The Thorn in My Heart" should be intriguing to all who know the family, as well as to cineastes yonder at the arty film schools who will lap up its elliptical/self-reflexive style. Normal people will simply walk out on it.
Compounding [its] bodily gross-outs, Hoffmann has drenched the film with accompanying tonal annoyances: insect buzzing, metal scrapings and human grunting.
A gripping, cliffhanger document of a deadly trek up the most dangerous mountain on earth where 11 climbers lost their lives.
Standout performances from Pacino, Walken and Arkin as old-timers prove that losing a step can't keep you off your feet.
Heartfelt depiction of first-crush love for two Chicana girls.
Crowd-pleasing comedy from stand-up Mike Birbiglia.
Triumph on the basketball court catalyzes national identity for Lithuania in this historical/magical masterwork.
Although it gives Willis and Whitaker an off-road chance to show off their character-actor chops, there's not much to recommend in this cinematic conceit.
Battling-buddy road movie carries viewers on an entertaining ride into blues country.
Rich portrait of the Feminist Art Movement.

Attenberg is distinguished aesthetically by cinematographer Thimios Bakatakis eye for both the beauty of coastal Greece and the hideousness of its mineral factories, conveying, like the film itself, the life-giving and life-taking moments in our lifetimes.
Double-barreled mayhem as if Sergio Leone designed a video-game.
Compelling glimpse into artistic compulsion in video games.
A well-assembled sci-fi thriller.
Technically facile grope at dark romance.
A sophomoric comedy with honor-roll style and smarts.
Romance and horror of personality don't jell in this skimpy drama.
A well-stirred titillation that will appeal to twentysomething audiences and movie-buff viewers who appreciate the pursued-pursuer, Hitchcockian style of suspenser.
Dark and engrossing look at a sports fanatic.
The Greatest pulls off a stunning fete, drawing an audience into a comprehensive film about grief.
A delirious satire of British jihadists.
Penetrating but tedious close-up of a marriage breakup.
Like a good ad, Art & Copy bounds along and never bores. That's a big credit to Pray's savvy compilation and of editor Phillip Owens' crisp cuts.
The John Hughes-style teen comedy has been revived in France. The French Kissers is funny because it rings true, in any language.
An unpretentious, subtle story of one man's redemption.
Powerful takedown of the financial services industry and Wall Street greed.
Genre groupies and Mamet maniacs should find the effort absorbing.
While the PG-13 rating makes it impossible to portray the actual battle realistically, this could otherwise be the most 'accurate' version of The Alamo to date, which isn't saying much.
It is good, old-fashioned, sword-and-sandal storytelling with multiple close-ups of sweaty hunks but is classic only by Hollywood's diminished definition of the word.
His performance is a vivid reminder that Sharif, 71, is still out there and capable of doing fine work when it is offered to him.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It remains a surprisingly instructive and cautionary lesson in the way that populist movements can burn parent states down to their grass roots.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Hellboy is the most engaging comic-book movie character to emerge in years, and his complex personality is perfectly personified by Ron Perlman, with a prosthetic assist.
As My Architect blossoms into a reunion of Kahn's human and artistic legacy, we see how changing light and passing time animate all our lives.
It's clear Theron didn't so much resemble [Wuornos] as she did channel her deeply tormented soul, in a way that Broomfield never manages to do.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Often heavy-handed and obvious.
Intermission may be more Love Actually-familiar than Robert Altman-intricate but is ultimately engaging on its own terms.
An impressive, engrossing and almost nostalgic tribute to a world found only in the movies, and to the movies it was found in.
While Washington has a sullen physicality, he is just too good and too smart of an actor to be credible as a character that is a bit more up Vin Diesel's alley.
Exasperating and nearly three-hour blend of stagecraft and sermonizing.
Godsend serves as a warning that just because you can clone another film doesn't mean you should.
The only thing missing is a laugh track.
This cacophonous, baroque and nearly incoherent tale is about film technology, not mythology.
Dickerson's seductive realization and DMX's chillingly detached performance give this subpar variation on culturally apocalyptic themes an amoral plausibility.

Overall generalities about the main characters, a tendency to reveal them through monologue rather than behavior, and a lack of curiosity about the Mormon youth's core beliefs keep Latter Days from feeling genuinely personal or particularly substantive.
An ironic, nostalgic and often poetic reminiscence about the period circa 1989.
The Coens still have enough tricks up their sleeves for a worthwhile outing.
In Altman, The Company and the dancers of the Joffrey have luckily stumbled onto a kindred and no-less-nimble spirit, for whom dance is just another type of storytelling.
The real breakthrough comes from Kaufman, whose absurdist sensibility has finally coalesced into narrative maturity.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

The film's insipid, lazy humor sticks about as well as a wet, slippery noodle being tossed around for two hours.
Whereas Capote was cold and atmospheric and almost surgical in its storytelling, Infamous is told in a more accessible and emotionally gratifying manner.
A top-notch grindhouse flick perfect for the Halloween season. It's also the best this series has seen in twenty years.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A pulpy, operatic, rousingly good crime thriller.
A small gem of a motion picture that leaves a powerful aftereffect.
A winsome piece of fluff that is easy on the eyes, the ears, and the heart
A film of schizophrenic tonal shifts and sadly missed opportunities.
The wheels of the contrived screenplay turn so loudly you can almost hear them creaking.
The disastrously hollow All the King's Men forgoes entertainment in favor of trying to cause death by way of crushing boredom.
If ever a studio film was released in theaters with the power of making audience members puke all over themselves, this is it.
Gorgeously choreographed aerial photography and seamless visual effects give life, scope, exhilaration and danger to the action set-pieces.
Could have used more science and less sleep.
Words cannot possibly do justice to what a total monstrosity this film is.
Means well, but it's as bland as a stale slice of dry white bread.
More honest and substantive than the average mainstream sports flick. Not necessarily more original, but certainly more worth the viewer's while.
Boring, empty, anticlimactic, uninspired and bankrupt of humanity.
Says little about growing up and relationships that hasn't been coveredand betterin virtually hundreds of other pictures on the same subjects.
None of them can act worth a lick, but all of them would be perfect for an Abercrombie & Fitch catalogue.
The performances are first-rate across the board. Hollywoodland endures as a fulfilling and memorable cinematic experience.
Has a relaxed and understated tone that blindsides the viewer at key moments with its dramatic potency.
Simply goes through the paces more often than it excels at its initial ambitions.
A feast for the eyes, Monster House should become a mainstay of the Halloween season.
So preachy in its anti-drug stance that it might as well have had the financial support of D.A.R.E. during its production.
Its sheer shameless juvenilia ranges from horribly unfunny to outrageously zany.
Should go where the sun don't shine, all right, and that's at the bottom of DVD bargain bins.
A winning and suitably uplifting way to spend a couple hours.
Crowd-pleasing, undemanding fun.
Two hours of cinema that is uncomfortable and sobering to withstand, but impossible to take your eyes off of.
Silent Hill is not for lacking memorably nightmarish imagery, but the picture tries one's patience far more often than it unnerves it.
Goes wrong on so many levels that it's hard to believe name talent and a major studio signed on in the first place.
A toxic love letter to hate.
As frightening and unsettling as any gore-drenched horror movie of the last year.
Pleasant enough for the little ones, but unrewarding for the rest of the prospective audience.
The past three films left the viewer entertained and exhausted from laughter by the end. Scary Movie 4 simply leaves you feeling empty and depressed.
An ingenious modern take on the slasher genre. Big fun that mixes well its comic aspirations with gritty, down-and-dirty suspense.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Manages to never be boring even when it is a complete waste of talent, film stock and the audience's time and money.
Chooses contrivances over naturalism and sickeningly saccharine sermonizing over lighthearted moralizing.
Falls smack-dab in the middle of terminal disposability.
Takes a stylish, back-to-basics approach to the material and doesn't hesitate to throw everything in but the kitchen sink.
A cause for temporary erectile dysfunction.
Forgettable, completely harmless, sporadically amusing, and not at all ready to go up against the real masters at Pixar and Disney.
Akin to David Lynch on an off day.
A complete cinematic joke.
The climax doesn't just spell out every surprise plot turn, but italicizes and underlines them too, and then puts to use a yellow highlighter for solid measure.
The thing that She's the Man deserves to be remembered for the most? Concrete proof that Amanda Bynes, no doubt about it, has what it takes to be a movie star.
Audiences searching for nothing more than popcorn entertainment will get their money's worth.
When the stars aren't charming the viewer, the film is busy shooting itself in the foot.
A big-screen adaptation that should have stayed on the printed page, where its charms are no doubt better served. Hoot isn't a bad film but it is a shrug-worthy one.
A rousing, slam-bang, no-frills action extravaganza.
A limp, uninspired dramedy that can never figure out what it wants to be about.
Its coarse opening sections are ill-matched for the warmly compassionate tale it ultimately matures into.
Flaws and all, Strangers with Candy has one invaluable thing going for it: the utterly fearless and downright brilliant comic performance of Amy Sedaris.
A grand-scale train wreck.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The year's shrewdest comedy thus far.
A majestic and exhilarating blockbuster that captures for the first time in the series the sheer awe-inspiring feeling of what it might be like to fly.
Plays to the lowest-common-denominator for so long that it can never quite redeem itself when the tone suddenly dims and turns into a tearjerker.
A juvenile jerk-off session of battling machismos.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Garfield in these shoddy movies is nothing but an impostor of the once-beloved real thing.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Supposed to be sweeping and romantic, but instead takes on an uncomfortable and creepy undercurrent.
Tightly paced, fast as a whip and addictively entertaining.
Gets big laughs in its clever, rapid-fire delivery and finds beauty and wisdom within its narrative simplicity.
Absorbing, charming, and even touching.
Goes to show that magic can't always strike twicenot even when virtually the same script is used.
Has its heart in the right place but overall the film stands as a one-track doomsday warning with too little substance to achieve its intended effect.
For all of its comedic nosedives, the film is frank and uncompromising as a study of the final weeks of a relationship.
A fast and furious smorgasbord of sound and fury, adding up to little in the long run, but, yes, fun while it lasts.
Faithfully derivative of the low-grade, entertainingly bad slasher items of two decades ago.
An old-school thriller just as heavy on intellect and thought-provoking ideas as it is on chase sequences and shootouts.
2006 has not been a kind year to the animated genre and the empty, irresponsible Over the Hedge is so far the worst of the lot.
A romantic comedy neither romantic nor particularly funny.
Boggles the mind with how many things it gets wrong.
There are some big laughs to be had, but just as many fumbles. Deuce would have been better off staying stateside and talking to his late wife's artificial leg.
A terminally lame teen comedy with a grade-school mentality.
A mesmerizing triumph of both pitch-perfect minimalism and devastating existentialism, painting a bleak, uncompromising portrait of desolation personified.
Frightening and enthralling, and quite often, but the film's consummate thematic missteps cripple the project beyond repair.
Its often low-key study of human interactions and bonding is quietly truthful and erudite.
Akin to a baseball game turned into a feature film, Mr. 3000 isn't so much bad as it is terminally empty.
A crass, hateful product of loathsome characters and an even uglier story. It's shocking that such a cesspool of nothingness has found its way into theaters at all.
Strictly of the take-it-or-leave-it variety, not romantic or involving or memorable enough to warrant more than an ultra-brief passing glance.
A one-of-a-kind original. Those courageous enough to give it a try will find their efforts rewarded, at times in the most unexpected of ways.
An utterly mesmerizing, boundlessly imaginative achievement, perhaps -- and I do not use such terms lightly -- the most visually astounding motion picture ever made.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A solid, affectionately told drama, at times wavering the line of excellent, that only disappoints when it doesn't add up to the fully-realized catharsis it is aiming for.
Creatively bankrupt trash made by a committee of hacks who don't know the first thing about generating suspense, frights, or cohesive storytelling.
Charmless and confoundingly amateurish, a trifle of bankrupt non-ideas that will be forgotten about long before the November election even gets here.
A taut, crowd-pleasing thriller in which the improbable, if canny, premise is overlooked in exchange for what is an exceedingly fun ride.
At no time does it work, providing cheap thrills, bad writing, and a particularly nasty side that tries to pass itself off as popcorn entertainment.
The Cookout holds a smug, mean-spirited undercurrent, made all the more rotten by an attempted sincerity as false as a set of dentures.
What might work powerfully on the page comes off on the screen as not terribly interesting.
For the not-easily-offended, this is certainly one of the most deliriously ballsy comedies to hit screens in years.
Doesn't even fall into the 'so bad it's entertaining' category. As unscary, threadbare, and downright dull as these kinds of movies come.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While the plotting doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel, it does skew conventions enough to leave the viewer edgy and wondering what will unfold with each progressive scene.
A highly charged, poignant study of the imperfections within human nature and the frailty of otherwise powerful love relationships.
A faux-sentimental comedy that not only isn't funny, but half the time appears to have forgotten to insert the joke.
A sincereand sincerely problematicfilm that may have been shot twice, but deserved a third try to get things right.
Not the customary disposable cinematic fare released on the always-slow Labor Day weekend, but an intriguing, original film of ideas and human feeling.
In the terms of the money-hungry Hollywood mindset, The Last Shot is an amusing, likable sleeper hit, but not an out-of-the-stratosphere blockbuster.
Oddly lacking a heart. In its place is misguided material decidedly unsavory for most of its target audience, and a string of inappropriate ethnic and racial stereotypes.
May be the most intellectually demanding motion picture of the year. Some will find their mind satiated. Others will leave angry. In one way or another, all will be baffled.
It's never scaryand doesn't try to bebut it sure does have a pitch-black, smile-inducing charm.
One sequel where a pressing need to find out what happened to the protagonist is absent, replaced by an attempt to cash in on the financial success of the first picture.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An endlessly magical experience. One couldn't ask for a movie more pure and genuine. In a single word, The Polar Express is a masterpiece.
A long slog through a pretty sea of thankless twaddle.
Boundlessly enjoyable, extravagant to look at, and a frequent adrenaline rush.
The frequent steps from reality into fantasy are gorgeous to behold and humanely relevant rather than cloying and cute.
Saw simply doesn't cut it.
Stylishly grim and nervously intriguing for most of its running length, but concludes with an underwhelming, derivative whimper.
A disappointingly unoriginal and one-note biography of a man and his life that were anything but.
Evoking Stanley Kubrick in its slowly spellbinding pacing and meticulous, always unpredictable technical attributes, Birth is a visually sumptuous work.
A gratifying early surprise of the autumn movie season, an intelligent and wise film that finds vast entertainment value in one man's own existential crises.
Has its respective merits, but this is one festive occasion that desperately needed another rewrite.
A motion picture that tries to fool viewers into thinking it is about more than it really is, Undertow is the perfect cinematic example of a wolf in sheep's clothing.
Genuinely surprises because one is never quite sure where it is headed next, all the while involving the viewer in freakish, unforgettably nightmarish imagery.
There are some hearty laughs to be had, but they don't come frequently enough.
A largely appealing drama, the kind of sports movie that anyone, even non-fans of football (like myself), can get wrapped up in and care about.
So pure at heart that, even with its over-the-top moments and cliches, one is willing to forgive the flaws and admire all that it achieves.
A spiffy-looking ride on a road to nowhere.
It's like going on an invaluable 8,000 mile vacation for the affordable price of a movie ticket--well worth the ten dollars.
A film that loves and respects the country's firefighters, but makes the mistake of not getting to know them in a meaningful or substantial way.
The dynamic pacing, plentiful dancing numbers, and charismatic actors ensure that even [more demanding viewers] will find themselves pleasantly diverted.
A hit-and-miss affair, commendable for its intricate, unpredictable storytelling but frustrating that it all adds up to a poof of smoke and a wink at the viewer.
Intelligently wicked and bloodily appealing in an agile sort of way.
The 2001 cut is my preference, but the 2004 changes have their select attributes. Both editions, indeed, are modern masterworks.
Has been rendered impotent by the insane demands of a studio obsessed with the PG-13 rating. An attractive but empty horror-lite version.
Yes, there are some bigeven giantlaugh-inducing moments, but this is one ribald cinematic effort that could have used another extensive rewrite.
For viewers who just want to laugh for 90 minutes without having to think too much, the no-holds-barred Dodgeball will happily do the trick.
Starts off with a quirkily original premise before completely derailing in shallow subplots that go nowhere and a loathsome conclusion that wants, but fails, to be uplifting.
A thankless visual spectacle, marvelous to look at but woefully empty where its heart should be.
A welcome new spin, a brash style, and more big laughs than expected on an old tale that still holds quite a bit of relevance.
Bankrupt of imagination and will be nearly forgotten the instant the viewer exits the theater, but it's harmless - the sole reason why it is difficult to out-and-out hate it.
A quirky, one-of-a-kind comedic gem. Even when you aren't laughing out loud, you won't be able to stop from smiling.
Soul Plane will likely inspire viewers to immediately rewatch Airplane! to wash out the bad taste this new movie pollutes into their mouths.
Content to parade out an endless, ever-wearying line of cliches, ludicrous plotting and dialogue, and paper-thin stock characters whom the viewer forms no relationship with.
Assured, visually triumphant filmmaking that isn't simply a joy to look at, but also bewitches with its tightly conceived plotting.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A film that not only works as a documentary but as an endlessly intriguing and grin-inducing narrative.
The film is a head-on collision of spare parts from different genres, none of which work separately or as a collective whole.
Blazes across the screen with mature, rapid-fire wit; genuine warmth; and rainbow-colored visual beauty.
How is Breakin' All the Rules different from all the countless other romantic comedies specializing in misunderstandings and mistaken identities? It isn't.
Reminiscent of a cheesy Harlequin romance that just so happens to have lots of big battles and expensive effects.
Too trite and uninteresting to service the wonderfully affecting performance from Lili Taylor.
One of the most thought-provoking and important films of the last few years.
Disposable eye candy that entertains while it plays itself out but isn't worth much once it's over.
Wants to be dark and scathing, but lacks the courage of its convictions.
Opts to waste its potential in favor of a barrage of cheap jump scares and clumsy plotting.
The comedy is drab and predictable. The satirical flourishes are so soft that they are hardly worth mentioning. The thrills are diffused by tonal shifts working against them.
A quality, albeit frothy, teen flick destined to charm its target audience, and maybe even some grown-ups, as well.
This is one screenplay that would have excelled had all the dialogue been excised or retooled.
A visually dazzling spectacle and a technically creative triumph. Spider-Man 2 is a significant and grandly entertaining cinematic work.
Real-life love stories rarely work out quite so faultlessly, but for two hours it's nice to believe that they could.
May have no objectionable material parents will find offensive for children, but just about every viewer will be offended by the patronizing hooey stuffed down their throat.
A frightening journey into the heart of human darkness and morality. Sure to endure as a watermark of the coming-of-age genre for years to come.
[Director] Joshua Marston's meticulous eye for cold, hard facts on his subject matter raises Maria Full of Grace above the level of mere docudrama.
Offers the ultimate conundrum. A complex motion picture that demands a second viewing, yet doesn't offer enough that's scary or emotionally resounding to be worth the first.
If there is a reason to see it, it's the effortlessly enchanting Murphy, but that isn't quite reason enough. This is one Book that should have remained closed.
Collateral is an arrestingly written and acted dramatic thriller that refuses to cut easy corners for the majority of its running time. An enthralling experience.
Sloppy, boring, dumbed-down and heinous. By the end, you may find yourself experiencing a fantasy of finding all the copies of the picture and burning the negatives.
Attempts to cram too much information into a 95-minute feature. Fortunately, there is enough that is exquisitely good to make up for many of its narrative downfalls.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A jittery, unapologetic experience worth a look for those who prefer psychological horror over broad slasher cliches.
A cold, calculating virtual redux of The Bourne Identity that leaves a bitter aftertaste in its wake. Audiences have seen this all before, many times over.
Overtly bad (and unintentionally funny) enough to become a camp classic.
Absolutely riveting entertainment, a chilling portrait of human paranoia also posing as an engrossing and visually vibrant political thriller. This is one arresting film.
The Door in the Floor is unfocused beyond repair.
Some of the most convincing and lifelike visual effects in movie history. This is a wide-scope sci-fi thriller done right.
Does justice to its well-known source material while putting a pleasant spin on it. It's better than one may be lead to expect, which is perhaps the best compliment of all.
Garden State is a beaming, unforgettable little masterpiece, creatively alive and emotionally intimate at the same time.
Its unforced mixture of the crass with the sweet may not be the likeliest of combinations, but it is a decidedly beguiling one, all the same.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A marginal entertainment with some greatly funny scenes definitely worth seeing, but is the rest of the movie worth wading through to get to them? Probably not.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Strives to be more than just a predictable, by-the-numbers kidnapping drama, but that, ultimately, is all that it ends up being.
One of the season's must-see efforts. All of the studio-produced, mass-marketed romances out there, take note: this is precisely what a love story should be.
This is some of [Kline and Judd's] most astonishing respective work in memory. De-Lovely is unremittingly romantic.
An important documentary and a spellbinding entertainment. Laugh-aloud funny, razor sharp, informative, humane, enraging, and powerful, oftentimes all of the above at once.
These daffy sea creatures pale enormously next to the infinitely superior joys of The Incredibles and The Polar Express.
A vile, morally repugnant lump of coal. One of the worst, most disingenuous Christmas movies in memory.
As a dramatization of non-fiction events, a film that, more than anything, sets out to evoke distinct emotions within the viewer, Hotel Rwanda is certainly effective.
Who could have guessed that a so-called slasher movie could be as psychologically haunting as this one manages to be? A new classic of the horror genre has been born.
Entertaining in its joy and energy, and perceptive in depicting a specific, one-of-a-kind era.
A worn-out Goodwill version of Rocky that either deserved a less-banal filmmaking approach or didn't need to be made at all.
A warm-hearted, enjoyable diversion. A possible contender for one of the sleeper hits of the summer.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Mysterious Skin, for all of its depictions of atrocities and human sadness, is a rarified thing of vulnerable beauty.
One of the most lackluster of the modern, big-budget CG-animated releases.
Sexist, homophobic, pointless and overloaded with brain-crushing bigotry...has an evil and putrid secret agenda that couldn't have less to do with football if it tried.
A slam-bang summer blockbuster. Completes, deepens, and enriches the series beyond the pop-cultural phenomenon it has long-since made for itself.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There is no necessary tension, no memorable characters, and no sense of fun. Instead, Renny Harlin just lines up his cast and knocks off their boring asses one at a time.
The intentionally over-the-top, at times cheerfully wicked, streak is greatly harmed by a cop-out conclusion that pushes the tone toward falsely uplifting mawkishness.
Will Ferrell is always entertaining, even in lesser roles like this one. Painless to sit through once, but offers nothing of value to be worth ever seeing again.
Thrilling, bone-crunching, gloriously choreographed fight scenes, but they're in between the more enduring core of the film, which is a character-centric family drama.
A dreary, uninformative, emotionless disaster. At least Alexander had the comical benefit of Angelina Jolie hamming it up with reptiles.
An absolutely riveting, highly charged drama, Crash is an important motion picture that demands viewing in high schools across the country.
Scary, scream-and-squirm-inducing, and suspenseful, it's the first unequivocally good--and often downright great--popcorn entertainment of the still-early summer movie season.
Hitching a ride, even one in space, has never been less exciting and adventurous.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Plain, old, rancid trash, as careless as it is despicably wasteful. If Xander Cage had to die, the XXX series should have keeled over with him.
Unobtrusive and virtually painless as an occasionally witty laugher, but lacks the courage of its convictions to follow through with its less commercial ambitions.
A gem of a love storyhonest, funny in an unforced way, sometimes painful and, ultimately, winsomely romantic. One of the nicer surprises of 2005, thus far.
Looks good, sounds good, and is a motion picture that the actors make worth seeing.
Palindromes is Todd Solondz's first significant cinematic failure, a pitch-black fable twice as shallow and trite as it is intriguing.
Has a rushed, thrown-together feel to it made all the more glaring by cheesy 3-D that is ugly and doesn't work in any way, shape or form.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Why bother ratcheting up suspense with unseen forces and horrors of the psyche when you can just show actors in makeup instructed to look spooooooky?
So bewitching as a romantic, charged & aesthetically slick star vehicle that it's easy to overlook its shakier aspects. Has adult summer blockbuster written all over it.
Batman Begins is involving and skillful, more so as a drama than as an action film.
A black hole of a movie without anything original to do or interesting to say. That it isn't outright terrible only makes its utter pointlessness all the more glaring.
Will please non-discriminating action hounds while leaving everyone else in search of a little meat unfulfilled. It's as fun as it is instantly forgettable.
Lacks the requisite passion and urgency to make the experience anything more than a periodically pleasant waste of time.
A brightly entertaining teenage comedy as frothy and predictable as cotton candy, but also just as sweet.
The most in-depth study of a single joke that has likely ever been attempted on film.
The first act holds such promise, but by the end, Bay deflates all rooting interest and throws logic out the window in favor of shootouts and been-there-done-that car chases.
Delights in its unashamed vulgarity and spiritedly laugh-inducing wickedness.
The Devil's Rejects is meanspirited, graphic, and bubbling over in ultra-realistic viscera, but it isn't without sociological merit.
Happy Endings, like its characters, is an ambitious, if flawed, work, but there is also a touching soulful quality that cannot be denied and cannot be faked.
Good enough to stand on its own, but the film doesn't even begin to hold a candle next to 1971's version.
Headed straight for divorce court.
Dark Water proves that the horrors of the human condition are just as frightening, if not more so, than all things that go drip in the night.
A painful, sluggish black hole of simultaneous bad ideas and no ideas at all.
The sparks of brilliance littered throughout Miranda July's debut feature are just thatsparks.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A loving portrait of a gorgeous, awkward creature that, in some ways, is remarkably similar to human beings, and in other ways couldn't be further from us.
The worst family feature so far this year...Rebound stinks like a rancid pair of sweaty old gym sneakers.
Overlooking a disappointing conclusion, War of the Worlds is a marvelous entertainment of imagination, edge-of-your-seat suspense, and surprising thoughtfulness.
Feels unfinished, like a rough cut still awaiting a much-needed polish. Fleetingly amusing? Yes. Full-out magical? Not so much.
Gritty, dark and unapologetically violent, Land of the Dead is a solid, serious zombie movie.
Zippy, brightly-colored fun. The film flies right by at such a stylish clip that the viewer hardly has time to realize how very slight the whole thing is.
Amidst the troubled waters are some bright spots that lift the picture above being a painful experience; as is, it is merely disposable.
This isn't the worst movie of the yearit isn't even the worst comedy of the yearbut it may be one of the blandest.
May hit some rough patches as it wraps itself up, but at its core is a film that is gentle and wise.
Travels down been-there-done-that territory, afraid to take chances and unaware of its own tedious mediocrity.
Breathtaking to look at, but its core is without a pulse.
Elektra would have been far better off staying dead.
Damn that Satchel Paige bobblehead doll and double-damn director Brian Levant for thinking it was a good idea.
An utterly abysmal wannabe-horror film. Never even remotely frighteningthe trailer is worlds above this lame finished product in terms of a visceral response.
Having seen it all before, and in a superior, more charming fashion, the most likely response from viewers will be lackadaisical indifference.
An understated drama simmering just underneath the surface with explosive emotions and occasionally breathless intensity.
So dimly lit and its plot so threadbare that the viewing experience is not much more gratifying than sitting in a pitch-black room for 95 minutes.
The epilogue is poignant and truthful in a way that the rest of the film, with its inept storytelling and strictly unfunny humor, does not earn or deserve.
A frantic, pointless sequel, funny in clumps, but mostly contrived and empty.
Better in sections than as a whole, and those sections don't arrive at a steady enough pace to undo its failings.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A biopic that is all shiny surface and no substance, washing over hard details in favor of a lot of stage performances that come off surprisingly flat.
The picture is a beautifully foreboding storybook sprung to life, mixing guffaw-inducing comedy, frightful fantasy, and resonating drama without missing a beat.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: So full of shameless vanity that each ticket stub should come with a mirror, a make-up case, and a high-priced plastic surgeon.
Wishes to be full of good will, but it is hampered by an unnecessarily extreme mean streak that the picture refuses to be accountable for.
Absolutely riveting entertainment. Takes a formulaic blueprint, tramples it to the floor, and comes up with something altogether more penetrating, touching, and real.
Takes the 'everything-but-the-kitchen-sink' approach. Leaves no sports cliche unturned and no chance for inspirational feel-good moments unvisited.
This is one dreary, listless film. The sooner it is forgotten and the once-promising director restakes his claim in being someone to watch, the better off we all will be.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most entertaining motion pictures of the year, The Phantom of the Opera is a cinematic gift for the ages that finds profundity in its thematic innocence.
Harmless but shallow, cinematic junk food that goes down with ease but has no nutritional value and will be forgotten about almost immediately after devouring it.
A solid, albeit flawed, effort. Stellar work by Leonardo DiCaprio, but Cate Blanchett's masterful, Oscar-worthy performance steals the film.
The sumptuous performances and tantalizing dialogue make even the most detestable of human behavior uncontrollably fascinating.
An enormous cinematic mess. Alexander is not so much mind-numbingly boring as it is intriguingly nonsensical.
Graphically violent and merciless...refreshingly unpretentious in its goal to entertain and put a jolt in any non-squeamish viewer sick to death of cookie-cutter genre movies.
The most consistently funny motion picture of the year so far, and also its sweetest. Once over, audiences won't so much walk out of the theater as they will float out.
A slice-of-life so purely amiable and astute in its portrayal of the cutthroat corporate world that it is easy to overlook a great many flaws in its design.
An absorbing mystery-thriller for its first hour ... until it races off the tracks toward a dumb, albeit predictable, twist ending.
Although not a chore to sit through, the whole thing seems rather clunkily thought out and offers precious little worth remembering once the end credits have rolled.
As the title suggests, Melinda and Melinda features two renditions of the same person. Woody Allen would have been smart to scrap them both and start from scratch.
When so few comedies these days are actually funny, Guess Who is an entertaining and diverting way to spend 105 minutes for audiences starved for laughs.
Gracie Hart may still be armed, but her sheer fabulousness has come to a rather abrupt and unfortunate end.
Ice Princess sticks closely to the mold of other sports flicks, but there is a tenderness and refreshing lack of compromise assembled from its spare parts.
Moves fast and isn't without its freakish images-but it becomes obvious the film was rushed into production without much thought or faithfulness into the first picture's lore.
A valiantly flawed effort boosted by noteworthy star turns that make the two-hour running time a rewarding filmgoing experience.
Doesn't contain a whole lot to grasp onto and take away with you, but it's pleasurable and bright and inoffensive while it lasts.
Hostage is a hit-and-miss action-thriller. When it is good, it crackles and pops with literally breathless, grip-your-armrest-style intensity.
Warm, funny, weighty, wholly original, and even occasionally quite tense, Millions will open up the minds of both adults and children without talking down to them.
A lame-as-lame-can-be bust.
The ambitions of the film are diffused by a nagging sensation that we've seen it all before, and done with a surer hand.
Hip, zippy, and oh-so-cool.
A consistently unoriginal comedy that plays like an abandoned 97-minute sitcom pilot without the laugh track or hardly any laughs.
As a PG-13, Cursed is a lesser, more cowardly effort, but one that still has enough giddy buoyancy and slick thrills to lift above its last-minute studio tinkering.
There is no reason to make a trip to the theater for what amounts to a loud and frenzied day at Chuck E. Cheese's.
The sum of its parts could have added up to much more than it does. Then again, let's be thankful for small victories. It could have been Are We There Yet?
Too many false endings and time issues aside, Hitch is difficult to discount when it handles the rom-com formula better than most of its insufferably dumbed-down ilk.
Good-looking, but decidedly hollow. Misses the opportunity to explore its evocative central conceits by attempting to do too many other things at once, and failing.
A chill-free, suspense-deficient thriller that is not only an enormous waste of time and film stock, but also insanely empty and heavy-handed.
Elicits a handful of smiles but not many laughs as it approaches a finale that comes as a foregone conclusion.
This is jaw-dropping, awe-inspiring, 'I-can't- believe-someone- made-this-crap' badness we're dealing with.
For legitimate frights that don't rely on gore, Grudge 2 fits the bill. Just don't go in expecting to make sense out of the convoluted story, because there isn't any.
Freddy Krueger is now a full-blown cartoonish caricature of his initially dread-induced former self.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child (1989)

movie_review_blurb: The music is heavenly in its use and perfect for the tone, rustling up an emotional response far greater than anything brought about from the characters themselves.
Drillbit Taylor goes down with ease when it isn't trying too hard. This may not be a great teen comedy, but it is a warm and smart one.

Soulless, impersonal and shamelessly derivative, this dime-a-dozen sci-fi garbage is such a depressing step down for Neil Marshall that one can hardly believe it was made by the same guy responsible for the rightfully acclaimed The Descent.
What could be translated into a wonderful and even educational thirty-minute short is stretched and padded to the brink when forced to fill out a feature-length running time.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Is Never Back Down so bad it's good, or just plain bad? Really, it's a little bit of both.
A small-scale family drama that walks the walk, but doesn't seem to know where it's going half the time.
Difficult to like and yet impossible to deny, Funny Games is a coldly efficient, spectacularly acted and unremittingly bleak thriller.
Yet another accomplished, stylistically courageous work from a filmmaker whose willingness to take chances and pull them off is his finest attribute.
10,000 B.C. is a load of crap dressed up with pretty background vistas. The film is terminally lifeless, something that a so-called 'event' picture should never be.

Worth a recommendation for adult audiences in search of something that won't insult their intelligence. Granted, The Bank Job won't enhance anyone's IQ, either, but sometimes a pulpy slice of crime thriller theatrics is all you need.
Ultimately becomes little more than a series of derivative, predictable genre conventions without the necessary skill to back them up.
In it's painfully accurate portrayal of characters struggling to make their way in a world that oftentimes seems cruelly unfair and confusing, Snow Angels rings resoundingly true.
This shrill, chaotic, mass-market drivel is the kind of absent-minded family film that gives thoughtful, worthwhile family films a bad name.
With some fine-tuning, Penelope might have been transformed into a winning little fable about accepting and loving oneself. As is, it only serves to remind of what could have been.

Fascinating in its depiction of a troubled relationship between sisters that is anything but black and white. This emotionally ripe angle to a tragic story that could have been told any number of ways is where the film gets its potency.
Stay home and watch any of Ferrell's past films, all of which are more worthwhile than this monotonously unfunny tripe.
Less would have definitely been more in this case; if viewers squint their eyes hard enough, they might just be able to locate a kitchen sink lurking somewhere in the background.
An inspired low-budget horror item with a rough and tumble guerilla filmmaking flair. What it lacks is a steady focal point to rattle the viewer's interest and emotions for an hour and a half.
A non-flashy but uncommonly savvy film about teenage life that one can only hope finds its rightful audience.
Cute but a little empty, Be Kind Remind boasts an original premise without the clarity of writing and character dimension to back it up.
Never scary but frequently cartoonish in its sour humor, Diary of the Dead can't even figure out if it wants to be taken seriously or as a poor, unfunny spoof.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is terminally pleasant. Granted, pleasant isn't a bad thing, but the film calls for a looser, more wild side that never quite comes.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Acted with aplomb and occasionally compelling, Stop-Loss nevertheless fails to impress.
A pulse-poundingly high-spirited and extremely well-directed drama. If 21 is only one thing, it's intoxicating.
About five good laughs stretched over a 70-minute running time (not counting the ludicrously padded 15-minute end credits).
An entertaining and inventive ride tailor-made for the summer movie season.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What once felt both magical and foreboding now seems rather dreary and perfunctory.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: So moronic it almost makes the recent mediocre Made of Honor seem sophisticated by comparison.
A phantasmagoric, candy-colored treat for the senses.
A slight but infectious British comedy, Son of Rambow charms in spite of a slim plot and sketchy character development. The first ninety minutes may not be, but the last five are just about perfect.
Not good, not bad, just there, the film faithfully crosses off one timeworn cliché after the next.
Not quite memorable enough to live up to the top superhero films but proficient enough to be satisfying, Iron Man suggests with a clever ending that better things are yet to come.
Can a movie title be so unthinkably bad that it single-handedly ruins the viewing experience? As it turns out, yes.
Far from a complete failure, but in trying so hard to up the ante the filmmakers have made a lesser, more rambling finished product. Simply isn't as satisfying this time around.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are a handful of solid laughs, but there are more than a few duds in the mix. One suspects that had Tina Fey penned the film herself, it wouldn't have been half as conventional and plodding.
Paints a compelling and thought-provoking picture of not only school violence, but violence in general, and the trickle-down effect that a single moment in time can have on one's whole future.
Was the movie entertaining? Yes. Did it quite consistently earn some big laughs and small chuckles? Yes. Was the audience's intelligence insulted? Thankfully, no.
A drab exercise in poor storytelling, empty-headed characters, low-grade aesthetics, and forgettable action sequences. This isn't 'so-bad-it's-good' we're talking about; it's 'so-bad-it's-bad.'
Could have used more innovation and less strained obviousness as it worked its way toward an underwhelming conclusion.
A stalk-and-slash horror movie with precious few slashes, the PG-13-rated Prom Night is a tame, by-the-numbers affair without surprises or a point of any kind.
It's a story that has been played out more times than can be counted and is none too fresh on this go-round. Street Kings simply brings nothing new to the 'bad cop' subgenre.

A smart film about smart people, as the title promises, but they are also humanely flawed. Like all of us, they don't hold the key to life's questions and dilemmas, and all the intelligence in the world isn't going to change that.

Because the film works so splendidly for so long, the sole misstep that The Ruins takes is a major one, ending on a note of disappointment. What comes before this is superbly crafted and as tight as a vise grip, worth seeing for that alone.
Despite its heart being in the right place, Nim's Island is a strikingly far-fetched and cloying picture that tries way too hard to be alternately juvenile and bittersweet.
Not bad but also so frivolous that there's nothing to grab onto and take away from it all. Leatherheads is a good-looking but misguided waste of time and effort.
Amiable. Bland. Cute. Formulaic. Inconsequential. Run Fatboy Run goes down with ease, but it's awfully slight.
With no one to root for, no adequate story development, and action scenes that are the epitome of underwhelming, Jumper is a lost cause.
Its simplistic and occasionally juvenile plot is at odds with its more mature subject matter. The Spiderwick Chronicles is flashy and diverting, but also ultimately insubstantial.
It's all been done before, and better. Furthermore, the nearly two full hours it takes to reach its foregone conclusion begins to pry on one's nerves.
At the risk of going against the obvious 'it's-cool-to-hate-Hilton' popular majority, it should be stated up front that The Hottie & the Nottie isn't half-bad.
National Treasure: Book of Secrets has the same director as National Treasure, the same writers, and nearly all of the same lead actors. This is no surprise, since it is basically the same movie.
I Am Legend is a frightening film. What gets under your skin, though, has nothing to do with the conventional horror elements.
The decidedly small-scale finished product doesn't quite measure up to the epic scope of its story. Fortunately, the film's heart remains very much intact.
Children may laugh at the broad humor, but what's lurking underneath the comedy is dark and disheartening.
About as appetizing as a candy cane laced with arsenic.
An auspicious and grandiose entertainment. Thoroughly immersive and genuinely wondrous.
Profundity is never achieved because the would-be encompassing love story at its center isn't given enough time to build and breathe.
Light on plot but plentiful in moments of keen human observation, Juno is authentic and, oh, so winning.
So screechingly obvious by the 15-minute mark that all the viewer is left to do for the remainder of the running time is wait around for the slow-witted machinations of the script to catch up.
A wise, low-key drama where the characters' humane, accurately written interactions take precedence over all else.
Would be right at home as a movie made for television. As a feature film, it is a forgettable, humdrum sapfest.
Simply put, to spend time with these people is unpleasant and without a payoff (or an emotional release) to reward the audience's efforts.
Abysmal in the extreme, Hitman is 100 minutes of soul-crushing nothingness.
Takes a terrifying plot and then somehow manages to miss the mark and the scares.
Slight, uneven and not very memorable. Just as the viewer's heart is intended to soar, mine was left lukewarm and wishing that it cared more.
Enchanted proves that a motion picture can be light and frothy and yet still be intelligent and emotionally rewarding. As unlikely as it may seem, this is one of the year's best and brightest films.
Not without its flaws, Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium is a minor but honorable effort that kids and adults will be able to enjoy together or apart.

There is a place for staunchly political cinema like Redacted, just as there is a place for any genre or personal perspective. In this case, it is the crude treatment of the material that spells its undoing.

Because the picture's technical side is so extraordinary, it is truly saddening to have to write that Beowulf isn't a very good movie. Take away the visuals, and what is left is a talky, subdued, lifeless affair.

In a world of mediocre, formulaic fare that is like everything else that has come before it, Southland Tales stands invigoratingly apart from the crowd. It's ballsy, fascinatingly different and thoroughly commendable.
Doesn't quite have what it takes to be low-key and reserved and still hold more than cursory interest.
