For viewers courageous enough to withstand the bleakest of stories and the most cynical of outcomes, House of Sand and Fog is a challenging motion picture.
If it's family fare you're seeking, see this and skip the dreadful, condescending Cheaper by the Dozen. You can thank me later.
Cold Mountain is a technical triumph, to be sure, but it is just as lacking in pure soul.
Turns its every character into a cliche and its every plot development into an easy preconception.
To say that The Return of the King is this already-classic trilogy's paramount achievement is to understate things.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rotten to the core and misogynistic in the extreme.
Something's Gotta Give is witty, smart, and charismatically electric-three vital elements rare to find in most of today's romantic comedies.
An engaging and affectionate motion picture that may have its fair share of problems, but treats its subject matter with surprising adeptness.
Snappy and charming enough to overcome its predictability and shopworn cliches.
[A]n imaginative, heartbreaking film -- one of 2003's best -- that you won't easily forget.
The Last Samurai is so built on common Hollywood movie cliches and superficial, jingoistic messages that it achieves no identity of its own.
The Missing may not be a standout western for modern day audiences, but it is undoubtedly a step in the right direction.
Syrupy, dumb, and desperately unfunny...Cheaper by the Dozen is the worst family film of the year, a sub-sitcom-level failure as abhorrent as it is half-baked.
The kind of rare perverse treat that John Waters would undoubtedly go crazy for...Billy Bob Thornton is genuinely perfect.
Trying to make sense of it and still stay involved through the duration of its 116 minutes is about as meaningless and unrewarding as...well, Timeline itself.
Becomes too cute for its own good, relying so heavily on symbolism to get its points across that it becomes more ridiculous than lyrical.
A thoroughly fascinating examination of a shameful footnote in journalistic history that many people probably wish to forget.
Gothika is a classy, dread-filled production populated with an above-average cast and plenty of namesake atmospherics...One of the stronger horror entries of the year.
A spirited fantasy that doesn't slow down long enough for the viewer to think about its flaws.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The performances save the day in The Human Stain, bringing humanity to a worthwhile film that could have ultimately been much better.
The film's languid pacing quickly grows tedious, and the movie itself, unfortunately, becomes a bore.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Filled to bursting with joy, creativity, and good cheer, Elf is one early Christmas gift that does not disappoint.

Delia, Greta, and Paula rank as three of the most multilayered and sympathetic female characters of the year. As each of them searches for their place in the world, Miller digs into their very minds to find an unblinking, flawed humanity.
The film's highlight is definitely its screenplay, both for the rhapsodic dialogue that jumps off the page, and for the memorable character creations.
Max has 'first-time director' written all over it, and the arresting, contemplative subject matter demands a more experienced filmmaker to do it justice.
An enjoyable, if unproductive, time at the movies.
Uses a thick undercurrent of atmospheric dread and truly creepy sound effects to keep the tension high.
Far from perfect, but its heart is in the right place...innocent and well-meaning.
Like an amateur entertainer who thinks his material works when, really, there is nothing remotely special about it.
Thoughtful and emotionally rewarding, I Am Sam works more successfully than it has any right to.
If the restless children in the movie theatre are any indication, the movie is just as uninteresting for them as it is tiresome for the adults.
A stark, gritty motion picture that is more interested in the details of the story than character-developing.
Orange County flies right by with the blink of an eye--not because it is necessarily too short, but because you are having so much fun that you don't want it to end.
May not be the cinematic abortion I expected, but it does resemble a C-section--the outcome turns out just fine, but it still leaves a big, old mess in its wake.
An ineffective romance, a monotonous thriller, and a decidedly banal crime picture.
The comedy is threadbare, the drama plays like an afterthought, and there are too many characters to thoroughly develop any one of them.
Miramax's last bid of the year for Oscar glory, but they have struck rock, rather than gold, with this muddled adaptation.
An intriguing failure that ultimately leaves you disappointed, rather than inspired or invigorated.
The most unromantic romance of the year.
The proceedings aren't quite as annoying as expected, but it has been sloppily made, and feels about twice as long as its 91 minutes.
A mostly fun way to spend 77 minutes and, with its lovely candy-colored visuals, it looks good too.
So uninteresting and overflowing with lame jokes that it is sure to bore viewers of every age, shape, and size.
If the tone...tends to lean toward mawkishness in the last half-hour, what is appealing...is its almost stubborn yearning to be like the motion pictures of yesteryear.
A wholeheartedly innovative, heartfelt, entertaining feast for the eyes.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: For the usually great Robert Altman, this is a terribly disappointing directing effort.
The ending has not been clearly thought out by director [Todd] Field, leaving the strength of the picture--the top-notch performances--to appear even more impressive.
After 87 painfully unfunny minutes of Slackers, you'll be begging for the type of mercy that only comes with the start of the end credits.
About as enjoyable, I would imagine, as searching for a quarter in a giant pile of elephant feces...positively dreadful.
Preposterous and exploitative.
Like a stale loaf of bread that you can easily recognize has past its expiration date.
A superb exercise in eliciting suspense out of simple, progressively sticky situations.
A family-friendly fantasy that ends up doing very little with its imaginative premise.
Its downfalls are evened out by a creativity all too rarely seen at the movies.
One of the best times I've had at the movies all year.
A stylishly filmed journey down a road to nothingness.
Features a handful of memorable scenes but...doesn't garner the type of impact it should.
Dumbed-down, lowest-common-denominator filmmaker with...no scares to be had.
In the annals of big-budget, modern-day animated excursions, Ice Age is one of the lesser efforts.
...pitiful, slapdash disaster. A DOA dud from frame one.
Isn't a complete home run, but...is that rare special effects-laden feature that actually uses its brain and has something worthwhile to say.
Tedious and hackneyed, you would have thought that New Line Cinema could have invested a few more benjamins into getting a workable script before filming commenced.
Immature, predictable, and annoying.
As far as war movies go, this is the best studio effort since Terrence Malick's brilliant 1998 picture, The Thin Red Line .
Stands as a rare, satisfying diversion into the world of vampires.
A supernatural mystery that doesn't know whether it wants to be a suspenseful horror movie or a weepy melodrama. It ends up being neither, and fails at both endeavors.
Tends to pile too many "serious issues" on its plate at times, yet remains fairly light, always entertaining, and smartly written.
Plays like a long series of skits whose comedy is a whole lot funnier to the filmmakers and actors than it is to the viewer.
Worse than just uneven; it leaves you not caring in the least about what is, essentially, an important part of history.
John Q may be too problematic to be marked a great movie, but one thing definitely is: Denzel Washington.
No earth-shattering accomplishment, but an unusually smart movie that the whole family can go to without a single person getting bored or talked down to.
A frequently disappointing cut-and-paste job...it fails to find any sort of smooth rhythm or dramatic arc.
How do you take jabs at things that were supposed to be comical in nature to begin with? Not Another Teen Movie never quite figures out the answer to this.
A ravishing stunner that never loses its way once...Director[Cameron Crowe's] most stunning work to date.
A hip, joyfully contemporary retelling of its vintage predecessor, but someone of director Steven Soderbergh's caliber deserves slightly better than this material.
As perplexing and ominous a motion picture as you're ever likely to see.
Preposterous... messy... saccharine.
Isn't as great a film as it aspires to be, but it is an entertaining one, and Drew Barrymore is a standout.
A remarkable technical achievement so far superior to the details of the plot and one-dimensional characters that it's a real shame.
Scene after scene suddenly rings with a resounding falseness [in the second half].
Chris Kattan is an undoubtedly funny actor, far funnier than anything presented in Corky Romano.
Young kids may like it (others stay far away), but it is guaranteed that no audience member, young or old, will be able to relate to it.
An absolutely merciless thriller--exciting, marvelously crafted, strongly acted, and with more than a few moments destined to increase your heartbeat.
[Denzel] Washington and Ethan Hawke are so good that they easily stand out in a cop drama that is...merely adequate.
This could very well be the most romantic movie of the year.
Has little charm and not nearly enough big laughs to sustain its withering plot and quick 85-minute running time.
A melodramatic potboiler that stretches the boundaries of believability far more than any one movie can withhold.
A lovingly crafted, nostalgia-filled walk through memory lane.
About as fresh as rancid Chinese food that has been stuck in the back of the refrigerator for several months.
Akin to a thrift shop novelty that is way past its prime.
A thrilling suspenser that wisely puts the lovely Sobieski front-and-center, where she belongs.
If most thrillers were as original and well-made as this one, we'd all be very lucky.
An affectionate romantic drama made by and for people in love with music.
Does the phrase, 'worst movie of 2001,' mean anything to you?
The best thing to happen to the horror genre since 1999's groundbreaking The Blair Witch Project.
As unflinchingly honest as any so-called 'teen' film to come out in ages...one of the most thought-provoking motion pictures of the year.
While there are intermittent scares and suspense to be had, the seemingly rushed screenplay, overly schmaltzy climax, and too-short running time bogs the final product down.
For entertainment value, things don't get much better...but when it comes to the potential-to-payoff ratio, things don't get much more frustrating.
The promotional tagline for Bones fittingly reads, 'Unleash the Dogg.' The filmmakers sure did, and in more ways than one.
A slight, cute charmer that, as far as pop-singers-turned-actors goes, is infinitely superior to the hideous Glitter and the even more wretched Spice World.
Forces a non-stop barrage of pseudo-deep theories and questions on the viewer that, more often than not, resemble a bunch of psycho-babbly hooey.
A shattering motion picture that packs a wallop...with two of the year's best performances.
It is easy to see why it took Texas Rangers so long to reach multiplexes. More perplexing is how it got there at all.
A thrilling action picture for anyone who enjoys getting their auditory and visual senses assaulted, and their nerves absolutely wrecked.
Has everything one would hope for in a successful thriller.
Perceptive and realistic...There isn't a weak link in all six of its major performers.
Not only unexpectedly enjoyable, but also kind of sweet.
An instantly forgettable and disposable affair.
A surprising waste of time that leaves you feeling cheated, unsatisfied, and mindboggled to what the point of it all was.
A depressing, stereotypical affair that can be thanked by the African American community for portraying their race as lazy, drug-addicted, and whorish.
Runs over two-and-a-half hours, but is so entertaining that it feels much shorter.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The film progressively loses its credibility until there is very little left to support besides [Willim H.] Macy's latest extraordinary turn.
A tender-hearted, feel-good romance about not taking everything in life at face value...[Paltrow] gives an alternately heartbreaking and comical performance.
Heist is not so much a fleshed-out cinematic experience as a shallow exercise in con games.
Knowing that such a wasteful project was done by such talents as Joel and Ethan Coen makes the outcome all the more mindbogglingly weak.
A wildly imaginative, quality family film that both children and adults will be able to enjoy equally.
The One is one vacuous hole of a movie.
A serviceably entertaining, if formulaic, thriller.
Practically screams out, 'Tiresome!'
Gets a lot of mileage out of some very fine performances before making way for mawkishness in the final half-hour.
As fascinatingly complex and brazenly original as any movie released this year...a breakthrough masterpiece.
A confused concoction that lacks magic, poignancy, or urgency. It does, however, achieve boredom on more than a couple occasions.
National Lampoon's Van Wilder may aim to be the next Animal House, but it more closely resembles this year's version of Tomcats.
A provocative study of the human condition...handled in a fully challenging way that never once talks down to the viewer.
Has some valuable insights into the dating world to go with its outlandish comicality...one of the biggest delights of the spring season.
Brings an unmistakable accuracy to its every moment that most films dealing with bereavement fall short of...Easily one of the most rewarding film experiences of the year.
Satisfyingly wraps up the Hannibal Lecter trilogy, creating a whole that is, ultimately, far greater than some of its parts.
Offers marginal enjoyment...but the movie [vanishes] from the viewer's mind once the end credits have rolled.
There simply isn't enough going on in the minds of these simpleton characters, let alone in the lugubrious plotting they're stuck in, to care about any of it.
An exquisitely formed, flawlessly executed masterwork...As sheerly imaginative and groundbreakingly wondrous as any animated motion picture you are sure to have seen.
As uneven as the first act is, the third act is just as remarkable...the picture slyly sneaks up on you.
Taut, well made...and memorably performed. It also happens to be thoroughly unpleasant.
Horrendously amateurish filmmaking that is plainly dull and visually ugly when it isn't incomprehensible.
A cut-and-paste example of how not to make a historical drama.
Worth seeing for [Goldie] Hawn alone, and this is, by far, the juiciest role she has been blessed with in ages.
Offers 102 minutes of breezy, occasionally very funny entertainment.
Go see Stealing Harvard, and the only things sure to be stolen are your wallet and a worthwhile time.
A technically well-made suspenser...but its abrupt drop in IQ points as it races to the finish line proves simply too discouraging to let slide.
The performances deserve mentioning [because]...there is little else that proves worthwhile.
A nightmarish portrait of the American Dream gone awry...digs deeply and touchingly into the psyche of a deranged human being who has nowhere to turn in life.
A mess when it comes to the characters and writing...but works its way underneath the skin like few movies have in recent memory.
[Jennifer Aniston's] exquisitely modulated and heartbreakingly understated performance is a revelation...easily one of the year's very best motion pictures.
Too mucky and uneven to signify an out-and-out winner, but...charming when it wants to be and not nearly as bad as early word has suggested.
A topically ambitious motion picture that never spots a true purpose for being.
A literate, delicately woven romantic drama that plays itself out more as a book would than a movie.
If there really was a merciful God, the film negatives would have been burnt to a crisp in a freak accident. No such luck.
Exemplary performances across the board...Poignant without turning into a sapfest, and subtle when it could have more easily been overwrought.
Rarely has a sport been captured on film with such daring originality and nailbiting tension.
A major waste...generic.
A mediocre melodrama, lugubrious in tone, but there are good things about it. More than expected. Not enough to recommend it.
If a horror movie's primary goal is to frighten and disturb, then They works spectacularly well...A shiver-inducing, nerve-rattling ride.
The kind of film one cannot simply walk away from and not think about. It is not only powerful, but the lasting impression it makes is nearly unshakable.
When all is said and done, [it] could have afforded another rewrite and a willingness to avoid pandering to the MPAA ratings board.
Treasure Island may be a much-loved story, but you would never know it from viewing the uninspired castration that is Treasure Planet.

If [director] Christian Duguay and [screenwriter] Michael Zaidan can be given millions of dollars by a studio to film something as obnoxiously bad as this, then even a young child of seven or eight has what it takes to work in Hollywood.
There must be an audience that enjoys the Friday series, but I wouldn't be interested in knowing any of them personally.
The very first movie I have seen in the secret agent series to warrant a recommendation.
By the time [it] finally decides to be a little different from the thirty other movies about inspirational teachers, the damage has already been done.
Consistently beautiful to look at and thematically daring, Far From Heaven remains unlike any other film you are sure to see this year.
Bigger, faster, funnier, and darker...[but] lacks the deep soul and character nuances of its predecessor.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Preposterous, labyrinthine, and aesthetically superb.
A by-the-numbers storyline, complete with character actions that don't make a lick of sense because of how underdeveloped they are.
Inoffensive entertainment for the undiscriminating, but lacks a fair share of the magic of the original.
A rather dismal, glaringly formulaic action-comedy.
Bowling for Columbine isn't just a highly recommended accomplishment; it deserves to be required viewing...One of the year's biggest entertainments, and one of its most thought-provoking.
Too often, the viewer isn't reacting to humor so much as they are wincing back in repugnance.
Contains a spooky ambiance from start to almost-finish.
There are singular moments of quirky inspiration,... however, at the service of a decidedly empty final product.
The premise of "Abandon" holds promise,... but its delivery is a complete mess.
Has elements of sheer brilliance, others of definite intrigue, and some that are disappointingly undernourished.
A merciless thriller, threateningly beautiful to look at and eerie to behold.
One of the most unconventional and conspicuously innovative cinematic treats of the year.
Woody Allen's weakest [film] since 1992's "Shadows and Fog."
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Succeeds on the sole basis of getting the heart pumping as one masterfully rendered, if hilariously over-the-top, action set-piece after the next is carried out.
A...more imaginative sequel...but plagued by an emptiness inside that cannot be denied.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: After a taut, top-notch first 80 minutes, director Doug Liman loses his way as the plotting and action sequences grow more predictable and mundane.
The star turns by Nicolas Cage and Adam Beach are, ultimately, what is worth seeing.
Its generic premise and low-scale action sequences prove to be a mostly forgettable affair.
After suffering through 116 minutes of this artificial gagfest, I was left pondering what exactly the secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood were, and why they were so damn divine.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: With a premise that is eerily similar to the tragic events of 9/11...it wavers somewhere on the disappointing line of emotional sterility.
You may not think too deeply about Undercover Brother once it's over, but you won't be able to deny how much you laughed out loud.
A skillfully complex and engrossing character study...A challenging piece of work that does not just thrill, but provokes thought out of its attentive evocations.
Individual moments in Spirit are better than its whole.
A comical, heartfelt gem that sidesteps an easy maudlin tone for something more grounded in reality.
Beautifully majestic...often awe-inspiring...five times better than Episode I.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A manipulative feminist empowerment tale thinly posing as a serious drama about spousal abuse.
The type of dumbed-down exercise in stereotypes that gives the [teen comedy] genre a bad name.
Takes an unflinching, emotionally rattling look at the recklessness of infidelity.
At best, Deuces Wild is adequate direct-to-video fare. At worst, it's a horrifically bad theatrical release.
A dazzling show-stopper that...is better than any of the Batman movies ever were.
A baffling misfire, and possibly the weakest movie [Woody Allen] has made in the last twenty years.
This is Angelina Jolie's movie all the way, and she does not disappoint.
A psychological thriller that is as thoroughly involving and taut as it is intelligently written.
There is a place for mindless popcorn fare, to be sure, but The Scorpion King proves that some things are even too mindless to enjoy your popcorn with.
In the annals of the Friday the 13th series, Jason X is one of the weaker entries.
A consistently involving experience, but the ending really does let down every that came before it.
Let's hope that the studio pays more attention to quality and creative freedom, and less time worrying about dollar signs, before the sequel goes into production.
There is nothing particularly clever or original to set it apart from the very basics of the genre.
Does not go far enough in its humor or stock ideas to stand out as particularly memorable or even all that funny.
Cold, unmoving, and desperately in need of a beating heart and a soaring soul, Minority Report is one of the most depressing disappointments of the year.
Its parts are infinitely better than its whole.
As skillfully made as horror films come. It's also about as genuinely scary.
Penetratingly draws us in to this passing snapshot of just a few of the many unsatisfying lives in Tinseltown.
Only a human vegetable could have possibly viewed the final cut and not have had any vocal concerns about the submerged level of quality on display.
A fully-developed, superlative character study.
Stuart Little 2 and Lilo & Stitch were respectable...in their own right, but The Country Bears is the most satisfying family film of the summer.
Most certainly the funniest Austin Powers movie yet, but it is also the most fervently uneven and charmless.
There is a refreshing absence of cynicism in Stuart Little 2--quite a rarity, even in the family film market. Eventually, it wins you over.
Exciting enough for the majority of its 138-minute running time to make for, at the least, a marginally arresting cinematic experience.
Not nearly as savvy a send-up of the genre as it thinks it is.
If a worse motion picture...sees the light of day in 2002, it will only be by sheer accident.
At the bottom rung of the series' entries.
Has an underlyingly hopeful current running throughout, but at its soul is one of an impossible heartbreak that can never be fully mended.
The premise of Reign of Fire is an exciting one that, ultimately, does not translate into an exciting film.
One of the funniest motion pictures of the year, but...also one of the most curiously depressing.
Amiable enough, but far too cliched and steadfastly generic to be worth recommending.
The relationship that forms between the girls and Professor Utonium is sweet and endearing. Then the horrid plot comes into play and all is destroyed.
The mercifully short running time is either a result of thin material or an attempt to be over before viewers start questioning how very generic what they are watching is.
Captures the resourcefulness and fragility of human nature with a consistently sharp eye that proves truly mesmerizing.
As jaggedly formed as [it is] around the edges, the focal point in each of these characters' lives remain crystal clear and solidly effective.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Sandler is back to form in a movie that has its share of over-the-top moments, but is likable for its underlyingly sweet love story.
Disney's most effortlessly charming and satisfying [hand-drawn] creation since 1999's Tarzan.
Don't Look Now brilliantly portrays the loves and losses we all experience, our here and now dictated by the fallibility of human nature and the cruelties of time.
The film spins its wheels as Winterbottom loses sight of the human element in exchange for a stab at mounting tension that simply isn't there.
A pointedly knowledgeable, frequently funny satire on slasher conventions and a terrifically scary, joyously suspenseful horror picture.

The loopy, satirical commitment with which [the filmmakers] have approached this second part gives it a slight edge over its predecessor. A likable, unapologetically R-rated slice of lunacy but a hair's width away from something greater.

By taking its time in the 4 years since the 1st movie, Dreamworks has mounted a superior 2nd installment, one that gives heretofore untapped personality to its characters and an extra shot of heart to the touching, age-old tale of a Viking and his dragon.
Culminating in the endurance of memories and hope for the future, "Lullaby" strikes an unforced, resonating chord. It is so much more than just a sad tale.
Entrancing, reminding of a thought-provoking media art exhibit exemplifying the antithesis of Hollywood moviemaking.
Doesn't hit every target or land every joke, but Steve Coogan's enthusiasm for the roleand the project as a wholeproves infectious.
By aping upon other like-minded pictures and never quite releasing himself from the shackles of humdrum convention, director Bobcat Goldthwait sells himself short.
"The Fault in Our Stars" is dignified and genuinely moving, a winsomely three-dimensional romance set against an unavoidably fatalistic backdrop.
Technically handsome, but approximately as deep and lasting as a small parking-lot puddle.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ambitious but clunky, "I'll Follow You Down" is not quite the picture to be Haley Joel Osment's post-adolescent breakthrough, but it is a step in the right direction.
The first hour's setup of "The Machine" is better than the threadbare guns-blazing action payoff, but the exceptionally fine work of Caity Lotz commands attention.
Growing up is a universal process of life to which anyone will be able to connect. "Ping Pong Summer" perfectly encapsulates this feeling, born out of the nostalgia of youth and times long past.

Even when "A Million Ways to Die in the West" takes a tumble, it never loses its winsomely sunny, eager-to-please disposition. Thisand the pleasure of watching the movie's charismatic actors mix it upmakes it all worthwhile.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Night Moves" is a masterfully crafted thriller, subtly, pointedly and auspiciously arriving at a destination as pessimistically valid as it is staggeringly loaded.

In building a fresh mythology, director Robert Stromberg has made a fairytale not only of darkness, but of hope, and not only of good vs. evil, but of the goodness that even those seen as evil are capable of possessing.
This is a satisfying entry, to be sure, and perhaps even the most ambitious, but the premise and its hulking ensemble are underused.

[Blu-ray Review] From the awesome newly commissioned cover artwork, to the terrific A/V elements, to a slew of new bonus content going above and beyond the call of duty, this is nothing less than a dream release. Buy it. Like, now.

All things considered, "Blended" deserves to be faster, funnier, peppier and less cluttered than it is. It is a testament to Sandler and especially the forever lovely Barrymore that even in lesser cinematic larks, they escape unscathed.
There is nothing wrong with "Chef" except that it is so ceaselessly, excessively pleasant. There is only so much humdrum harmony one can take before the film in question grows tedious.

A summer blockbuster with terrifyingly majestic sights, breathlessly constructed action sequences, tautly eloquent storytelling, and an overall sense of wonder and imagination. At the risk of sounding trite, it has to be said: "Godzilla" is awesome.

[Blu-ray Review] The narrative is by no means free and clear of clichés, but it becomes exceedingly obvious all the same that an attempt was made to separate it from the glut of similar body-count fare inundating the marketplace at the time.

A pedestrian, undeveloped indie clunker, its failure as a complete, satisfying story especially disappointing since the sibling relationship at its center could have been special with a better script.

[Blu-ray Review] "Ernest & Celestine" will bewitch children and grown-ups alike, a none-too-soon respite from the typically louder, busier animated features Hollywood tends to produce. This Blu-ray release is excellent on every level. Buy it.
To watch the boundlessly unpredictable "Borgman" unpeel one disquieting layer at a time is to be simultaneously invigorated, terrified and humbled by the vastness of its macabre ambition.
Are there some strong performances and the occasional potent moment? Sure. The problem is that there is no joy or liveliness to what's been put in front of the camera.
The closer one peers into the weird and macabre pleasures of "Curtains," the more its technical mastery and subtextual implications reveal themselves.

What keeps the movie energetic and resounding comes down to the astute performances from its actresses and the almost aching reality they bring to a premise both silly and ultimately tragic. Whether they're dead or not, growing up can be hell.
Tonally and creatively messy, and filled with entirely too much shouting. In the case of "The Angriest Man in Brooklyn," less would have been much, much more.

Gloriously animated with a preference for woodsy, mountainous landscapes (just make sure it is seen in the 2D format where the colors shine their brightest), "Planes: Fire & Rescue" outdoes itself when stacked next to the underwhelming "Planes."

A fitting companion piece that doesn't simply repeat the formula of its predecessor. Each are worthy of discussion and debate, both of them socially conscious, politically loaded allegories that just so happen to also pass for genre fare.
There are a handful of solid laughs sprinkled throughout, but the assumption is that bigger and better jokes are yet to come. They never do.

It is nothing short of stunning to watch "Boyhood" unfold. Richard Linklater's magnum opus offers more than what one has any right to expect from a film while simultaneously illuminating the infinite boundaries to which cinema is capable of going.
For all of Caesar's complexity, "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" lacks intimacy and personality in all that surrounds him.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is difficult to become fully absorbed in goings-on when the characters keep having to deal with plummeting IQs.
An eerie, insanely watchable documentary, "Killer Legends" was tailor-made for true-crime enthusiasts and folklore buffs.
An old-hat but somehow still fresh horror-comedy that wins its audience over by the personalities onscreen.
[Blu-ray Review] Lacking in scares and suspense, the picture throttles its audience with visual effects and evocative imagery, but never gets to the heart of the characters.
Flawlessly, heartbreakingly captures the joy, the fallibility and the transcendence of one's ever fleeting existence. Roger Ebert may no longer be here, but his impact and legacy will endure.

"Snowpiercer" is a rich, ravishing experience, a motion picture dripping in social consciousness and thematic intricacy without becoming preachy or losing sight of its other purpose as a rousing, robust entertainment.
As much as Melissa McCarthy is a presence worth watching in almost anything, it is difficult to get too excited about the low-key, wishy-washy "Tammy."

A sci-fi adventure with more interest in the truths of being thirteen years old than in its otherworldly storyline, the project's sincerest moments are not surprisingly skewed toward the former coming-of-age material.
A grisly thriller composed of talent on both sides of the camera, but the material rarely rises above lukewarm.
[Blu-ray Review] "The Final Terror" has been entirely unavailable in the U.S. since the days of VHS, but it fully earns the right to be rediscovered on Scream Factory's outstanding Blu-ray release.

"Transformers: Age of Extinction" isn't a "good" movie by any conventional standards, but as nothing more than empty, stupid, sometimes dazzling spectacle it provides exactly what audiences who flock to this series will be looking for.
One of the most enraging films to come around in some time, a picture of very real, uncompromisingly savage horrors.
A familiar crime yarn of strained familial bonds, but it manages to find an emotional truth and urgency in between the editorial streamlining of its various story threads.

"The Sacrament" is strong stuff, a concise, provocative exhibition of how the words of one individual can pull such an influentially harmful sway over a group of vulnerable people searching for purpose.

Ultimately, "Locke" is more noteworthy for the process of how it was made than the worthwhileness of the finished outcome, leaving nothing to the imagination while squandering the opportunity to explore what is going on behind Ivan's eyes.

Anyone can throw a stream of broad, raunchy jokes onto the screen and hope they stick, but if there is a real story, identifiable characters, and a beating heart behind them it can smooth over the occasional slack gag and rambling pacing.
The finished product plays as if it was thrown together by people whose research consisted of skimming over the West Memphis Three's Wikipedia entry.
A bravely imaginative, startlingly unnerving, freakily mesmerizing puzzle-box mindbender.
It is a near impossibility to stop from smiling during "Muppets Most Wanted," the charming feel-goodness of its spirit spreading to viewers like a particularly enchanting airborne virus.
A cogent testament to its overall success: when the movie ends, the urge lingers to find out what will happen next.
The gusto with which "Bad Words" embraces its title cannot be discounted, but the film never equips itself as successfully as it wants to.
[Blu-ray Review] An amalgamation of satire, conventional box-checking and fright tactics, "The Slumber Party Massacre" is smarter than most naysayers give it credit.

[Blu-ray Review] A minor work from the Mouse House, but Disney enthusiasts will still want to pick up this high-definition package for the stupendous picture and lossless audio upgrade. They know who they are, and for them this Blu-ray comes recommended.
If "Veronica Mars" gets one thing rightand, let's be serious, it gets a lot of things rightthe most lasting impression is the one it leaves its viewers with.

It is okay, even desired, that movies like "Need for Speed" embrace a popcorn-munching frivolity and sense of fun, but there still needs to be an underlying accountability for its subject matter and onscreen figures meant to be rooted for.
"Patrick" isn't one for necessarily spinning its wheels, but it too often hurts itself by jumping the rails into insanity.
"In Fear" is an oft-frightening film that stays with you. One of the most accomplished genre offerings of the last few years, it is a must for horror fans and suspense enthusiasts.
This swirling, pun-heavy time-traveling farce gets its smartly written part-wacky/part-sweet tone exactly right.
[Blu-ray Review] Dynamically directed, legitimately suspenseful as the climax plays out, and consistently captivating for all 102 minutes.
Has what it takes to bring a sense of awe back to modern audiences no longer easily impressed with fantastical, effects-driven sights.
A humdrum, even irritating slog that, safe to say, won't be giving anyone a sleepless night.
Embraces its disposable B-movie leanings, but remains mediocre even under these modest prospects.
Looking for a better movie in the same vein? Try 2005's "Flightplan," 2005's "Red Eye," or even 2006's "Snakes on a Plane," and treat this disappointing entry as the afterthought it finally becomes.
Irresistibly brash and deeply moving, "Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me" is a vanity-free portrait of a phenomenal artist.
A jet-black, vaguely satiric but never jokey crime thriller. Enthralling, wince-inducing and purposefully unpleasant.

"HairBrained" is stuck in one of those strained, superficial movie worlds that resemble Earth, but bear few commonalities with real life and human behavior. The experience of watching it is frustrating, then obnoxious in its too-cute adorkableness.

[Blu-ray Review] Looking and sounding like a million bucks (or more) and full of exhaustive bonus content new and vintage, the Blu-ray release of "The Jungle Book" is a must-own for anyone who loves animation, the Walt Disney studio, or film in general.
As comedy, as drama, as crime actioner, the film ends up making little impact at all.
[Blu-ray Review] Well shot and technically competent. It's also a bit of an insult to the viewer's intelligence.
"Hercules" did right by casting Dwayne Johnson in the lead, but then lets him and the audience down. This is overpriced, distinctly unsatisfying Hollywood schlock without a trace of bite.
Even if "Off Thomas" would have likely had a more fruitful life on the small screen, it is still an enjoyably fast-paced way to spend 96 minuteswith a few additional surprises up its sleeve.
A found-footage knock-off of "The Blair Witch Project" that grows more shameless by the minute.
A lavish big-screen spectacle to be proud of, an entry in the Marvel canon that comes thrillingly close to matching the spirit and sentiment found in Raimi's original trilogy.
If "The Double" is a tad too chilly dramatically for there to be much purgative punch, its unique ambience of unease and eccentricity is irresistible.
A lean, unsparing carousel of vigilante-style comeuppances, "Blue Ruin" brings newfound immediacy and quaking apprehension to a plot that, on paper, sounds as if it has been seen many times before.
Pertly humored and touching in spots without becoming too soapy, the film's entertainment value, plain and simple, goes a long way in smoothing over its problem areas.
At 76 minutes, "Dead Shadows" still feels a bit stretched beyond its means and concludes with little of the tragic grandeur it is aiming for.
In attempting to experiment with horror tropes and the found-footage format, director Karl Mueller tries too hard and walks away with a muddled, drastically uneven hodgepodge.
Somber but not humorless, "Only Lovers Left Alive" plays to a languid but involving rhythm that is its own.

It becomes apparent after only moments that the filmmakers are once more happy to reach for the lowest common denominator, slapping together an icky non-stop barrage of bodily functions, racial stereotyping and rancid epithets and call it a comedy.
"Transcendence" is much too lofty a title for a film that is rarely, if ever, transcendent.

A 106-minute game of cat and mouse where no one is safe, Greg McLean's second installment is fearless in the depths it plunders, very, very nearly matching the original in terms of its disturbing vitality and ultimate prolonged urgency.
[Blu-ray Review] Worthy of being rediscovered by fans of any of the actors or '80s comfort-food movie enthusiasts in general, "Chances Are" earns a recommendation.

A misguided sequel that seems meandering and carelessly thrown together with no attention paid to its mixed messaging and detrimental alteration in location. "Rio 2" takes a property that was already on the mediocre side and cuts it at the knees.

Any movie that engages its viewer on a topic he or she is normally not interested in is doing something right. And so, despite an array of plot contrivances and strained storytelling banalities around the periphery, "Draft Day" grew on me.
At the risk of classifying a work so thrillingly unclassifiable in its unrivaled vision, "Under the Skin" is an instantaneously quintessential 21st-century masterpiece in science-fiction and horror.
The buzz, it turns out, has overinflated a film with a riveting structure and not much else going for it.
For an enthusiast of horror and Broadway like myself, it is disappointing to root for "Stage Fright" and keep getting let down by the scattershot results.
There is the feeling that the expansive world of this ongoing Marvel saga is no longer spinning its wheels, but headed somewhere potentially fresh and exciting.
First and foremost, a vehicle for Kristen Wiig's transformative range as an actor. "Hateship Loveship" is a low-key gem.
A congenial animated feature that grown-ups can enjoy, parents will appreciate for its valuable themes, and little ones will be over the moon about.
Aronofsky has missed the boat on fulfilling this story's full potential. In terms of money spent and talent procured, this is a major creative fiasco in the annals of big-screen turkeys.
[Blu-ray Review] Lovers of all things Pooh will undoubtedly want to own this Blu-ray release, while children in the single-digit range will now have another go-to title to watch every Easter.
movie_title: Winnie the Pooh: Springtime with Roo (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Does not cover all that much fresh territory, but the film commands attention by taking the material to its extremes. Director David Ayer brings seat-jolting tension and savagery to the otherwise subjectively familiar.
As far as soapy, action-oriented, melodramatic spectacles go, "Pompeii" fits the bill.
A movie of tireless ideas and exciting stylistic panache.
A vivaciously crowd-pleasing space adventure. Of all of Marvel's many Phase I and Phase II projects tackled, "Guardians of the Galaxy" is, to date, the most alive with imagination and wonder.

"Ragnarok" plays like Norway's answer to "Jurassic Park." If the film is derivative of Steven Spielberg's 1993 blockbuster, the skillfulness with which the similarities are deposited is also what makes it memorable.
It has often been said that Hollywood changes people. "Starry Eyes" disturbingly, unforgettably takes this adage to the literal brink, then pushes far beyond it for chillingly good measure.
"Force Majeure" is a blistering, ultimately empathetic tour de force.
On the whole, this isn't a bad sequel, but it is a lesser one that lacks the heart and unlikely charm of Stan Winston's picture.
"The Dog" is insanely, endlessly watchable, a compelling human-interest documentary and a riveting true-crime exploration all in one.

Aesthetically, a vision of pure, impeccable imagination. If "Big Hero 6" concludes on a dishonest note, there is still no denying its successes as an entertainment of tender, witty accord. And it's pretty. Really, really pretty.
Illustrious of vision but even grander of ideas, "Interstellar" is majestic science-fiction done right. Mostly.
A dull, uninspiredalbeit aesthetically handsomeexperience.
An instant classic. Urgent yet compassionate, unyielding as well as frostily whimsical, the film transforms again and again as it cackles in the face of expectations.

Features a compelling plot and some stylish individual moments of tension during the thunderous climax, but its energy is sapped and forward momentum severely lacking. One patiently waits for it to take off, and it never fully does.
movie_title: Monkey Shines: An Experiment in Fear (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Were it not for an ingenious segment popping up right in the middleNacho Vigalondo's nightmarishly gutsy "Parallel Monsters"this gravely inferior sequel would be all but entirely worthless.

Regardless of the identical title, "The Town That Dreaded Sundown" isn't some pointless Xerox copy of its '76 predecessor, but a dynamic, atmospherically shot thriller with a perceptive knack for time, place and methodically mounting unease.
Destined to be voraciously talked about and studied for years to come. Perhaps it is imperfect, but it is also unmistakably great.
Take out Ig's horns and snake attacks and special powers, and what is left is an attentive exploration of fate and loss that flirts with profundity.

The performances in "Beneath the Harvest Sky" are better than the movie itself, an exceedingly derivative teen melodrama that too often loses focus and meanders off on lugubrious tangents with its criminal subplots.

It's a stupid, stupid movie, but also, in its own way, rather smart. Director Anthony C. Ferrante knows exactly what he is doing, and the results are as exceedingly amusing as they are entirely inconsequential.
Without its lead actors, there would be little that is original or special about "St. Vincent." The film is all the better for them.

The picture neither lifted my spirit nor made me feel the heightened emotions it was so obviously striving for. Were it not for the purposes of this review, "The Book of Life" would already be completely forgotten.
"The Best of Me" is content to remain a by-the-numbers excursion into tough-to-swallow soap opera theatrics. At this point, even Nicholas Sparks himself should know better.
Unusual and charming in a literally down-home way, but writer-director Gerard Johnstone's loopy script barely pierces the surface of its promising cast of players and their upside-down world.
Wading into cheese, corn and sap by the grand finale, "Ouija" is a spineless chiller in desperate need of a sturdier, more confident brand of chills.
A riveting horror-thriller with a textured sense of location and encroaching menace.
Tantalizing and disturbing in equal measure, "Foxcatcher" is a firecracker of a thriller about a perfect storm of events that led to an inexplicable tragedy.
"White Bird in a Blizzard" lingers in the mind long past its conclusion, a coming-of-age mystery with a dynamic lead heroine and an oddness that never loses sight of its resonance.
A skin-crawling thriller without compromise, "Honeymoon" is unpleasant, whip-smart and mesmerizing.
An alternately kooky, effectively low-key chiller worth seeing.
An undervalued gem ripening and enduring with age and perspective, destined for rediscovery.

Mildly competent and mostly diverting, but the formula is getting stale, and it feels like everyone involved knows it. These characters deserve a break, and so does this increasingly preposterous, threadbare series.
This is a somewhat tiresome found-footage excursion admirable in how it came together, and disappointing that it couldn't have added up to more than it ultimately does.
This is a terrifically chilling entertainment, one that deserves a spot alongside the best paranoid thrillers of the 1970s.
With an over-reliance on cheap jolts, this distaff sequel excels in fog-soaked atmosphere, but stumbles with its repetitive storytelling and stilted pacing.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "[REC] 4" is missing out on the deep-throated scares of the first two pictures and mostly drops the more supernatural elements previously established, but it is difficult to deny its tautly riveting force.

A heinously inflammatory propaganda piece that gives the documentary form and even-minded conservatives bad names, "America: Imagine the World Without Her" boils down to 105 minutes of uneducated ignorance.
movie_title: America: Imagine the World Without Her (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Julianne Moore's lead turn is towering and momentous, the work of an actor whose awe-inspiring natural talent knows no limits. Watching her in this role provides a thrill that not even some of the best action films could hope to attain.
Dark and heavenly, sardonic and touching, the film melodically navigates its every narrative turn and tonal shift with the same grace afforded to its gloriously shrewd music and lyrics.
With the exception of a winsomely sentimental denouement, this is exceedingly humdrum stuff.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A splendid entertainment, full of heart and toe-tapping bliss without becoming goopy and cloying. The soul of who Annie is and what "Annie" has always been is still very much in abundance.
It is better to start middling and finish strong than the inverse, and this is where "The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies" has arrived in the nick of time to turn things around.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Has undeniable technical merits and two fine central turns from Bale and Edgerton, but how successful can a sprawling live-action spectacle really be when it makes one wish he or she was revisiting 1998's animated, "The Prince of Egypt," instead?
Honest, aching and finally uplifting, "Wild" is a human story worth telling.
"The Hero of Color City" was made for five-year-olds and is unashamedly derivative of "Toy Story."
Depsite the by-the-numbers trajectory of its narrative, the film is renewed by Redmayne and Jones' impassioned turns.

"Whiplash" is intense, brutal and really bloody. Oh, and it's a music drama. An engrossing, piercing force with which to be reckoned, barreling over reality into operatic theatrics so deliciously over-the-top they border on the surreal.
The kind of plodding sequel that gets made because the first one was a financial success, not because there was necessarily another story worth telling.
Captivating as both drama and allegory, and may even one-up the previous two entries in terms of its force of will and emotional complexity.

Only laugh-out-loud funny a handful of times, but it is pleasing and sweet for most of the duration. While not quite the classic the book is, this genial film adaptation follows suit with comparable ideas and valuable sentiments.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Regardless of its errant imperfections, stirring conversation-starter "Men, Women & Children" is potent filmmaking about something.
A vision of artistry and pure entertainment, "Sleeping Beauty" will never, ever grow old.
"Million Dollar Arm" is bland and overlong at 124 minutes. Simply put, there is nothing here of interest.
Distinctly unimaginative in its third act but competently made nonetheless, "Jersey Shore Massacre" should divert viewers under the right circumstances. Otherwise, this is pretty disposable fare.
Spotty and slipshod, an unsteady, mostly vacuous excursion that not only shines a light on how much better "Sin City" did it, but virtually erases from memory with each passing scene.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "If I Stay" overcomes its more hackneyed embellishments and mawkish dialogue for a sensitively composed tale where themes of sacrifice, understanding and courage ring identifiably, piercingly true.
Pulled off with a fine cast and a taut storytelling sensibility from director George P. Cosmatos, the film is worth a revisit or a first-time look, whichever the case may be.

A brief but entertaining addition to the series canon. Disney's Blu-ray release comes with an audio commentary, three more "Toy Story" short films, and a bunch of other worthwhile extras. An engaging package that is easily recommendable.
There is a lot to admire as the film embraces a pleasing brand of old-school chills over modern-day, pop-culture hipness.

[Blu-ray Review] Some movies from childhood hold up when they are seen as an adult, and others do not, trapped only in the nostalgia of the time in which they were first watched. Recommended for fans, but temper expectations.
Bloated at 126 minutes, its long-windedness a letdown for a franchise that has yet to capture a confident, clip tone and rhythm. The further it goes, the more it falls victim to this lugubriousness.

[Blu-ray Review] A top-notch A/V offering, a few short but cute extra features, and a slight but likable movie for any agewhat's not to like? Disneyphiles and families with little ones should be confident in picking up this title. Gawrsh!
movie_title: Mickey, Donald, Goofy: The Three Musketeers (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [Blu-ray Review] Looking great and jam-packed with quality bonus content, the Blu-ray of "Without Warning" is something of a dream. Highly recommended.
movie_title: Without Warning (It Came Without Warning) (Alien Encounters) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: [Blu-ray Review] Disney's 2-in-1 Blu-ray release of "The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad" and "Fun & Fancy Free" is an irresistible deal that should become a mainstay in any Disney fan's high-def library.

[Blu-ray Review] Disney's 2-in-1 Blu-ray release of "The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad" and "Fun & Fancy Free" is an irresistible deal that should become a mainstay in any Disney fan's high-def library.
movie_title: The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad (1949)

movie_review_blurb: [Blu-ray Review] Isn't one of the Mouse House's absolute best, but it is an astutely written entertainment with a keen aesthetic sense and a fun ensemble of characters. For Disney collectors, picking "Hercules" up is a no-brainer. Highly recommended.
Not without its contrivances as it caters to younger audiences, "Bears" is a nonetheless earnest, adorable real-life adventure.
[Blu-ray Review] For genre fans of the offbeat, horrific and tongue-in-cheek, Scream Factory's impressively packed Collector's Edition Blu-ray release of "Motel Hell" is worth seeking out.

For a motion picture taking place within a population suffocated by its own sameness, "The Giver" dazzles and provokes as a rallying cry in favor of the irreplaceable messiness and beauty that life has to offer.
"Step Up: All In" is so divorced from anything resembling reality that it is astonishing to behold. The best advice, though, would be to avoid beholding it.
In spite of the movie's shortcomings, there is an eager-to-please quality to the whole of "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" that is difficult to resist.

Cloaking tragedy in a veil of humor without compromising the truth of its thematic eulogy to love and loss, the film runs the gamut of emotions. It's droll. It's mournful. It's adorable, and surreal, and eerily burrows its way under the viewer's skin.
A junk-food thriller with skillfully believable special effects and a lurchingly ham-fisted script, one that commands attention and spurs resulting groans in equal measure.
There is much to admire in "Tarzan," but no lingering emotional through-line to this particular telling.

When a premise is juicy enough and the accompanying script is good enough, it can go a long way in smoothing over certain irksome deficiencies. For that matter, so can a host of legitimately earned scares.

With "Magic in the Moonlight," Woody Allen appears to have made a movie just to make one, bringing to it little of the passion, urgency and inspiration that separates his superior efforts from his second-rate fillers.
No one will be anointing "Aftermath" a feel-good triumph anytime soon, but there are flashes of unanticipated sensitivity and disquieting inspiration that cannot be denied.

Delivering a more riveting journey than ultimate destination, the film excels as a fantastical, thick-tensioned mood piece with an eye for the deliciously, preternaturally unknown. It also happens to be damn scary.
This is a special gem of a movie.

Not only withholds the dignity of "The Conjuring," but actually surpasses that film's fiendish parade of frights. For horror enthusiasts in search of a serious tingle in their spines, "Annabelle" delivers in spades.
"Gone Girl" is nothing if not absorbing, beginning as a sort of investigative procedural before corkscrewing halfway through to become something else entirely.
This cavalcade of sophomoric, mean-spirited schlock is an embarrassment, putting to shame all of the exciting, limitless possibilities the horror genre has to offer.

A Lifetime melodrama posing as a big-screen thriller, "A Good Marriage" starts with the germ of a provocative premise, then proceeds to take it in a direction that betrays the audience's intelligence.
"The Boxtrolls"and, for that matter, Laikaboldly play to their own tune, and theirs is an uncommonly wonderful voice that too seldom gets heard in today's American-made animated features.

"The Equalizer" isn't above excessthere is a slow-motion walk away from one of screen history's most bombastic explosions, for instancebut it delivers upon all of its gritty, crowd-pleasing pursuits.
A scabrous, tightly drawn chase dramaeven if, ultimately, the narrative doesn't lead anywhere particularly new.

Constructed as a mystery, its various layers gradually unpeeling with each new discovery, the film eschews a lot of early exposition in exchange for a deliberate build-up. This first installment is certainly promising enough to warrant a continuation.

A dramedy about the bonds and dysfunctions of family and the possibilities of roads not taken, "This Is Where I Leave You" is too pleased with itself by a half, hiding its valid truths behind a wall of mugging artificiality.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Tusk" is deeply weird and spectacularly wonderful.
It is a joy to see a film that tackles the topic of art and its value in the world, and all the better that actors of Owen's and Binoche's caliber can lead it.
"Dolphin Tale 2" doesn't have a pessimistic bone in its body. Indeed, the film is so earnest that one almost feels like a curmudgeon having to criticize it.
"Pumpkinhead" is horror, fantasy, supernatural thriller and tragedy all wrapped up in an enthralling, phatasmagorically realized whole.
"A Long Way Down" doesn't bother to explore its characters on any substantial level and comes close to offending in how flippant the whole thing is to the subject of suicide.

An observant double character study, "The Skeleton Twins" revolves around two protagonists who are worthy of the viewer's time & sympathy. The film gets beautiful mileage out of the sterling work of the indomitable Kristen Wiig & a revelatory Bill Hader.
An ideal weekend movie, the sort of entertaining low-budget horror item that will work best for audiences looking to unwind and have fun after a long, busy work week.
Deals up some infernal imagery that chillingly toys with concepts of identity and the unknown, yet these individual moments do not collectively build to anything of note.
"They Came Together" proves that spoof humor can still be quick and funny, and not have to consistently reach for the lowest common denominator. The wait was worth it.
Is "Baby Blues" about an evil doll, or just the story of a young woman whose psyche is nearly destroyed by the flagrant dishonesty of the people around her? Either way, it's just not very good.
"Cabin Fever: Patient Zero" lacks the personality and humor of Eli Roth's debut feature, but it delivers in droves on the grisly brand of payoffs for which his original film is known.
Fans of "The Legend of Hell House" and haunted house stories in general should have no qualms about picking up a copy. Recommended.
A quality family film likely to stand the test of time, "Paddington" is practically impossible to dislike.
A brooding and sumptuous thriller. "In Secret" is immensely fine, sudsy climactic theatricality and all.
Tackled with a sense of thoughtfulness and compassion that makes the would-be garden-variety narrative worthwhile.
A well-made film, one that is admirable for what was achieved even as it slightly disappoints for what it could have been under less-restrictive production circumstances.
Tough and tinged with the kind of nostalgia that's both bitter and sweet. Very funny at times, sometimes painfully so, "The Way Way Back" deserves to become a go-to summer movie.

If "The Lone Ranger" weighs itself down again and again, at least it finally delivers during a stunning third-act set-piece that at long last incorporates all of the elements that should have been readily up on the screen throughout.
Pleasant as it plays out, but also glaringly lacking when stacked up next to its shrewder, sweeter, more inventive predecessor.
Worth running out to see for anyone who dares lament that they don't make funny movies like they used to.
A political disaster movie that also, little by little, turns into a cinematic disaster.

Warts and all, "Maniac" still does what it should, digging under the skin and never for a second shying away from the grim realities of a protagonist who's not only an antagonist as well, but a violent sociopath.

Mild to an almost offensive degree, "World War Z" has a whole host of issues, but the most irresponsible of all is in turning a grand-scaled, epic story of an undead pandemic into such a benign experience.
Welcome back, Pixar. You've been missed.

Splendidly pert dialogue, laugh-out-loud situations, and an ensemble of ready and willing performers combine to ultimately give "I Give It a Year" the volt of electricity it needs to keep from becoming familiar and obvious.

Provocative and beautifully crafted, radiating with another one of the auteur's typically flawless soundtrack compilations, "The Bling Ring" brings insight and hypnotic urgency to a story not to be believed if it weren't so unbelievably true.
A satisfying and faithful capper to a series that was made by true-blue horror buffs as a love letter for true-blue horror buffs. Job well done.
Mistakes serious faces and shaky-cammed anarchy for what it so desperately needed most: a sense of wonder and a beating heart.
Dies a slow, wheezing, woefully unfunny death.

Consistently surprising with stylistic ingenuity and storytelling elegance. Never afraid to journey into the blackest of hearts, the filmmakers involved in "V/H/S/2" have given the project their best shot, and it shows.
Finds varying degrees of success as a genre film, but fortunately makes up for its downfalls as a compelling conversation starter.

It wants to be "Clueless" meets Gregg Araki, but it has far less on its mind than the former teen classic and not nearly enough provocative material to match the latter indie director's sensibilities.

The first feature film from "Funny or Die..." director Jordan Vogt-Roberts, "The Kings of Summer" isn't very funny and dies slowly but surely as a coming-of-age film that bludgeons the viewer with its own quirkiness.
Pleasant? On occasion. Laugh-out-loud funny? Rarely. "The Internship" seems content to settle on middle-of-the-road. Such mediocrity wouldn't pass muster at Google, and it doesn't here, either.
Lacks the sweeping romanticism of "Before Sunrise," replaced by the realities of one's day-to-day existence in a world where things don't always turn out the way one imagines, or hopes. Such is life.
Definitely a curiosity piece, but one gets the sneaking suspicion it wasn't also meant to be an inert one.

More "Transformers" than "Cloverfield." Where is the terror? Where is the suspense? Where is the beauty? The majesty? The sense of loss? "Pacific Rim" is a pretty, dumbed-down shell of a movie. It could have been so, so much more.
Almost aggressively more of the same. If you hated the last one, you'll be in misery all over again. If you took to the predecessor, you'll find this one a fitting continuation.
A well-intentioned but sorely misguided fable.
Lean and observational, "Prince Avalanche" relies upon the performances from Paul Rudd and Emile Hirsch to guide the way.
[Blu-ray Review] It's got first-rate, photorealistic CGI effects, fine period art direction and costumes, and features an irresistible lead performance.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: When it comes to big-screen biopics, "Lovelace" never makes it past the shallow end of the pool.
Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley are one of the most appealing onscreen couples in recent memory.
Doesn't exactly win points for originality, but it is affecting all the same, scripted with care and showing that Kristen Bell is fully capable of diversifying the types of film roles she takes on.
Doesn't really break any new ground for the director, and yet as a technical exercise it's nice to see De Palma back in his element.
A great-looking entertainment that could have reached new classic status with a longer cut that allowed the characters to breathe, expand and deepen.
Is it wrong to expect more from the Disney brand when they've proven they can do so much better than this disposable trifle?
A well-acted, genre-busting curiosity, "Jug Face" is bold of premise and disquieting in its low-key mounting.
The drop in quality and care [from "The Lightning Thief"] is kind of a bummer.

Definitely a crowd-pleaser, all but guaranteed to be a sleeper hit of the late-summer movie season even if it is jagged around the edges and tries too hard to be too many things at once by the finale.

Lindsay Lohan's raw, passionate, haunted performance is easily the best thing about "The Canyons," a film that depicts the superficial and passive-aggressive without finding any deeper comment or point beneath the surface.
Whereas the inaugural movie appeared to try to be a family film of quality, this one has a derivative, made-by-committee feel.
If director Joshua Oppenheimer occasionally loses his way in his own narrative, where this picture demands attention is in its chilling portrait of indoctrination and evil.
Watching Halle Berry shoot hoops, flirt with Benjamin Bratt, and beat up Sharon Stone in "Catwoman" is starting to sound mighty preferable.
Loose and limber, proudly R-rated and wickedly amusing.
A devastating portrait of the fallibility of man and the importance of appreciating what one has while it's still here.
A defiant and sinister piece of experimental, Grand Guignol cinema, not easy to forget or to deny.
A forgettable, made-by-committee production with actors who should know better.

With a sure-footed elegiac pace and a keen understanding that anticipation and what we don't see is sometimes more affecting than the payoff, "The Conjuring" plays like a loving throwback to cinema of the '70s.

Because Wiig is an actor of uncommon depth, one can easily tell when projects aren't equal to her intelligence and talent. "Girl Most Likely" is one such blunder, a plodding, familiar indie comedy that wades too often into sitcom territory.

A synthetic sleight of hand that divulges plenty of tricks but never quite settles on a satisfactory endgame, "Now You See Me" moves sluggishly through its paces while managing to waste just about every actor in its top-flight ensemble.

This is not the same M. Night Shymalan who gave audiences a reason to shriek in fright one minute and uncontrollably weep the next. Where has that artist gone? "After Earth" bears the mark of a work-for-hire who has all but given up.
The near-incomparable Greta Gerwig gives Frances a fire, an exuberance, and a three-dimensional uniqueness that ensures the viewer never sways from her side.

Better than it probably deserves to be. When so many trilogies start strong and finish with a whimper, "The Hangover" movies set the bar very low to begin with, and then lower still, just so the only way to go for the finale would be up.
Might have been more fun and less offensive had it been made in the 1980s or '90s. In 2013, however, it hits just a little too close to home to be brushed aside as mindless entertainment.
Too good for too long to not be worth recommending, but it's disappointing to see so much potential squandered just for a dishonest twist and some cheap thrills.
It is rarer than it may seem for a movie to come along that inspires not only a fairly consistent stream of chuckles, but also a few well-earned guffaws along the way.

Old-fashioned and not entirely unexpected, the film doesn't work very well as a mystery, but garners a creeping intrigue all the same as the many faces of teenaged protagonist India Stoker are revealed.
An imperfect but perfectly gorgeous experience, a motion picture of quite literal cosmic enlightenment with the creativity and gall to put most run-of-the-mill movie releases to shame.
Colin Farrell and Noomi Rapace are a pairing made in Hollywood heaven. It's too bad "Dead Man Down" can't quite pull itself out of purgatory.
An inventive and stirring fantasy. Chances are very good that L. Frank Baum would be immensely pleased.

There is some immature amusement to be had by "21 & Over," the occasional clever line of dialogue or quirky situation, but then there's the majority of time spent wallowing in stereotypes, mixed messaging, and overbearing racial insensitivity.
Regrettably, the film isn't much more than a series of moments, eventually becoming tedious before the 88-minute running time is up. It all feels very much tacked-on.
Topped by a clever little zinger of a last scene, the film ends up being a fun action romp after alland, again, that's in spite of the fantastical creatures of the title falling flat.

An intensely evocative, absolutely spine-tingling thriller that paints an empathetic portrait of realistically strained modern-day suburban domesticity before little by little introducing a rasping pall of doom.
There is little room for denial that "Snitch" means well, but there also isn't anything to give it those extra shots of immediacy, grit and verve it so desperately needs.
Sure, it's occasionally loopy, but also thoroughly suspenseful in spots and rather pleasant as a whole.
This 97-minute piffle may run a full half-hour shorter than its predecessors, but it is so dull and lacking in creativity and tension that it feels like the longest one.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Not romantic enough to make the viewer gush and not imaginative enough to work as pure fantasy, the film falls into a mediocre rut that it doesn't pull out of.
February or not, "Would You Rather" is an instant contender for feel-bad movie of the year, but please do not read this as a criticism.
Beginning as an urgent indictment and culminating in a silly, sudsy about-face that means very little and is sure to produce groans, the film betrays and cheats itself out of a point.
For all of its extraneous subplots and contrived scripting [the film's] got one decidedly potent weapon in the form of the fearless dynamo Melissa McCarthy.
The end of life really ought not to be treated as such an immature lark.
It exists in a land of middle-of-the-roadness, one that does nothing spectacularly, but can be admired for staying as uncompromising as it is.
It's so thrilling when all the elements of a film come together just right. Chill-inducing cadavers be damned, "Warm Bodies" is sheer bliss.
"The Croods" is 2013's first major animated tentpole release, and, as such, it will hopefully only be uphill from here.

This superior sequel cranks the bloody beatings, gorings, andmost importantheart up to eleven while building upon a sort of mythology ambitiously operatic enough to hang with the big-boy crime fighters.
As frightening as any conventional horror movie, as cautionary as any crime-drama, and as gritty yet empathetic as any coming-of-age story in quite some time.
May have a grittiness to it that its predecessor lacked, but it has corrected absolutely none of its problems.

One must sit through 90 minutes of macho posturing and moronic dialogue before the first memorable action set-piece arrives. From there, things finally take off, but the diverting third act is not enough to make up for the endurance test of the first two.
Forgettable to the point where its memory begins to fade the moment the film is over, "Epic" diverts only in that it's not strictly a chore to watch. Faint praise, to be sure, and epically un-epic.
Giving all impending summer 2013 tentpoles a reason to be intimidated, "Star Trek Into Darkness" should safely reintroduce audiences to just how much fun moviegoing can be.

A sensory wonderland both intimate and vast as director Baz Luhrmann creates an immersive onscreen world that, for all of its bold and fancy reimaginings, remains accurate to F. Scott Fitzgerald's sumptuous literary descriptions.
"Iron Man 3" might not be a total bust, but it does result in one big "meh."
"The Happy House" is nothing if not a fresh mixture of colorful characters, questionable manners, and rusty, suddenly-new-again horror conventions.
Lines such as, "Who do you have to lynch for a Cosmo around here?" pass for a version of humor that only a Mississippi slave owner in 1858 would likely find funny.
Michael Bay has helmed his most confident, grown-up feature, to date.
A ravishing, eye-popping, even groundbreaking science-fiction epic. "Oblivion" impresses again and again on a scale as emotionally intimate as it is physically colossal.

Though admirable for moving away from director Rob Zombie's comfort zone by focusing on mood and atmosphere over jump scares and a body count, the viewer walks away feeling the one thing horror should never elicit: indifference.
A penetrating examination of who we are as a people and culture living in the advanced electronic age of the here and nowa place as potentially dangerous and harmful as it is radically convenient.
The inexcusably desperate "Scary Movie 5" is this once-prosperous series' death rattle.
The company isn't the problem in "The Company You Keep." Everything else is.
There is only so much twirling in wheat fields a person can handle before it starts to come off as a mockery of itself.
"Breathtaking" is an adjective that should be used sparingly when discussing film, lest the word begin to lose its rightful weight and inference. "Trance" is just that, and then so much more.
Falls back too frequently upon manipulation and speech-giving to get its obvious points across.
It might not be "Cabin in the Woods," but this cabin in the woods nevertheless holds a sharp-toothed bite.
A little too convenient at sorting out its plot threads, but nevertheless remains a tough, compelling, uncompromising experience.
If writer-director Shane Carruth were to ever find a way to get his audience to feel as well as he gets them to think, he might be truly onto something extraordinary.

An original sci-fi vision from writer-director Andrew Niccol, one that takes chances, falls on its face a time or two, and otherwise works as well as it does because of how brazenly different it dares to be.
Who was "Family Weekend" made for? Beats the hell out of me.
The romance between Tina Fey and Paul Rudd is by far the most conventional and least interesting thing in the otherwise pleasantly articulate "Admission."
Is "Almost Human" an alien invasion story? A gory slasher flick? A tribute to B-movies as a collective? It is all of the above, and really rather groovy.
The clichés come fast and furious in "Lee Daniels' The Butler," as numerous as the amount of times the viewer is reminded this is Serious Oscar Fare™.
[Blu-ray Review] I wish I could wholeheartedly recommend "Dark Angel" as a movie as much as I recommend the Blu-ray's technical side.
Darkly funny, sexually explicit and fearlessly disturbing all at once, anchored by Leonardo DiCaprio in a deliriously brilliant performance.
Doesn't resonate with the sheer force and impact it could have, and yet it still does make a truthful, comforting impression at its own pace, on its own terms.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A genre-busting romantic drama of both generous whimsy and heart-crumbling beauty, "Her" isn't quite like any other film out there.
An unforced, low-key drama, its story one that is more episodic than conventionally plotted. Not a lot is accomplished or resolved, and yet that is one of Ethan and Joel Coen's overriding messages.
An example of performances transcending the motion picture they are in, "American Hustle" excels when observing its human figures in all of their honest and pretend forms.
As much as the fervent "Anchorman" supporters might have wanted a sequel, the redundant "Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues" sees to it that Ron Burgundy is kind of no longer a big deal.
Feels like a chore rather than a source of entertainment and/or enlightenment.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A respectful glimpse into the complicated but virtuous person P.L. Travers was, as a woman and an artist. She may have been hard to please, but she likely would have approved of this warmly felt biopic.
A hackneyed story that spoon-feeds its messages to the viewer while devising just-plain-wrong set-pieces involving a run-in with the Ku Klux Klan and the crucifixion of a bratty little white girl.
The performances are worth the experience, more so than a story that doesn't deliver the amount of insight or enlightenment it thinks.
Unambitious and evaporates almost as rapidly as it plays out, but at least it knows what it is and only has one aim: to divert viewers for two hours.
"Madea's Big Happy Family" is a facetious title; there's not a happy one in the bunch. Eventually, neither is the viewer.
If the film's successive missteps are frustrating, though, it is because the rest of "Oldboy" has a dangerously irresistible ambience difficult to deny or resist.
Too pat by a half during the finale, but Tyler Perry shows a maturity as a filmmaker that would pave the way for arguably his best picture, 2010's "For Colored Girls."
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A half-silly/half-moralistic story about how it is never too late to turn things around, "Madea Goes to Jail" is as wispy as whipped cream, but also as easy to consume.
"Frozen" is lighthearted and funny when it wants to be, but its dramatic core is where it gets its strength and durability.
Has far more on its mind than ornate costumes and CGI effects, and this is what finally lifts the movie above its more mundane trappings.
A moving little slice-of-life gem, unassumingly big in existential significance.
Tyler Perry means well, but there is no denying that all of this would work far better on daytime television.
It is a film full of jagged edges, but one that is sincere and beguiling at its core.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)
