Here is a motion picture that proudly bends genre conventions and follows a multilayered narrative not quite like any other viewers will have seen.
A good picture, certainly, but no more than that. In spite of what others might claim, there just isn't much substance here beyond the patently obvious.
A hobbled-together mess, high on style and low on substance, while emotional potency clocks in two degrees above freezing.

Viewers willing to check their brains at the door and go along for the ride will find it a suitably exciting, if not exactly tougher or smarter, version of subject matter that is timely in an entirely different way than it was nearly thirty years ago.
One of the year's most gripping dramas, a visual wonderstruck with an emotional chord that reverberates far beyond the awesome imagery.
A motion picture for anyone who loves movies, revels in the art of filmmaking, and appreciates the special, one-of-a-kind, cathartic power of great horror cinema.
To call the ho-hum and inconsequential "The Last Stand" a B-movie is to give it too much credit; only on rare occasions does it deserve even a C.
Elle Fanning gives it her all, but is deserving of a better showcase than "Ginger & Rosa" offers her.
"A Haunted House" runs a scant 86 minutes, but it's a painful 86 minutes, seeming twice as long and more punishing by the second.
A confident, lovingly articulated mood piece about a subject that is universal, yet rarely told.
Dense, gritty, sumptuous, and free of superfluous melodrama.
The sort of film that fails to give its audience anything but a shrug to take away with them.
Will no doubt divide audiences, even within die-hard fan circles, but it is almost always preferable to take chances than to repeat old tropes with no concern for putting a spin on things.

Moves at an unassuming, surprisingly intoxicating pace, aware of the ebbs and flows and overall qualities that come with living outside the big cities. If only for a few hours, it's a place worth visiting.
Billy Crystal and Bette Midler class it up as much as they can. It's just such a shame "Parental Guidance" is otherwise so darn dumb.

The late holiday season's most dizzyingly imaginative and thoroughly pleasing release, an end-of-year jewel as chock-full of sizzling performances as it is bursting with busted knee caps and spurting innards.
Positions the wrong person as the lead protagonist. The film lays its heart on the line, but its focal point is off.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If "Jack Reacher" falls into more predictable patterns, it does open up some potentially fascinating avenues to take the title character if this were to turn into an ongoing franchise.
Thoughtful and well-made, but it also might be a little too simplistic and straightforward for its own good.
Instead of cheering and wiping away tears at the end, it leaves one deflated as he or she ponders the ways this translation has gone wrong.
A vanity project of the most thankless order.

Airy fare, but Seth Rogen and Barbra Streisand are just about as perfect as perfect can be together, believably playing son and mother in all of its hair-pulling, but ultimately reassuring, intricacies.
With approximately six more hours to go, it's tough not to shudder at the sheer lengths director Peter Jackson is about to go to stretch this story into paper-thin taffy.
Don't let this small but potent little gem pass by.
An acceptable but very slim romantic comedy.
A rare sequel that ably tops the original in just about every department.
It's all rather self-indulgent and certainly on-the-nose, but also knows how to keep the viewer's attention. It starts by grabbing for the jugular.
Some kind of twisted work of genius, proudly joining the upper echelon of horror cinema.

The chances of seeing a bunch of people dressed as Smiley this October 31st is giving too much credit to a project that will be forgotten before it has any chance of becoming more than a minor pop-cultural footnote.
Irresponsible and insulting in the way that it takes great pains to, quite correctly, rail against messing with the natural order of things before hypocritically contradicting itself in the end.
Basically a loose, lesser remake of its predecessor, there is the cloying sense that what is being watched is extraneous and unnecessaryand really, really loopy.
The cinematic equivalent of a theme park ridefun in the moment, inconsequential in the long run, and over in a blink.
Art-house cinema at its most achingly smarmy and self-indulgent. Frustrating verging on abysmal verging on infuriating.
It is the genuine central relationship [between Dax Shepard and Kristen Bell] that turns this off-the-wall free-for-all into more than just a throwaway romp.
Sounds like it should be a blast. Why, then, is the reality about as fun as chewing on a hand grenade?
Simply put, it is no less than the most confident, fully realized, and just plain imaginative stop-motion animated feature since 1993's holiday classic "The Nightmare Before Christmas."
A serious drama that works far better as an inadvertent comedy of filmmaking ineptitude.
Skirts the credibility line, occasionally coming off as a stretch and other times so eerily plausible it might as well be a documentary.
Delivers a series of well-chosen jolts and unsettling ideas. Otherwise, gee, it really is quite a lot like countless other pictures that have come before it.
Produced by Walt Disney Pictures, this live-action fable is the best original project the studio has rustled together in at least a few years.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Lewd, crude and sometimes a gas, but as a political satire the film recoils in trepidation, fearful of leaning too left or right and alienating a segment of the audience.
The "X-Men Origins: Wolverine" or "Exorcist II: The Heretic" of the "Bourne" series, a low-rent, low-voltage rehash with each new idea offered up being a bad one.

There aren't nearly enough movies made these days about and catering to the AARP-aged population, and even fewer still with the intelligence and insight said audience members deserve. For this, "Hope Springs" is something rather rare and special.
Doesn't come close to earning the revery of its moniker. This is one misbegotten deviation from the norm not worth repeating.
Looks as good as can be, but, as is so often the sad case with big-budget Hollywood bonanzas, there's a precious absence of brains to go along with the diverting imagery.
The third and, thus far, wisest installment based on Jeff Kinney's best-selling books.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cannot possibly be what anyone involved had in mind when they signed on.
Easily the best entry in the surprisingly financially successful dance franchise.
Delicate, unassuming, and, like Ruby herself, kind of difficult not to fall for.
Blends the narrative, the dancing, and the music in a vibrant way that hasn't been captured before. Otherwise, it's really just more of the same.
Competent and too innocent in its own way to strongly dislike, but there also isn't much to push it above mediocrity. There's more substance in cotton candy.
Even if the picture breaks no new ground, the verve of the actors and their fancy footwork is half the battle.
May run just 82 minutes (and that includes drawn-out final credits), but the picture's brevity can't hide what a toothless waste of potential it all is.
There is something most definitely amiss when a four-and-a-half-minute short has more laughs, wit, sweetness and creativity than the feature-length main attraction that succeeds it.

An enthralling mixture of lyricism and curdled blood, the film is at once heartfelt and wrenching, quietly ominous and literally cutthroat, a western-cum-gangster-saga in a vein both classic and modern.
The real find, above all else, is Mike Birbiglia himself. He's as sure of a natural in front of the camera as he is behind it.
The outcome is unsatisfying, but it may inspire a fair share of viewers to seek out a shower immediately afterwards.
Pleasant despite being awfully slight and rather mean-spiritedproof that this material might have made a far better picture with a smarter, more controlled voice.
Though it might sound like a hacky platitude, don't be surprised if "Pitch Perfect" leaves a fair share of its audiences outwardly cheering.
Takes on a serious topic, but fret not; the film is an absorbing, marvelously-acted piece of work that entertains without ever feeling like a school assignment itself.
Proof positive that the makers of "Hotel Transylvania" did not do their research: Frankenstein's monster is named Frankenstein.
Brutal and chilling, if not air-tight, it is best to allow the many pleasures of "Looper" to sweep over without dwelling too closely on particulars.
One of the truest coming-of-age films in recent memory.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Marred by all the mistakes of a novice who has watched a lot of horror movies, but never quite figured out the key ingredients that made a good one effective.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A full-blown entertainment of observational humor and relatable poignancy.
Director Robert Lorenz means well, but "Trouble with the Curve" is so run-of-the-mill it is difficult to work up much enthusiasm or concern.
A provocative drama, but also a frustrating one. Individual moments spark to life, while the rest of it is akin to a book that's scarcely been read beyond the synopsis on the flap.
When "End of Watch" works, it compels with an immediacy few filmmakers can hope to achieve. It's worth stepping over the occasional indiscretions to get to the good stuff.
It's a give-and-take picture, one with faults as well as virtues, but writer-director Josh Radnor makes certain that he leaves his audience with something to think about.
Likable in spurts but too safe by a long stroke, "Backwards" would be right at home as a cable movie airing on ABC Family.
Proves without a shadow of a doubt that this franchise is just jerking viewers around as it paces in circles. At some point, even Alice is going to have to admit that she's been wasting her time.
A well-crafted dramatic thriller with a rare braininess and a deeply unsettling undercurrent.
Carries with it a low-key transcendence, flourishing first and foremost through its lost and aching protagonist.
Sometimes, less is more. "The Words" is one of those times.
A grab-bag of clever, diverse frights.

Before jumping the rails by the climax, director Bornedal gets it right, his know-how of the genre, of the importance of building atmosphere and character over predictable jump scares, recalls a lush, adult-minded style all but missing since the 1970s.

A smutty feature-length sitcom with heart, "For a Good Time, Call..." is like a well-cast, middle-of-the-road television series; it's pleasant enough while passing the time, but also so insignificant that it's only too easy to forget.

As black as comedy can get while still ending up a crowd-pleaser. Straddling a very fine line, but never toppling over, the film's future cult status and high rewatchability factor are all but guaranteed.
Neither the movie nor the performance is memorable enough to cause much stir, and they will likely get lost amidst better end-of-the-year offerings.
Director Lynn Shelton garners three terrific performances from her leads, but she does so while losing sight of her most promising narrative thread.
This studio version is, oddly enough, far less commercial and only about a quarter as lushly mysterious as the superior overseas original.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though centering on ventriloquism, it is clear that director Mark Goffman's film could just as easily be about anything.
Freed from the shackles of the overpriced, unnecessary 3D, it should really impress when it hits high-definition Blu-Ray. Too bad the rest of the film doesn't match the visuals.
Competent but hollow, the film is out of sight, out of mind the moment the end credits roll.
Provides a sympathetic, if gradually unhinged, protagonist, then proceeds to put him through hell for no apparent reason other than because it can.
Defies all rules by being a post-trilogy sequel as vividly original and resourceful as any horror film released in years.
A non-stop, over-the-top, intentionally ridiculous smorgasbord of violence and bloodshed that ceases being disturbing and just becomes pure, 100% fun.
Visually and aurally, "Hanna" is a highlight so far in 2011.
Erect creature penises or not, this is a limp misfire.
Whether or not the theatrical arena was the appropriate medium with which to tell Bethany Hamilton's story is up for debate, but it is nonetheless one that deserved to be told.
Creatively mishandled to the point of making a mockery of its own brand.
A pale, uninspired, unnecessary redux. Greta Gerwig, bless her, floats effortlessly into the film to almost single-handedly save the day.
The frequently mind-bending plot keeps the viewer engaged, but it's the sympathetic attention to its characters and their urgent connections with each other that give the audience a reason to care.
Tiny Tim's legacy might not have been to terrify the living hell out of people, but that is what it will be once this movie gets done with him.
A small but pleasurable film that nonetheless leaves room for improvement, "Win Win" is more like "Win Tie" on final calculation.
A faint shadow of the original.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A meretricious, nonsensical, CGI-heavy fiasco, tedious enough to become a chore and so empty it's likely to weave a glaze over most audiences' eyes.
In the end, no matter who these characters are to each other, they've grown to mean something to us. Their emotions are true.
Resembles a mundane two-hour episode of "Law & Order: Los Angeles."
There are certain actors who you can just look at and instantly fall in love with. Tom Hanks is one. Drew Barrymore is another. Bradley Cooper is not.
It's vaguely pleasant and never offensive, but also predominately blah.
There is no denying how much better it might have been with an extra screenplay polish and a greater willingness from director Tim Hill to think outside the box.

The film always seems to be on the cusp of locating some bigger truth about one's life and destiny, but this cinematic treatment loses its way by focusing almost solely on a sudsy, perfunctory love triangle.

Sure, it's supposed to just be a silly popcorn movie, but treating these cardboard cutouts as people to admire and care about is dishonest and contemptible. That the movie sucks besides is the final insult.
For a work so seemingly light and straightforward, this is an astonishingly inept, curiously depressing experience.
Like its lead character of Oliver Tate, the film is preoccupied by its own self-consciousness. It means well, but it doesn't care enough.
Meaningful yet told with a light hand, touching yet a little undernourished.
Never forgets that special effects and sheer spectacle mean nothing if there aren't relatable characters and an emotional thematic throughline to first and foremost care about.
Revitalizing the series with fresh blood and new ideas, "X-Men: First Class" is an altogether superior motion picturegrander, better written, and more dramatically sound.
It is no doubt Malick's most ambitious motion picture to date, and, regrettably, his most misguided.
The opening and closing moments of "Midnight in Paris" are visually resplendent. The movie in the middle gets in the way.
Po has yet to receive a film as memorable as himself, but this one will suffice until his next chance for greatness comes along.
As the film goes on its dull, dim-brained, slapdash way, there isn't a solitary laugh in sight. Not one. A person couldn't write worse jokes if he or she tried.
This franchise, like many of the "arrgh!"-spouting pirates who have come before Captain Jack Sparrow, is dead in the water.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A promising, intermittently entrancing film that the viewer wishes could have made more of an impact than it does.
The stylistic angle comes off as a gimmick used to occupy the viewers' attention and keep them from stopping to think about how flimsy the script is.
An irritating, lifeless experience, so bad it sucks the fun right out of moviegoing.

A destined comedy classic that knows how to be crowd-pleasing without sacrificing itself to empty-headed callousness or shoehorned distastefulness. Let's not mince words, either: Kristen Wiig is brilliant.
As equal parts tough, touching and resolute as the renegade saving-grace of the title, "Hesher" is an uncommonly perceptive cinematic revolution.
An example of just how much bang indie filmmakers these days can get with their bucks. Hollywood, are you listening?
Paints a detailed, believable glimpse of the 1980s and has an impressively extensive soundtrack of decade-specific tunes to go with it.
Bland, forgettable, and ultimately too pat to break away from its chains of thorough, pre-fabricated, overly conventional safeness.
Take away the titular gimmick, and the film would be a standard-issue family drama with nothing to set it apart from other oft-told tales of suburban ennui.
Will not be going down anytime soon as one of the quintessentially great superhero efforts, but it isn't a failure, either.
Doesn't always evade the traps of convention, but it is the first film of its kind in a while with an ending that isn't such an obvious foregone conclusion.
May have been made on a tight budget, but one would never know it based on the striking production values director Jim Mickle manages in order to realize his harrowing vision.
Feels strikingly unnecessary. Why watch the same tale spun for a tenth time when you could be watching one of the previous nine?
An entertaining slice of salty life, but ultimately just what its title suggests: merely a peep into a world with greater potential.
If Red State isn't necessarily Kevin Smith's best picture, it most certainly is his best-directed. It's a smart, mature film from a man who, now, has artistically come-of-age.
Sure to remain one of the most spiritless cinematic experiences of the year.
Carries authentic aesthetics, a dread-drenched tone, and provocative food-for-thought ideas involving religious hysteria that prove timely even in the 21st-century.
Just about as inspired as its title.
Can a motion picture overcome a lousy script if it is an otherwise effective, technically proficient piece of filmmaking? Sanctum sure-footedly answers this question in the affirmative.
The planet's annihilation has never been so ineffectual.
What are we supposed to take away from the film? Director Simon West would probably prefer that we not bother to think about it, or anything, at all.

A film that somewhere on its journey from written page to finished product has been stripped of its initially cerebral leanings for a dopey, excessively conventional lighting and effects horror show. There isn't a legitimately scary moment to be found.

The on-screen lovers in questionand the actors portraying themhave a heck of a lot of chemistry, not only with each other but with an ensemble of sparklingly written and well-cast supporting players.
To not give Mary even the smallest of catharses is creatively pretentious, cruel to her and unfair to the audience.
It's clear when a film is being tonally dishonest with itself, and this is what overpowers the positive traits that the film has to offer.
"This is getting to be, like, who cares?" says one character toward the end of "Carnage." They couldn't be more right.
Vanishing on 7th Street is a skillful, compact chiller, unburdened by too many subplots or the tendency to overexplain what is going on.

The first reveal of Nicolas Cage sporting a blond wig with ringlets that makes him look like a Shirley Temple drag queen impersonator after a post-medieval-party-themed blackout is the sort of fright probably not intended by its makers.
Biutiful is an acting tour de force on Javier Bardem's part, wrenching more for his performance than for a story that otherwise seems a little too cluttered, unformed, and familiar.
Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling are better than Blue Valentine as a whole, but one cannot deny the experience rattles with a weary knowledge not easily faked.
So filled with mixed messages, misguided plot turns, and consecutive false denouements that, by the actual end, it finally comes off as nothing but an infuriating betrayal.

In lesser, more obvious hands, it could have become a drippy, manipulative Lifetime movie. Even if there are times when it does threaten to seem like such, writer-director Don Roos and his adroit cast never let it cross over.
Relies on the sympathetic nature of its characters and the raw truthfulness of its story to carry it through the land of overfamiliarity.
Surprisingly not all that painful, but don't fall for the 3D scam.
A maddening, joyless experience, easily one of the most inept films of the year. It's cynical. It's mean-spirited. It's ugly.
So much more than just a study in dusty chestnuts of the Wild West.

Meticulous yet unrestrained, a tone poem of deep, quiet lyricism and frequent flashes of striking brilliance. That rare motion picture that would stay exactly as is were the liberty be given to change anything about it.
Cedar Rapids isn't hard-hitting, but it is wise in its own dippy way, and in Ed Helms' Tim Lippe is a protagonist written with uncommon affection.
Adults will be hoping for more substance, but they won't get it as the skinny plot devotes all its time to frivolous play and increasingly tired slapstick humor.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Adults will be consistently amused by all of the references and in-jokes to the Bard's famed works, while children will learn a little about the original play as they get swept up in the likable characters and fast-paced, heartfelt story.
As a romantic comedy that works as both rom and com, it's a pleasant entertainment with, finally, a nice heart.
An impersonal, borderline-mechanical experience book-ended by the dramatic warmth its middle hour hasn't a speck of.

Shot on chintzy soundstages that look like the sets from "Fraggle Rock," the film doesn't work as horror, as whimsical folk tale, or as a romance. It does, however, work on occasion as bad dinner theatre.

Innocuous but underwritten. An indie romantic comedy-drama that provides the occasional snicker and a low-key level of emotional urgency, the picture nonetheless comes up lacking in both development and charisma.
Barebones and overly literal. With respect to its initial ambition, it's also terribly boring, stretched to the brink at 80 minutes.
For first-time director Michael Greenspan, Wrecked stands as a future calling card to show just how much intrigue and audience involvement he can rile up with such a minimalist plot.
Wry, genial, and not at all interested in jumping on the bandwagon of flash-in-the-pan pop-cultural hipness, "Rango" holds an eclectic eye for finding beauty in the unusual.
A slipshod teen sudser starring 20-year-olds playing 17-year-olds penned as 12-year-olds.
Now here's something you don't see every daya gripping, literate sci-fi film, full of thematic texture, emotional warmth, and existential complexity.
An '80s movie lover's wet dream.
Congenial, to be sure, but also so very subtle that it never becomes more than a confectionary dash of moody pleasantness.
Time and again promises answers and payoffs that do not come. Instead of being enigmatic for a reason, the film feels simply half-formed.
Horror fans will be elated with what could be the bravest slasher effort of the last couple years.
Ceaseless in its goals to devastate, infuriate, nauseate, and finally challenge audiences used to more pandering, watered-down treatments of tragedy and vengeance.
When Cage battles a roomful of bad guys while having sex with a big-breasted waitress and smoking a cigar, it's a highlight that reaffirms the film's auspicious sense of humor.
Noxious in the extreme, growing into an endurance test the longer one has to spend with these two louts posing as protagonists.
A low-budget, underseen genre gem that makes up for occasionally stilted dialogue and unpolished acting with a remarkable visual sense and skillful command of building tension.
A character-centric thriller signifying Mena's progression as a filmmaker even as it doesn't quite retain the same home-grown charm and earnestness of its predecessor.
An exquisitely observed slice-of-life with a genuinely transporting feel for its setting. Sumptuously dreamlike and compellingly elusive.
It would only be respectful to hang up Big Momma's oversized girdle once and for all.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Had passersby been listening through the theater door at the advance screening I attended, they might very well have assumed the audience was watching a comedy rather than the trite, overwrought drama it actually tries to be.
Indistinctive and empty, forced to rely on multiple car chases, fist fights, and a literal ticking time bomb to cover up its lack of ideas.
Movies like this one are a dime a dozen unless the makers bring something a little extra or unusual to the table. When they don't, they end up as ho-hum as The Eagle.
Lifeless, joyless, and a whole lot less than meets the eye. One has to wonder if all these superhero tales were created by way of "Mad Libs."

Relegating the film to January and uselessly converting it into ugly, barely-there 3-D so inadequate it might as well be billed as 2 1/4-D, the studio's decisions contradictorily stink of both desperation and defeat.
Has what it takes to move the viewer, at least sporadically. Boy, though. The rest of it sure is pedestrian.
In other words, the destination is of the take-it-or-leave-it variety. Getting-there, thoughnow that's novel.
Where are Shrek, Fiona andgulpDonkey when you need them?
You know you're in trouble when it takes well over an hour to figure out that the two on-screen figures you've been watching are actually playing the same character forty years apart.

Awesome special effects emulating the terrifying splendor of the end of days collide with an austere portrait of the varying reactions and outlooks that people are apt to experience as they stare death irrefutably in the face.
Excitingly unique, deeply disturbing, and beautifully macabre. Why can't more films be as proudly one-of-a-kind as this one?
If 2011's "The Thing" is not quite 1982's equal, the distance in quality between the two is closer than one has any right to be expecting.
Works as a breezy entertainment that audiences will want to flock to on a Friday night.
As funny as Alzheimer's and as entertaining as catatonia, "The Big Year" is more pet peeve than pastime.
Relies on a mounting atmosphere of slow-burn intensity and an attention to people rather than plot points.
Make no mistake, this little cinematic burst of savagery and bathroom pornography is as balls-out as its predecessor was comparatively restrained.
A thoroughly absorbing thriller that matches its memorable title in sheer foreboding.
It's all very heavy-handed, but maybe kids of about ten to thirteen will be more taken with it.
Juno Temple and Jeremy Dozier are one of the most surprisingly sweet cinematic pairings in some time.

The results are gently sincere but maybe a little misguided, a far cry from the note-perfect, transcendently adorable 1999 gay love story "Trick," which this one reminds ofand pales in comparison to.
A tepid, excitement-free Hallmark telepic dressed up in an A-list thriller's clothing.
It's deeply frustrating, made all the worse since Anna Faris is clearly trying her hardest with substandard material.
An uncompromising gem, the kind of film that hits all the right notes as it navigates from gentle, unforced humor to knowing pathos.
"Abduction" has plenty of problems, and the least of them, as it turns out, is Taylor Lautner.
Make no mistake, "Tucker & Dale vs. Evil" is a total lark, yet it's also very clever. Real thought and ingenuity were brought to its making, and it shows.
It's not about aesthetics, and it's certainly not about people, so the film settles on a lot of chaos and whirring bullets. "Killer Elite" is a waste of time and resources.
It takes a brave studio picture to recognize that there's sometimes more to the sports genre than the common trifles and clichés audiences have been predisposed to expect these days.
Rum is in short supply and a diary might have come in handy to understand who Paul Kemp is beneath the surface. That is, if the viewer had been given a reason to care in the first place.
Curmudgeons could probably pick it apart 'til the cows come home, but "Dolphin Tale" is exceedingly hard to dislike.
This is Eiizabeth Olsen's picture all the way; she is such the captivating centerpiece that everyone else should feel lucky to be in her orbit.

Moves with such a fleet foot, with such know-how in interweaving its many cast members while using each one of them to their strengths, that it pleases and entertains for just about every one of its 104 minutes.
A particularly plain, patly penned picture preoccupied with penguin poop.
Director David Cronenberg has done nothing to vividly bring this story to life. He sets his actors adrift and hopes for the best. The best never comes.
A character study of uncommon originality and perceptiveness with a protagonist as fascinating as nearly any seen in 2011.
There simply isn't enough material to withstand a feature-length running time in between the musical numbers.

Pixar filmmaker Brad Bird tackles his very first live-action feature and, without so much as appearing to break a sweat, ably puts to shame most veteran directors who have made a living in the action genre (that includes you, Michael Bay).
A dreary ordeal.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A crasser but very nearly as sweet unofficial remake of 1987's "Adventures in Babysitting."

[Rating Updated 12/31/15] It may be cornball in spots and pedestrian in others, but it is pure cinematic comfort food that works wonders for the last day of the year. It's fun in spite of its (many) problems.
"Shame" is uncompromising, no doubt, but the picture doesn't add up to as much as the viewer hopes based on the clear talent involved.

"Arthur Christmas" is imaginatively crafted and its computer animation is divine. With its wide-ranging international locations and and seasonal color scheme, watching the film once doesn't quite seem like enough.
When so many movies can't even exact one strong emotion from viewers, here is a motion picture that frustrates, haunts and fascinates in equal measure.
Extravagant but unpretentious, a touching fable with a thoughtful message and eye candy galore. It's one of the year's richest entertainments.

Less irreverent than it should be and, during the home stretch, not as spirited and momentous as one hopes. Reacquainting audiences to the charms of hand puppets, however, is a victory in and of itself.
Is there anything Michelle Williams cannot do?
Only the series' bread and butterthe song-and-dance performancesare able to occasionally buoy the flagging energy. When the music stops, "Happy Feet Two" flounders.
Tough, touching and unsentimental, Payne's low-key hymn to loving, losing and learning to move on is a pleasing addition to an impressive oeuvre.
Stretches forty-five minutes of material to two hours in order to satisfy the ignorant two-parter conclusion.
An impeccably dressed yawnfest.
Jack and Jill isn't awful or particularly successful. It is, however, the curiosity piece expected, totally undemanding and just bizarre enough in concept to keep one's interest up.
This is not quite the be-all, end-all biopic of J. Edgar Hoover that prospective viewers were expecting, or at least hoped for.

Perhaps this viewer has become a victim of desensitization, but what might have come off as shocking a decade or less ago now has a bland, "been-there-done-that" air to it. It's definitely not the gut-buster it thinks it is.
A beautiful love story wrapped in a hasty, too-rigid structure. Who knows what an extra half-hour might have bought the filmmakers.
Pleasant but consistently rather bland, a light, low-key Lifetime movie with an A-list star and wide theatrical distribution.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One-ups both of the previous films in quality and quantity of its scares.
In a year of near-perpetual ennui at the multiplex, "Drive," at long last, is a real, true, passionate motion picture to replenish a doubting cinema lover's soul.
Falls victim to self-indulgence now and again, yes, but there is also an empathy Miranda July exhibits toward all her on-screen creations that cannot be faked.
Dodging easy melodrama and preferring to focus on the little moments that stay with us in our memories through the years, the picture's low-key indelibility sneaks up on the audience.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film, finally, locates a certain solace, a propensity for hope and empathy. In finding someone else, it finds itself.
Too goofy to be frightening and too lame to be funny or amusing, the picture ultimately turns into an interminable waste of time.
As meticulous and deliberate as the narrative is early on, it is just as clumsy and ineffectual in the second half.
The characters do not feel like archetypes of the romantic comedy genre, but like people as authentic as you and I.
Won't be an awards contender anytime soon, but it is altogether sweetly smurfier than anyone could have predicted.
In a summer that seemingly has seen a new comic book adaptation every other week, it's a toss-up whether "Captain America: The First Avenger" or "Green Lantern" is the weakest of the bunch.
Mediocre more than an utter failure, "Friends with Benefits" ought to be forgotten in the shadow of the smarter, funnier, sweeter, and altogether superior "No Strings Attached."

Like a sensationalistic flavor-of-the-month crime or Hollywood scandal, the film is sure to capture the viewer's attention while it plays out, but is just as destined to lose its luster the second the saga in question has run its course.
It's a charmer, yes, but let's just say it has none of the nostalgic emotion of its wonderful, somewhat misleading trailer.
The best was saved for last.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There is a charming film to be made that casts Rosario Dawson opposite Kevin James, treating them both as free-thinking, interesting, three-dimensional people with legitimate wants, dreams and desires as they fall in love. "Zookeeper" is not that movie.
Whether it might have meant delving into grimmer thriller territory or bending toward more courageously incendiary humor, the finished cut screams out for a clearer, firmer, fuller vision.
Ringing true fairly consistently and lingering afterwards even in its lightness, the film doesn't have to try to please. It just does.
"Don't mess with Texas!" Emma snarls at the captive Cordelia, the girl tied to a chair with an apple lodged in her mouth. Yes, it's as unclean and creepily disconcerting as it sounds.

Transformers: Dark of the Moon cannot be recommended when all is said and done. Considering how much more disastrous it could have been, however, this is one instance where two stars is almost something to celebrate.
Watching it is like gazing upon a plagiarized essay; no matter how good its content might be, it doesn't take away the knowledge that it was just copied over from someone else's paper.
As appalling as any motion picture released so far in 2011. Ruthlessly betrays every last thing the original so passionately stood for.
More a grim, crafty exercise rather than anything deeper, but it still delivers the desired impact.
The film's depiction of a married couple in emotional peril rings true rather than maudlin, sustained at a riveting pitch through the consummately raw, sympathetic performances of its two leads.
Blue and bawdy as all get-out, but it turns out this is just a ruse for the heart hiding underneath.
Should be commended for following the apocalyptic plot threads to their logical destination.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: When the end arrives at the 89-minute mark the immediate reaction is that it was too slight by a half and a lot safer than expected.
Atrocious is far from tops in the annals of 'found-footage' thrillers, but it does know how to wrestle with expectations and ratchet suspense when it gets down to it.

The film is so tightly written, the characters so well developed and the execution so perfect that if Loach retired from filmmaking tomorrow, this heartbreaking working class film would be a fitting coda... to a career that has been firm in its mission.
Though comedy/satire is not his strong suit, Michod succeeds with the action scenes, or formal official banquets sequences.
Nicely done. Warm-hearted. The film's aura sticks with you.
It misses the mark as a major theatrical jazz documentary like I Called Him Morgan. But within its own specific genre, this film is illuminating.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Niki Caro orchestrates the proceedings with a very sensitive eye that never wavers.

Retracing Muhammad Ali's vibrant life is an opportunity for audiences to reexamine American history, race relations, the civil rights movement, the antiwar movement and the sports world through the eyes of a perceptive black man.
At only 75 minutes long, you question whether the better medium might have been cable TV or VOD and not a theatrical release.
Pathetic on just about every level.
Brilliant. Historic. Compelling.
What the documentary the filmmakers have assembled is educational, eye opening, often emotional, sad and galvanizing.
Credit a smart script, smarter direction, excellent production elements and an unflappable leading man for taking you to hell and back -- over and over again.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Earnest performances by Morris Chestnut and Monica Calhoun anchor the film.
Michael B. Jordon honed his talent on series like The Wire and Friday Night Lights. His performance seems natural but that doesn't mean it was easy to achieve. It's subtle, deep and fiery.
If this sequel is guilty of anything it is of flaunting total excess in the name of comedy.
This is a smart blend of cop drama, thriller and paranormal elements.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is still the best big budget summer movie of 2014.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Black Nativity is a jubilant experience.
Warts and all, in fits and starts, finally the Hardest Working Man in Show Business gets his story told.
Top Five gives us a glimpse of [Rock's] comic genius. Just a tad.
'You have ugly talents,' George says, almost admiringly, to Martha. So does this movie.
By its midpoint, however, Thornton has begun forcing both the film's poetry and the preternatural goodness of its simple-minded protagonist, and Sling Blade's sweet charms begin to curdle.
It's the story of good white actors stranded, in the name of noir, in a movie that refuses to kick into gear until it's far too late.
The Orphanage is a visceral and well-crafted horror film that goes for the heart as well as the mind.
This results in an adaptation that should be an exciting film of revenge and redemption, but feels like a quirky slog of a chambara film that we've seen before, but with extra blood.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Edge of Tomorrow] may not be as smart as it could've been in the broad strokes, but a clever, well-acted thrill ride like this doesn't really need to have its head fully in the game, now does it?
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Horse is loaded with heavy subject matter, but it's engrossing and sure to make moviegoers recoil, cry, and even laugh on occasion.
As if to make up for the predictable main plot, The Perfect Match is bogged down with a slew of uninteresting B-stories.
Field proves more than capable of delivering Showalter-level goofiness while giving the film its heart.

Cernan knows how to spin a great yarn, and if you do zone out for a moment, he can quickly reel you back in with the time he nearly died on his Gemini 9 mission or the surprisingly fierce politics behind his being chosen for the Apollo 10 crew.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chow and his actors present a full-force farce. Sure, some jokes fall flat, but the sheer magnitude of ridiculousness has you forgetting about that soon afterwards.
Lazer Team may not be a necessarily fresh story, but an energetic cast and some unique sci-fi ideas make it a fun little movie to check out for fans of the genre.
A historically respectful, morally careful film.
Grant McPhee's Night Kaleidoscope has solid visuals and frequent bursts of great cinematography, sadly this is not enough to cover up its paper thin characters and story.
It is exceedingly difficult to recommend Alien: Covenant. The inert dialogue and fatuous narrative leave the film feeling rather redundant.
Too often do jokes fall flat for Deny Everything to be a truly successful comedy, and the lack of character development makes it hard to care about the overall narrative.
Paris Can Wait is not only the worst film I've seen at the Edinburgh International Film Festival but it is also one of the worst films I've seen in a cinema.
Bad Day for The Cut is a Northern Irish revenge film that, despite feeling somewhat predictable, is solidly entertaining.
God's Own Country is a contender for the best film I've seen this year.
Double Date is a fantastically entertaining comedy, that had me laughing from beginning to end.
The Last Photograph features some fantastic performances and interesting elements, though this is not enough to make up for its sloppy editing and uneven script.
The Dark Mile is a confusing and empty horror film that is completely lacking in any substance.
Predictable, overbearing, and generic, Ghost House is a film that is lacking in all the essential ingredients that make up a great horror.
Be Afraid is a dull, repetitive slog that does absolutely nothing original or interesting.
The type of work that requires patience for the quiet intersections and confrontations of simple lives.
An utterly delightful film you can't help but smile at.
A sweet but familiar coming-of-age tale.
An infectiously sweet, lovely tale about two young people who bring out the best and most hidden sides of each other.
Nocturnal Animals doesn't have much substance, but its dazzling style is hard to completely resist.
A biopic best described as 'nice,' though thankfully its lead performances make it worth the while.
A masterpiece of poetic filmmaking, Moonlight is one of the most powerful films of the year.
A film that slowly sneaks up on you, imbued with such quiet emotions that you don't feel its full weight and beauty until it ends.
Unafraid to expose her character's weaknesses and degradation, White Girl establishes Wood as a brazen new talent to watch.
Snowden is nothing more than rabid cinematic cheerleading that's too consumed with Stone's own praise to actually make us care.
Pure and simple, Catfight is a total blast.
It shirks the typical Disney model of an untouchable, picturesque fantasy by telling a more grounded, human story coursing with love and earnestness.
Masterminds stars some of the funniest names in comedy. Too bad the movie isn't funny.
A cheap exploitation of the horrors of alcoholism, depression, and domestic abuse that thinks it's much smarter and artsier than it is.

Lee's intimate visual style brings us closer to the rawness of his characters, but the realistic look exposes the artifice of filmmaking. Watching Billy Lynn feels like watching actors making a movie.
Rowling and Yates succeed at transporting you to a magical world you don't want to leave.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of observing its historical subject from behind a glass case, Jackie offers a piercing portrait of a woman's psychological and emotional journey.
The most beautiful accomplishment of Ross' inspiring Captain Fantastic is in questioning how we evaluate parenting and how to prepare children for the world.
Too removed and too safe to leave a lasting impression.
Rules Don't Apply could have been an insightful look at a tragic, troubled figure. Instead Beatty made a conventional romance with lead characters we hardly care about.
What Lowery's remake does best is convey classic Disney magic in a family film that's as uplifting for kids as it is for adults.
[The Secret Life of Pets] achieves what it aims to be: cute, clever, and pleasantly enjoyable.
The moments when the movie puts the audience into the freakish environment of its characters are its most fun, and best experienced in a theater with loud speakers.
While a reunion between Greengrass and Damon should feel like a refreshing extension of the franchise, Jason Bourne is just another replica, and an unnecessary one.
The real problem with Free State of Jones  isn't that it plays like a dull history special, but how it tells its story with ignorance and colorblindness.
[Redmayne] emanates an emotional urgency in Lili with a potent mix of confusion, pain and longing that oozes from his every mannerism.
Fukunaga's visual knack for wading into dark, perilous atmospheres to capture the trauma that haunts his characters comes to full fruition in Beasts of No Nation.
The Walk's walk quickly becomes tasteless, making a mockery of a spectacular feat.
A love story of sublime subtlety where the smallest encounters have the most consuming impact.
When Truth falters, it's Blanchett's unyielding, captivating force that keeps it alive.

A bunch of bizarre-for-the-sake-of-being-imaginative stuff happens in The Last Witch Hunter, much of it making little sense, and some of it that probably made sense but I hadn't the energy to figure it out.
As grey and lifeless as the lethargic pedestrians wandering through the London streets.
Crowley's unpretentious drama has a sensitivity for its protagonist's emotional journey that's richly rewarding throughout.
Trumbo's biggest misstep is in sacrificing an aura of authenticity for gaudiness in its attempts to capture an unsavory era of American filmmaking.
Although sprinkled with some good scenes, The Night Before falls short of bridging the gap between adult humor and family Christmas comedies.
There's a lot of good actors in this movie, but they're given so little to do besides run around and shout in the midst of splashing waves.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Daddy's Home is the white bread of family comedies, stuffed with everything you've seen before.
One of the most enjoyably bizarre, confounding and visually inspired movie-watching experiences.

Passengers goes from having a clever premise to an unethical one that romanticizes stalking in a Stockholm Syndrome love story, and somehow the ending is even worse than everything that comes before it.
Both an accomplishment in introspective, transcendent filmmaking, and a puzzle as imbalanced as the knight at its center.
We've heard this story before, but a refreshing sense of humor and a stellar performance from actress-comedian Jessica Williams brings Jim Strouse's film to life.
A magnificent look at the freewheeling wonder of childhood.
Though admittedly daring, Aronofsky's latest is a self-indulgent melting pot exploding with too many ideas. It's enthralling, and frustrating.
A blisteringly funny and sympathetic portrait of the Olympian led by an outstanding, confident performance from Margot Robbie.
Has the deceptive appearance of a quirky Charlie Kaufman-like sci-fi political tale, but it wastes its brilliant concept on a misguided, uninteresting story.
Del Toro made a masterpiece that will remind you what you love about the movies.
A quirky little movie that takes its whimsical, embrace-your-inner-kid metaphor much too seriously.
Suffers from sluggish pacing, but proves Cruise is still a good movie star.
Shia LaBeouf's John McEnroe, a firecracker of energy and anxiety waiting to burst at every moment, is the film's strongest asset as it continues to sideline him.
If Netflix gives us one 'Meyerowitz'-level performance for every bad Adam Sandler movie, then that four-picture deal wasn't a total loss.
If Wonder Wheel ended with the reveal that everything we'd just watched was the first draft of a bad play by Timberlake's lifeguard, perhaps you could call it a success.
A giant Kenneth Branagh vanity project.
Don't get me wrong, the Hugh Jackman-led P.T. Barnum circus musical is a bad movie, but one that's just enjoyably bad enough to keep you entertained.
Kasdan's film could've just been any generic survivalist action-comedy; slapping the board game onto the title is nothing but shameless branding.
At best, a schlock sci-fi movie that has the quality of a straight-to-video sequel. And at worst, it should have us worried about the direction of the Cloverfield franchise as a whole.
It's all so dumbfounding it makes you wonder: Did Eastwood even, like, show up on set and direct this thing?
A tender, introspective film you'll want to pull in close, hold tight, and keep with you.
A fine directorial debut from Serkis, but far from a memorable one.
A uniquely exhilarating experience with a sharp, unflinching style and a magnetic performance from Robert Pattinson.

Is Kidnap inane? Totally. But fun? You bet.
It's Cory Finley's sleek and stylish visual language that makes Thoroughbred a must-see, and one of the best surprises out of Sundance.

Mudbound may be set over 70 years ago, but its layered and affecting approach to race, love, and family feels especially relevant - and necessary - today.
Any of Guadagnino's cinematic trips to sunny Italy are worth taking, but Call Me By Your Name may be his most tender and sumptuous work yet.

We rarely see a major studio give a director this much free rein, and it's a relief to see something this wacky that's not a remake, reboot, or adaptation.

Like a fine wine or a stinky cheese, Winterbottom's The Trip movies have only gotten more mature with age, and Spain is the most thoughtful one yet.
Valerian is easily Besson at his most imaginative since The Fifth Element, creating a canvas that's bursting with originality. This is world building at its finest.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Girls Tripisn't just notable for its foul-mouthedsense of humor; it tells a story that celebrates black sisterhood, female sexuality, and most rewardingly, self-respect.

Ultimately, all this makes Justice League the superhero movie some fans feel they deserve but not the one other fans needed-especially fans who prefer their tales to grow with them.
The film, like its likeable heroes, struggles to find its own sense of significance in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and its titular saved "galaxy" is left with little gravity or sense of place.

movie_review_blurb: An absolute pleasure from beginning to end.

A serviceable although not exceptional place-setter.

movie_review_blurb: Salinger triumphs, though, as an absorbing portrait of a singular man of mystery.

movie_review_blurb: And Still I Rise mostly soars, though, on the wings of Maya Angelou's own words and recollections. She lived a multifaceted life for the ages, overcoming a wealth of indignities while also rising above her own considerable faults and frailties.
