Given its poetic nuances, it's a shame the film succumbs to cliché.
While it opens a rare window into an unconventional life, this portrait of an artist as an old woman is prone to strange distractions.
Exterminating Angels is Jean-Claude Brisseau's Sex is Comedy, though it could just as easily have been called Anatomy of Hell.
The best thing that can be said about Breach is that it isn't directed by Tony Scott.
Gray Matters is as unhinged as its characters.

Instead of reinventing the procedural mechanics of the serial-killer drama, filmmaker Christian Alvert adds to its current state of retardation with desperate atmospherics and a cheap disquisition on sex and religion.
Bridge to Terabithia is a film most children should see, but it's so dully aestheticized they may not care to.
If this film was intended as a joke, consider me fooled.
Together, filmmaker and subject pave a symbolic path toward healing that is an inspiration to us all.
There are worse things than death to look forward to, like having to sit through The Barbarian Invasions a second time.
Peter Schønau Fog's Danish hot-potato The Art of Crying is a failure, mostly for its desperate sense of trying.
movie_title: The Art of Crying (Kunsten at græde i kor) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Better than the film's soap-operatic flashbacks, familiar slogs through Cautiva terrain, are the story's playful, unpretentious observations of culture-clash and assimilation.

This groovy little film is spiked with an arresting, hyper-saturated mix of sadness and joy.
Maxed Out is more ambitious than Morgan Spurlock's egotistical Super Size Me, but its also more scatterbrained.
... toothless caprice ...
Alexis Dos Santos's artful doodle about a boy and his seething hormones in Argentina's dreary Patagonia region that recalls some of the seminal works of the New Queer Cinema movement.
The film is so opulently and noisily aestheticized it gives the illusion of being smarter than it is, though it benefits from some endearing performances.
In 1964, the film's innuendo might have seemed daring; today it's close to ridiculous.
Courtesy of Catherine Hardwicke, The Nativity has become the most boring story ever told.
This sensualist delight is an immaculate expression of the thrill of the hunt and the cruel damage our hearts of glass incur from an unexpected loss or missed opportunity.
movie_title: En la Ciudad de Sylvia (In the City of Sylvia) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Reminiscing in Tempo is simply not in sync with its subject matter.

The film has an excellent pedigree, but when it poops it stinks of a Tim Allen movie.
Mel Gibson is sick, but his new film profits from his weakness.
Try to phase out the redundant and uninspired political discourse and focus only on the sporadic bursts of robot aggression, which McKenney shoots at gloriously odd, jumpy angles.
More than 40 years old, François Truffaut's whirling dervish remains an ageless beauty.

Ostensibly the untold story of the birth of the C.I.A., Robert De Niro's film is really the most mundane psychological profile of the year.
Trekkies believe in a curse on odd-numbered Star Trek movies. I have a theory that every other Claude Chabrol production sucks.
It hurts to rag on something with such a micro-budget, but writer-director Paul Bojack's overlay of stories runs on empty.

movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film does not benefit from the great power of contrast that was central to the superior Mardi Gras: Made in China, but it's crucial for its very methodical study of life inside a sweatshop.

movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A multi-layered demonstration of living in almost perfect harmony.
movie_title: Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World (2007)

The documentary never finds the appropriate rhythm to match the severity of its subject matter.
Jacobs Jr. gives us a film perched somewhere between the realistic solipsism of Mutual Attraction and the insufferable quirk of Garden State.

Tom Tykwer's Perfume stinks.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Prone to poetic abstraction and exuding a magical-realist's reverence for history.
Stylish, violent, and often dull Batman adventure.
A flashy movie that's more like a video game.
A darkly violent take on the comic-book hero.
This gimmicky animal tale is crude but funny.
Witty, action-packed superadventure with big themes.
Old fashioned cartoon mayhem.
Super-nostalgic superhero adventure still soars.
Deceptively adult movie is fun, but not for kids.
Pure, sweet imagination for both kids and adults.

movie_review_blurb: 1960s flick won't appeal to today's kids.
A smart, charismatic Superman retelling.
movie_title: Superman: The Last Son of Krypton  (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Same bat-time, same bat-movie.
A slow starter which builds into a chilling depiction of the agonising disintegration of body and mind as they are exposed to the elements.

movie_review_blurb: If only there were drugs strong enough to make it all bearable.
movie_title: Carlos Castaneda: Enigma of a Sorcerer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sordid beatings, joyless sex, and a sullen synth score create the air of a home-brewed '60s sexploitation-noir flick, or a pre-Stonewall pulp homosexual novel, complete with narrative clichés and the occasional bit of ugly beauty.

Indiscriminately shot, set to insufferably caffeinated trip-hop, and edited with the superficial pep of a television magazine show, Let's Get Frank conveys its congressional star as a personality, but not quite a character.
Offers little that is not also explored in current agit-docs like Fahrenheit 9/11, The Corporation, or Outfoxed.
Undeniably entertaining and eye-opening, Outfoxed shows how Fox works, but not why.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Perfunctory battle sequences, cardboard characters, and uncreative scare 'ems.
This unwarranted iteration of the '70s shaggy-dog tale pales in entertainment value compared to its website, which features a rant from the mutt's creator, Joe Camp.
A corny hodgepodge of gooey sentiment mixed with half-baked mush and strained pieties.
Spins a tripartite tale around familiar Bollywood obsessions, here reinfused with new life via clever use of a Pulp Fiction structure.
Hits just the right balance of pop and political.

movie_review_blurb: A lovingly overblown piece of terrorist-chic trashfilm.
Relentless, pretentious tedium.
movie_title: Georges Bataille's Story of the Eye (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Though the Pioneer is reviving this picture's original barf-bag-at-the-door promo gimmick, there's about a 50 percent chance it'll be more useful to save it for watching the returns on Election Night.

[A] complex and deeply moving documentary of Catholics at prayer, who remarkably speak to the camera as they do to God.
Anakin's defection from Jediism to Sithdom should provide the film's backbone, but neither the script nor Christensen delivers the needed nuance.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Taylor Mead traipses with elfin glee through a lost San Francisco of smoke-stuffed North Beach cafés, oceanside fairgrounds, and collapsed post-industrial ruins.
Streaky low-frame-rate DV, Dogme-style mundane interiors, and merely unembarrassing televisual performances add up to a monotonous, unenlightening experience.
Provides a therapeutic laugh for liberal audiences whose mouth corners have long been turned downward by the plumb bobs of reality.
The film's witlessness keeps any satirical potential submerged well below soap opera levels.
movie_title: Adored: Diary of a Porn Star (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A ridiculous macho slugfest attempting to reassert the '80s-style roid-raging revenge narrative.
Posits its working-class supporters not as protagonists but consumers, cheering on their just-folks race-car heroes for proxy fantasies of high-speed escape and high-tech goodies.
The format gets used best ... to capture the dizzying heights achieved by motocross and BMX riders, whose balletic hotdogging occasionally ends in bone-crushing screwups.
It offers little beyond the momentary joys of pretty and weightless intellectual entertainment.
A keen, gripping psychodrama with unsettling real-life underpinnings.
Sven Nykvist's golden-hued cinematography perfectly suits Hesse's mind-expanding narrative of Buddhist enlightenment.
It's funny, as the old saying goes, because it's true.
Squanders the cross-cultural comedy potential of a Jewish-themed Christmas movie on cheap fart gags and boilerplate schmaltz.
Sensitive and stimulating documentary.
movie_title: Rivers and Tides: Andy Goldsworthy Working With Time (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The results are neither the touchy-feely do- goodism nor Dogmatic dementia one might fear.
A deft, ambitious exercise in old-school socialist agitprop crafted with the precise multimedia flair of a corporate PowerPoint presentation.
[A] draggy, visually underwhelming portrait of contemporary surf culture.
Ultimately, it's a Hollywood science fiction plot wrapped around a traditional boy-meets-girl Bollywood core, and the song-and-dance numbers are for the most part merely serviceable.
Serves up a gripping look at skate history through an investigation of one of its darker moments.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A logo-laden celebration of the joys of sponsorship wrapped inside an innocuous teen-pic package.
Hough's doc never rises above the level of first-year student project, hobbled by scattershot editing, badly written intertitles, and useless directorial voice-over.
Old annoying ethnic family stereotypes meet new annoying gay-relationship stereotypes in this candidate for Kiss Me Guido's heretofore uncontested niche.
Pretty much everything here -- tow surfing, hydrofoil boards, token bit on women surfers -- already appeared in this summer's equally halfass Step Into Liquid.
A dizzy time capsule of proto-revolutionary anarchy, like bits of youthful, energetic innocence frozen in the snowdrifts of time.
Atlas's remarkable moving-picture- book tribute to Bowery.
Pilots its culture-challenging raison d'être through an increasingly insufferable collection of gaysploitation conventions.
Weiss and Speck never make a convincing case for the relevance of these two 20th-century footnotes.
movie_title: Escape to Life: The Erika and Klaus Mann Story (2002)

movie_review_blurb: No uplifting populism here.
It's unclear whether this is an actual issue, or just something spicy to be cooked up in the potboiler.
Despite the tale's dusty pedigree, Ron Howard spins a ticket-worthy two-plus hours of movie-movie entertainment.
Though occasionally striking, the footage doesn't pack the evocative punch Herzog intends, and segments that should be lyrical mind trips only result in overstretched longueurs.
The trauma is real, and the facts disturbing, but the doc doesn't have the chops to deliver what should be a more powerful statement.
Varda transforms the typical French cinema gamine into a complex, tragic figure: the girl who's all too good at playing plaything, forced to face the hollowness of her youth.

movie_title: Bergman Island (Ingmar Bergman - 3 dokumentärer om film, teater, Fårö och livet av Marie Nyreröd) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A micro-doc packing more intoxicating beauty and invigorating ideas into its 17 minutes than most other films do in 90 or more.
It's a noble experiment in pushing the limits of cinema, but Tykwer never achieves true profundity.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Neither profound nor funny, but merely uncomfortable. A hubristic failure at risky humor, The Tiger and the Snow provides Benigni his own Michael Richards moment.
movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A noble experiment in pushing the limits of cinema, but one too many sequences of ruffling silks and dreamy flower bouquets evoke little more than the ad-agency clichés of an elongated Chanel No. 5 commercial.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Roberto Benigni here plays out a madcap tale of romantic obsession against the backdrop of the Iraq invasion. The results are neither profound nor funny.
movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though the film never transcends its own neo-boho quirk, it concludes in a marvelous final shot: a long take set to Gang of Four, grungy and materialist in the Jacobs tradition.

It's easy to understand why this was Herzog's final collaboration with the actor, but Kinski's performance nevertheless serves up a potent confusion of documentary and fiction that has long been an essential element of Herzog's filmmaking.
Smith's own work, here montaged for easy digestion, is already too rich and sumptuous to require any further frosting.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Shadow Company attempts to provide a balanced view of a potentially polarizing issue, interviewing historians, security firm heads, war journalists, and former contractors themselves (the Army declined).
Lang's impossibly vast skyscraper-ziggurats (inspired, it's said, by his first view of the Manhattan skyline) are the blueprint for nearly every science-fiction movie city of the past 30 years.

The exceptional cast -- Vaughn, Giamatti, Kathy Bates, Kevin Spacey, Rachel Weisz -- is an embarrassment of riches for a script this thin and this beholden to family-fare protocol, with its mushy-minded moral and slick sentimentality.
An elegant and powerful treatise on rural feudalism that crossed over from the New Indian Cinema's government-sponsored purview into commercial success.
It tries to hold a mirror up to humanity, but merely provides a romp through a forest of empty signifiers.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This crude revision of Barnum as a white able-bodied savior-a kind of Oskar Schindler of the sideshow-is particularly in bad taste considering the far more unsavory historical realities.
Leaner and sharper than its fast-and-furious TV spots would let on.
Though Out of Place uses quotations from Said's writings to frame its chapters, the result is less a picture of Said himself than of the environments that shaped him.
movie_title: Out of Place: Memories of Edward Said (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though physically weakened and near the end of his life, his discourse is sharp and incisive, creating a remarkably compelling self-portrait.
Critics have rightfully hailed Tarr as one of filmdom's criminally undersung geniuses.
Yilmaz Arslan's hard-edged story of Turks and Kurds on the mean streets of urban Germany veers between moments of sensitive humanism and horrifying brutality.
Burns argues for a cogitating, agitating Warhol: deep thinker, cultural barometer, and world changer.
It fails to deliver the narrative thrill twists its origins would promise.
If we're going to be fighting the war on terror in perpetuity, could we at least get better movies out of it?

A photographic Homer of his own odyssey, Mekas journeys -- like us all -- in irrevocable exile from his own past, attempting to reconstruct that invisible nation of youth to which he can never return.

Part wacky comedy (with plenty of jailhouse humping), part existential allegory, Pound betrays its stage-play roots with too much actorly grandstanding but is peppered with ecstatic funk-powered freak-outs.

Unfortunately, what could have been a superficially amusing IFC reality series was stretched into a thin, overlong feature that follows the rocky integration of this very New York clan into a somewhat ruffled island society.
[A] subtle, elegant documentary.
movie_title: William Eggleston in the Real World (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A virtuoso narrative loop-the-loop that travels through a phantasmagoric catalog of animation styles.
A dreamlike travelogue that transforms a mundane world into something strange and new.
[A] well-wrought investigation of the often mysterious life of Edgar G. Ulmer.
movie_title: Edgar G. Ulmer: The Man Off-Screen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [The film] falls in line with the celebratory doc fare often found at gay film festivals: sub-TV production values, middling archival footage, and a hesitancy to separate history from nostalgia in the course of enshrining the first-person record.

[Yule] reveals a struggle far more complicated, suggesting that the manic entanglement of human relationships can't always conform to the winner-loser narratives that the lawyer-driven court system demands.
movie_title: The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Time We Killed achieves a quiet power through rough-edged, handcrafted means.

Thomas Allen Harris's Twelve Disciples of Nelson Mandela takes on an intensely dramatic topic -- the struggle against apartheid -- yet paradoxically transforms its powerful source material into a stiff and sometimes awkward tutorial.

Kyle Henry's Room is one of those rare American indies that confidently and successfully propose their own narrative logic, drawing viewers into a mental puzzle that may not contain a single clear solution.

Few of the interviews get much further than recording surface boasts and assertive self-definitions; LaChapelle connects all their stories with common threads of resisting gang culture, but at the expense of flattening out each person's character.

This picture remains faithful to the underlying affability of both Chappelle and Gondry, orchestrating a feel-good homestyle vibe that, while peppered with moments of sly political commentary, never harshes its own, slightly bittersweet mellow.
Surely a figure as crucial as Geldzahler deserves more incisive treatment.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An unsatisfying marriage of excessive production values with insipid cinematography and flat-footed editing.
Well executed but ultimately unsatisfying ...
[Hinds] carries it easily, but it's impossible to escape the sense that Banville's work is best experienced on paper.
The exquisitely photographed landscapes pull you out of your living room and into the grandeur of the West.

Bouquet and Auteuil inhabit their characters believably and turn in resonant performances.

Arguably one of the funnier and more heartfelt of the [crime movie] genre to come along of late.
Has a rich, 'lived-in' texture that gives the narrative a credibility not based merely on its actuality but on the conviction with which it is presented.

A genuine love/hate portrait of Kinski that acknowledges his acting talent but doesn't hesitate to capture his notorious behavior.

Bears some resemblance to All About My Mother, but lacks its compatriot's flamboyance, content to traffic in glib banalities and unwitting self-absorption.
Yuki's streamlined revenge story (the furious, elegant choreography is by HK maestro Donnie Yen) has in its modest dimensions a surprising grace.
The amped-up Dickian scenario features too many frame-filling fireballs.
The change in tone, from swiftly destabilizing drama to outright fantasy, feels less like Kim provocatively switching gears, and more like he's painted himself into a corner.
Marred by a rambling voice-over at one end and a pat therapeutic resolution on the other, the film has a nice half-hour patch somewhere in the middle.
The let's-travel-through-the-TV-screen sequence was better in Fat Albert.
Feels contrived.
Bigger lopes along endlessly, a no-surprises foray into backstage high jinks and the notion of life as the best acting coach there is.
Most of the action is tedious, and the less you pay attention to the dialogue, the less you'll feel your hand inadvertently twitching as if with joystick.
Despite a fairly explicit lesbian boobfest (projected attendance just went up!), the film is more good-natured than provocative.
Several sharp jolts give the doc its dramatic shape, and one episode in particular, caught with a neighbor's lens, will make you gasp with grief.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Exasperating Southern-lit seminar.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The overall approach is to throw preordained movie sequences (rap number, shopping spree) together and hope for the best.
Jessica Yu's elegant new doc In the Realms of the Unreal is a spry, creative response to his oceanic talent and claustrophobic life.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: So true to its title that I've forgotten many of the details already -- and I just saw it this morning.
National Treasure gets more entertaining as the preposterousness rises.
Could SpongeBob, all gangly goodwill and ice cream appetite, be the anarchic savior for our stressed-out times?

Chad Friedrichs's doc has too many rock-crit talking heads, too often saying the same thing based on scant information -- a clumsy portrait of the artist that inadvertently serves as a mirror of the critical faculty itself.
Vigorously pushes the supernatural line throughout, but unfortunately its final movement is so incoherent that the whole thing collapses.

Unnervingly smooth, mouths moving in strange, even frightening formations, the Polar people are the least convincing things on-screen, glaring impostors amid the otherwise painstakingly rendered scenery.
Patient and fascinated, but never succumbing to abstraction.
Though the film lacks some of the paper incarnation's subtlety, Dai's infidelity to his own text keeps things interesting.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Blame Freaky screenwriters Heather Hach and Leslie Dixon for the yellow-peril fantasies, and instead curl up with Rodgers's novel and its sequel, A Billion for Boris, which remain eminently enjoyable today.

Opening with a bravura wedding sequence and ending with a sycophantic bow to a replaced telephone receiver, the film has its longueurs, but Mifune's buttoned-down avenger is a compelling portrait of righteous obsession foundering on unpredictable reality.
movie_title: The Warui yatsu hodo yoku nemuru (The Bad Sleep Well) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: Number derives sleek hysteria from its audaciously constraining narrative strategy.

Superbly acted (especially by bone-thin Farrow and Ruth Gordon as the ultimate neighbor from hell), it's a satantango in the land of Is-this-real-or-am-I-crazy?, with a luridly literal ending that doesn't negate the previous, more interior terrors.
It's an astringently cynical take on official history, with Warren Beatty as a muckraker investigating the strange aftershocks of a senator's killing.
Enthusiastically scored to the titular quiet storms, ersatz c&w, and hip-hop textures, the anti-rockist Slow Jam King is more fun to listen to than watch...
Nathalie is intricate, provocative, cleanly acted, but it's never entirely convincing -- and never more so than in the table-turning climax.
Fun and nourishing, Charlie's the topsy-turvy equivalent of a three-course dinner in a single stick of gum.
A gratifying playground of high-wire language.
Irredeemably dull.
To this viewer and reader, the decade-old juggernaut is as deeply felt as it is flawed, dense and illogical and laudably weird.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A whimsical success of a very high order: The pace never lags, the invention is incessant, and it makes you want to have a bite of cheese afterward.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: We're going to trot out the mandatory one-word Beatles-album-derived closer: Help!
The Baxter nods to better-behaved comedies of the past.
One leaves the film with the Twilight Zone sense that the place isn't quite the hellhole prior reports have suggested.
Ralph Walker is no Max Fischer, and his monomania gets dull fast.
Syd's emotional tailspin is embarrassingly banal, and his assertion that 'everybody here hates me' quickly applies to the audience as well.
Razor-walking self-consciousness (or just plain braininess) is perhaps impossible to depict coherently on-screen, and the someone's-watching-me vibe is otherwise overfamiliar to moviegoers.
The multiple story lines can feel choppy, but the dialogue has snap, and the pants' powers never distract from the teenagers' emotions.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Stella Street goes from can-I-laugh- yet? to wanna-go- home in about three minutes.
Has characters explain transparent motivations, to convince the gullible that the feelings here are real.
Emphatically acted, ponderous, and ultimately a little silly.
Russell is terrific as coach Herb Brooks.
Christensen and most of the young men are barely there.

Adapted from the 1949 memoir by two children of pioneering efficiency experts Frank and Lilliann Gilbreth, the film now has a title that doesn't really make sense, but it gets modern-day mileage for its even more improbable premise.
Airlessly melodramatic, full of moral brow-furrowing.
C'est la 'B'! Timeline is crudely written, haphazardly acted, and improbably fun.
[A] wan Christmas concoction.
Based-on- a-true-story kitschfest.
Returner might work best if one could sub its soundtrack of r&b vamps and 'I've Got the Power'-style beats for a steady stream of MST3K chatter.
Manages both reverence and joy.
Essell is brightly malevolent, and Stiller is perfect as the well-meaning homeowner.
A thirdhand lark.
The film's problems are too numerous to list, but look for the boom mic at approximately 45m.
Zucker orchestrates the gags with great relish, lunging for the funny bone with sweetly idiotic characters, relentless slapstick, and topping sight gags.
George's portrait of hobo lives gets stuck in self-absorption.
Styles range from cabaret to barbershop to toe-tapping bubblegum, and the rainy-day serenade at the start nods Cherbourgward, with a soupçon of Low Countries sass.
movie_title: Ja zuster, nee zuster (Yes Nurse! No Nurse!) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Crammed with wild action, obvious but well-mounted gags, and playful effects, the film is refreshingly silly.
Transpires in a somewhat chintzy fantasy kingdom lousy with more cameos than your typical Love Boat season.
The star-is-born trajectory nourishes some howlers ... as well as a thumpingly unsubtle portrayal of the creative process.
Paige eventually comes to a self-affirming decision, but the Danish interlude succeeds too well in making us feel her boredom.
The filmmakers don't have enough faith in the world they've created.
His nostalgia enabled by technology, Conran takes the ghosts in his machine seriously, and the results appear at once meltingly lovely and intriguingly inhuman.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I remember best [Gilda's] mutable hair, which went from a bob to a wave to a longish Angelina Jolie coif.
Though the acting is tentative at times, with performances not quite landing on the same page, Evergreen is a compassionate slice of Pacific Northwest misery.

In the rare moments when a rifle, grenade, howitzer, bayonet, dagger, fist, land mine, or flamethrower isn't being deployed, the film pushes its melodramatic plotline with soap operatic shamelessness.
movie_title: Tae Guk Gi: The Brotherhood of War (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Scenes end abruptly, laughs are as rare as yetis, and the overarching question seems to be: Can we turn this into a franchise?
Aside from cameos by Jim Broadbent (as the drunken major) and Peter O'Toole (as Nina's reclusive, eccentric father), much of the acting strains for a sophistication that quickly becomes annoying.
Stormy twentysomething emotions seethe under a deft quirkfest.
E J-Yong's transposition illuminates, with satisfying crispness, the hyper-Confucian high society of the time, as well as the underground Catholic movement.

At times it plays like an affecting portrait of a marriage on life support intersecting with an earnest coming-of-age story, at times like a Lands' End catalog in which all the models have been instructed to squint at the middle distance.
As parody, it's toothless and often smug, but as random Ferrellspeak generator, it has its delights.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most satisfying comedy of the past year -- at least among the ones starring Stiller.
Hard to recommend, with its haphazard tone, wobbly acting, and cipher-like lead.
Stateside's real-life frame allows the complexities of mental illness and military service to lose dramatic tension, resulting in a desultory home stretch.
The orgy of morphing, shrieking, lightning-cracking, and habitual rope-swinging quickly turns oppressive.
An affecting, inside-out portrait of the artist as a young schizophrenic.

Foreman aficionados may want to keep the curtains of this theater drawn, and listen as his fertile lines suggest what could have been: 'The space between the trees is blank enough for something interesting to happen in it.'
Starsky & Hutch and 21 Jump Street, for instance, were a hoot. Hollywood should have quit while it was ahead, though, because CHiPs is the antithesis of a hoot.
Although the script tackles the dilemmas of resistance and collaboration, it never rises above the level of a television movie.

Nicolas Pesce's film opens with an air of originality and deep disquiet and beautifully framed black-and-white photography... Unfortunately, in the second half it descends into... gratuitous torture porn.
You brace yourself for the worst with this adaptation of the kids' TV favourite but it's actually rather fun.

The power of Clay Tweel's tear-jerking documentary, based on Gleason's video diaries, comes from the honesty and humour with which Gleason presents the gradual loss of control over his bodily functions.
[A] quietly provocative drama.
Personal Shopper is unusual and unsettling, but not quite as clever as it thinks it is.
How Pierce Brosnan must miss the days of playing James Bond.

With a budget of $150 million The Great Wall is the most expensive co-production yet between America and China, but any hopes that it might foster a new spirit of cinematic co-operation are marred by its being, well, a bit rubbish.
A note-perfect parody of the British Technicolor horror films of the Sixties.

Yes, the story may have been panel-beaten into a gleaming, Oscar-friendly shape. That Hidden Figures is still so entertaining and moving is due in large part to a hugely likeable central trio of performances.

The man, played with dark relish by Michael Keaton, has the fabulous name of Ray Kroc (there is a suitably reptilian air to his grin as he says things such as: "Contracts are like hearts. They're made to be broken").
It's apt, I suppose: an unfunny comedy about an unfunny comedian.
After Love shows that the French still have plenty to say about the bloody endgame of romance.
He specialises in stories about impossible dreams and defying nature and for his latest film Werner Herzog turns to the most ambitious, abominable creation of them all: the internet.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ethel & Ernest is the kind of contemplative grown-up animation that the Japanese have been making for decades but the British have never fully embraced. That's our loss because the format can make for deceptively powerful filmmaking.
An uncomfortable blend of war movie, family drama and dystopian sci-fi.
Veronica is the trophy wife of a reptilian businessman. Ashley is a struggling artist who paints pictures of decapitated sperm. Both are vile.
A humane morality play, set against the murky bureaucracy of post-communist Romania.
A hugely likeable animated film about two cornerstones of childhood: wild imaginations and bottom jokes.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Free Fire is all about bullets and quips. Neither hit their targets 100 per cent of the time but enough do to make this one of the more diverting shoot'em-ups.
If ever a band cried out to star in a documentary, it was Oasis.
This is a queasy Netflix film about anorexia whose good intentions are undermined by its aura of starvation chic.
Mullan is never less than compelling, but the editing is abrupt, the story is formulaic and the sparky dialogue is submerged under a clubhouse of dour Scots clichés.

A bracingly cynical set-up is slightly betrayed by a treacly ending, but redeemed by the cast, especially the watchable Seyfried and MacLaine, who has the same glint in her eyes that she had in 1960 in The Apartment.
This experimental drama by Jon Sanders is brave and radical but not, sadly, enjoyable or engaging.

The "It" of the title refers to the contagious disease that has devastated the outside world (a world that, like much in this beautifully minimalist film, we never see), but it also denotes something even more virulent and destructive: human fear.
The Red Turtle is a dialogue-free love story, strange and sparingly supernatural.

Alan G Parker's film is an overlong, tedious parade of familiar talking heads (Hunter Davies, Pete Best) trotting out familiar anecdotes and, significantly for a film about an album, there's not a note of Beatles music.
movie_title: It Was Fifty Years Ago Today... Sgt Pepper and Beyond (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If this were a spoof, it would be a work of genius. Sadly, it's played straight, a glossy melodrama-cum-thriller of staggering cheesiness and unintentional hilarity.

Mohamed Diab's superb Egyptian drama is set in the aftermath of the overthrow of President Morsi in 2013, with the army engaged in running battles on the streets with the pro-Morsi Muslim Brotherhood.

Christine Franz's film is overlong and, like many music documentaries, slightly overstates the importance of its subject. However, it captures the mundanity of their working-class background [and] the intensity of their live shows.
This is Warren Beatty's first film as director in almost 20 years and it really wasn't worth the wait.
It's elevated above bog-standard biopic fare by the performances.
This west London-set neo-noir has moody lighting, edgy camerawork and femmes fatales aplenty, but it could have paid less attention to style and more to storytelling.
Raoul Peck's lyrical documentary was nominated for an Oscar this year, and it really should have won.
Grief and guilt, then, and Arnie's portrait of desolation is quite powerful, if rather one-note (he favours the school of stoic mourning).
This chilling chamber piece from the Norwegian director André Ovredal is an exercise in restrained horror.
A splurge of gruesome effects and cosmic mumbo-jumbo that neither makes sense nor provides anything approaching a real scare.
This feels like austerity Almodóvar: pared down but no less powerful for it.
If you don't know what helicoptering and blossom are, they will be forever etched on your consciousness by the time Waters takes his bow.
It's not as funny as Spinal Tap (which film is?), but there are still a fistful of laugh-out-loud moments.

The makers of Hot Pursuit would love to add Reese Witherspoon and Sofía Vergara to that list of great odd couples in road movies. They won't, because the two entirely lack what those other duos had in abundance -- chemistry.
John Madec is a millionaire with an array of expensive toys... He's Douglas's nastiest creation since Gordon Gekko in Wall Street.
A bit like a cross between Before Sunrise and An American Werewolf in London but nowhere near as good as either.
Joanna Lipper's documentary tells an important story that will be unfamiliar to many Westerners, although it could do with more panache in its telling.
Kung-fu hip-hop musicals don't come along very often, and having seen this one, I'm quite glad about that.
The latest film from the prolific, provocative French director François Ozon.
Poltergeist is an update of the 1982 horror of the same name and remains faithful to its story: spirits terrorise a suburban family and make a beeline for the youngest of their three children.

This engrossing centrepiece meshes with subplots involving Burnham's dysfunctional family and unbalanced neighbours, in a virtuoso study of isolation, repression and fulfilment. Mendes infuses the lush visuals and lyrical script with dramatic panache.
The acting, script and production values rarely rise above film-school level and, once she has drawn him some anatomical diagrams (really!), the bedroom scenes are just awful.

It's like being hit over the head repeatedly with a very expensive, very loud train set.After two and a half hours in this bludgeoning company, you're begging Bay to put away the boys' toys and make a rom-com.

The film is let down by inauthentic dialogue and plotting that unravels rather embarrassingly in the final reel. But the tension is well sustained and Treadaway's performance is full of pallid intensity.

Godard opens up his box of tricks and tips it all over the screen in a flurry of improvised, postmodernism that takes scattergun shots at consumerism, cultural imperialism and the Vietnam and Algerian wars.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: The performances drip with cliché, while the narrative is all over the place: plot developments are either clumsily telegraphed or given the flimsiest of dramatic explanation.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet, if slightly stagey, documentary-drama.
Unlike most sequels, this "bigger, busier" strategy pays off, resulting in a romp that's as affable as it is inventive.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As messy, jarring and disorientating as the Eighties London in which it's set. Thirty years on, though, it's also a seamy snapshot of a time when bohemian lefties embraced the lower classes and multiculturalism as if they were new albums by Talk Talk.
Gerard Depardieu as the walrus of lurve chansons? It's unlikely, but it works.
[Diesel] has been a dab hand with hit points and 20-sided dice since the Eighties... This, sadly, has convinced the 48-year-old that it was OK to produce The Last Witch Hunter.
More interesting than most popcorn thrillers.
The Hallow is a horror movie in which evil black gunge plays a key role and rural Ireland is the backdrop. A bit like Dark Water meets Ballykissangel, but worse than both.
Unfortunately, although it conveys plenty of the tedium of soldiering, there's little of the drama that I assume it also features.
movie_title: Tell Spring Not To Come This Year (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There are scares from the off in the short, punchy horror Lights Out, adapted by the director David F Sandberg from his short film.
It plays out like a Gallic version of The Trip, the sitcom starring Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon, but with fewer gags.
A remake of the equally unmemorable children's film of 1977,
Anders Thomas Jensen is one of Denmark's most fêted film-makers, the winner of two Oscars and a man with a knack for twisted comedies.
Stylishly mounted, well paced, with clever use of flashbacks, and written with panache.
Adults may find that a bit much. Kids, I suspect, will lap it up.
Taking its name from a fictional smartphone game in which contestants roam New York completing challenges and are whittled down until only one remains, Nerve is basically Pokémon Go meets Highlander.

Unfortunately, the psychedelic imagination that director Maksim Fadeev brings to the minor characters in this kids' cartoon from Russia is not matched by the animation, which is clunky to put it kindly.
A film called Anguish hardly sounds enticing but I think I'd prefer anguish to what this arthouse horror actually serves up, which is plain tedium.
It's a profoundly depressing tale, but beautifully photographed in black and white.
Victoria is the film that out-Birdmans Birdman.
Curious but quietly powerful.
This affectionate documentary is one for the fans, but there are more of them than ever after Staples revived her career with the help of the Wilco frontman Jeff Tweedy.
It's as ruggedly constructed and guilelessly entertaining as its leading man, Chris Pine.
How many other permutations of Manhattan mating rituals can there be? No really interesting ones, is the short answer.
It's a long way from Pretty Woman.
The Fear of 13 is riveting and that's mainly due to its extraordinary subject.
It's always a pleasure to see Mark Strong in a lead role -- too often he's wasted as baddies and bosses. In Closer to the Moon he gets his most interesting part in a while.
This surreal but shonky Mexican animation makes the clichéd link between monstrous transformation and adolescence and does absolutely nothing new with it.
It's all amiably silly and definitely an option for half-term.

This is a harrowing watch, with footage of executions -- the emotional toll on the men is tangible. Yet RBSS is performing an essential duty; it is often the only conduit of reliable news from Raqqa to the wider world.
... achieves the unusual feat of being nasty - and boring.
Shaul Schwarz and Christina Clusiau's disturbing documentary digs into the murk of the African big-game trade with candour and even-handedness.
... a soulful portrait of a private man who was forced to become a standard-bearer for grief and did it admirably.
We knew Bening could do sexy, but this is newer terrain for Bell, who has played a few too many boys and bit parts in recent years.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are generally woeful.
A tremendous piece of cinematic rug-pulling.
Hamm is note-perfect in the role, programmed to be charming and empathetic but prone to gaucheness when someone wrong-foots his software.
Moving but rather reverent.
Scandi-noir takes a supernatural turn in Joachim Trier's creepy, erotic thriller.
There's sometimes a perverse pleasure to be had in seeing fine actors slumming it in crass movies. Not here.
Vincent Cassel lays on the tortured-artist schtick extra-thick in this ultimately tedious French-language portrait of the artist Paul Gauguin.
A bizarre mix of exhilarating and reprehensible. Not good, bro.

Torture-porn fans rejoice! The franchise that lumbered on for seven films and grossed almost a billion dollars has been revived, meaning that another group of luckless so-and-so's are facing a series of gruesome tests that they probably won't survive.
A mediocre film would use Elio's parents as a one-note backdrop to his affair: oblivious, disbelieving, disapproving or draconian. Here they are none of those things.
[Deliver Us] is uncomfortably exploitative.
[A] feeble French John le Carré knock-off.
... Cuba's geriatric music troupe get a touching send-off in Lucy Walker's hagiographic but moving documentary.
Why has nobody thought of this before - the Nativity retold for kids via knockabout animal animation and gloopy pop ballads? Oh yes, because it's an absolutely dreadful idea.
... feels more like a sequence of box-ticking perils than a genuine survival story, and the female characters (sexy traveller, sexy indigenous woman) are painfully two-dimensional.
Brett Morgen's elegant if rather one-note documentary follows Jane Goodall, one of the top authorities on chimpanzees, from fearless twentysomething to respected eco-ambassador.
... biopic of a French icon that's beautifully photographed, sensitively acted and punishingly dull.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We know the ending - Switzerland gave women the vote, becoming one of the last European countries to do so - but this is a warm telling of a neglected story.
A considerable buzz online suggested that this Spanish horror might arrest the recent run of iffy Netflix movies. Sadly, it doesn't.

The shots of scorched red landscapes and dried-up riverbeds are often rapturous and [director Warwick] Thornton's habit of interspersing the action with quick, silent flashbacks and flashforwards adds an air of unsettling fatalism.

Such ridiculousness should be funny, but it's not, possibly because the world it's lampooning was so laughable in the first place. Best entertainment in the world? This isn't even the best entertainment in Marsden.
It's clever, silly, slick and fun.
Gerwig's deft handling of script, camera and actors is all the more impressive given that this is her first film as solo director.

I'm still not sure what the paradox of the title is. Perhaps it refers to the impossibility of offloading a film to Netflix at the 11th hour, as Paramount has done, and still expecting it to be a hit.
The toil becomes mythical; there are heartbreaking echoes of The Old Man and the Sea as thieves run off with some of his hard-won cargo.
As funny as it is moving.
If it is a swansong for YA, it's a solid one.
This is a dark and honest heartbreaker, built around a trio of tragedies.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The self-pitying white man may not deserve our pity, but Stiller wins it anyway.
It's amiable stuff, but rather infantile - about as hard-bitten and plausible as an episode of The A-Team, and with a similar standard of acting.
... a movie of both substance and silliness. Olés all round.
You can see where this is heading, but it just doesn't work, and most of that, sadly, is down to Coogan.

This, remarkably, is the first time that America's best-loved living actor, actress and director have worked together. It's a film worthy of their talents, a vivid Valentine to America's First Amendment and the golden age of newspapers.
It's slow, sensual and gorgeously observed.
The best that can be said for Daddy's Home 2 is that it's slightly less awful than its recent female-led counterpart, A Bad Moms Christmas.
... there's just about enough darkness and irreverence amid the candy-coloured moralising to sustain parents to the end.
I can't remember violence in a film eliciting such verbal reactions.

Just as Toy Story did by featuring an owner of the toys, it reminds us that these films are about play and imagination. Yes, they're also effectively feature-length adverts for Lego, but this is rampant capitalism at its most arch and entertaining.
The two Voyager space probes are the subjects of this appropriately epic documentary, full of lavish visuals, brain-frying statistics and infectiously enthusiastic Nasa boffins.
Directed by Simon West, who made the infinitely superior Con Air, it teeters under the weight of its clichés.
It's all done with vim and it doesn't take itself too seriously; just as well given the lurid violence and black-magic subplot.
Beneath the blood and balefulness it's a light-hearted confection, with a whiff of Blackadder in the period caricatures and shameless mugging.
Sunbeams illuminating tropical fish, sea lions shimmying through a kelp forest -- some of the underwater photography is gorgeous in Jérôme Salle's glossy French-language biopic of Jacques Cousteau.

In Stanley Tucci's spare, sly film, Geoffrey Rush blends cantankerous charisma and seething self-doubt as the Italian-Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti, with Armie Hammer as the suave American writer whom he asks to sit for him in his chaotic studio.
An uneasy hybrid of gritty Mexican drama and weird, David Cronenberg-style body horror.
Given the monumental scariness of the original documentary, it's striking how optimistic sections of this one are.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Simultaneously twee and tedious, whimsical and unengaging.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mark O'Connor's film is a formulaic, but confidently handled gangster flick set in the rock-hard Darndale district of north Dublin.

The title suggests an orgy of the undead loaded with jump scares, but this is a more restrained and more disturbing proposition. The monster here is metaphorical: part depression, part manic obsession.

The title of Morgan Matthews's insightful film doesn't just refer to Frank Williams, the boss of the Williams Formula One team. This film transcends the remit of the sports documentary by also focusing on his late wife Virginia.
Not only does this film hate its very subject matter, it's also the most hideous example of product placement in cinematic history.
A raunchy comedy that's high on the raunch, but rather low on the comedy.
Seldom has a teen protagonist been as annoying as the one in this high-concept high-school horror.
After the success last year of The Shallows, here's another schlocky but brazenly entertaining thriller pitting American woman against homicidal shark in Mexico.
"I like your name," said David Bowie when he first met Mick Rock. "It can't be real." Well it was, and Rock would more than live up to it.
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Philip John's feature debut ends up being rather lovely, thanks to a light directorial touch and endearing performances from its three leads.
A curious but ultimately humane story of brutality and grief on a vast Native American reserve in Wyoming.

Francis Lee's splendid directorial debut has been billed as a Yorkshire Brokeback Mountain and there are undeniable parallels... God's Own Country, however, is significantly less glamorous than its Oscar-nominated predecessor.
Dennis Skinner is one of our most colourful and principled MPs... A shame, then, that the Beast of Bolsover comes across as either smug or boring for much of this hagiographic documentary.
movie_title: Dennis Skinner: Nature of the Beast (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing premise becomes a bit of a dog's dinner in Marianna Palka's dark indie parable.
It's best described as a Kiwi Napoleon Dynamite, gawky, deadpan and poignant.
Dibb's film at times feels of a piece with Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk, from the oppressive immediacy of the camerawork to the heavy, droning soundtrack.
This wry documentary focuses on the original entertainer-turned-president and his box of showbiz tricks.

If you're looking for a film to dissuade people from joining a band, this is it.Michael Winterbottom's docudrama explores the dark side of touring -- not the sex and drugs (oh, for more of that) but the utter tedium.

The heist bit is quite smartly handled, with James Franco rocking a natty moustache-and-mullet combo as a bank employee and Taryn Manning... impressively obstreperous as one of the robbers. The horror part, however, is dreadfully underpowered.
The film moves at a good lick and it's directed with a light touch by David Leveaux.

The sincerity and sentiment of this film are there to be basked in. Yet audiences outside Japan may find the subject too serious and yet too slight; there's a reason why films about potential incest aren't often as cute as this.
Eden surprises by managing to paint a vivid and disturbing picture of the trafficking experience within the context of a conventional thriller.

An authentically awkward, ordinary life, scrupulously observed.

A film which says little of consequence beyond fictionalizing its target; only Bisset's Lady Macbeth-like presence hits an appropriately hysterical note for this tabloid-trashy film which quickly chokes on its pretensions.

Compellingly weird and occasionally wonderful to behold.

A well executed minor drama that casts a careful life on the inner lives of military personnel, and promises good things to come in terms of the young cast, and Tom Petch's future career.
